Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: And of his porte As Meke as is A Mayde
He neủer yett no villanye ne sayde
In all his lyfe vnto no mane wyghte
He was A gentulle parfytte knyghte
For to telle you of his Araye
His horse was gode butte he was notte gaye
Of Fustyan he werede A Gypoun
All by smeterede with his habergoune
For he was late ycome Frome his vyage
And wente For to doone his pilgrymage
With hym þ̉er was his sone A yonge sqwyer
A louer And a lustye bacchelere
With lockes crulle As they were leyde in presse
Of twenty yere of Age he was as I gesse
Of his stature he was of euene lengthe
And wonderlye delyuoure And clene of strengthe
And hadde bene some tyme in Chyuachie
In Flaunders in Artoys ⁊and in pyckardye
And borne hym welle As of litulle space
In hope to stande in his ladye grace
Euene browede was he As hitt were A Mayde
And Fulle of fresche Flowers whyte ⁊and rede
Syngenge he was And Floytenge all þe daye
He was as Fresche As is þe moneþe of Maije
Schorte was his gowne wᵗith sleues longe ⁊and wyde
Welle couþe he sytten on horse ⁊and Fayer ryde
He couþe songes make And welle endyte
Iuste ⁊and eke dawnce ⁊and welle purtrewe ⁊and wryte
So hote he louede that by nyghtertale
He slepte no More þan A nyghtyngale
Curtayse he was lowlye And sarvysable
And karuede bifore his Fader Atte the table
A yeman hadde he And saruantes no Mo
As atte þᵗat tyme For hym luste ryde th
And he was cladde in Cote And hode of grene
A Schefe of Arrowes brighte ⁊and keene
Vnder his belte he bare Fulle þryfftelye
Welle couþe he dresse his tabulle yemanlye
His Arrowes drowpnyde noughte wᵗith Fethurs lowe
And in his hande he bare A Mightye bowe
A notte hede hadde he wᵗith A browne vysage
Of woode craffte couþe he all the vsage
Vppon his Arme he bare A gaye braser
And by his Syde A swerde ⁊and A buckeler
And on that oþ̉ere syde A gaye daggar
Harneysede welle ⁊and scharpe As poynte of Spere
A Cristoffle on his backe welle schene
An horne he bare the Bawderike was grene
A Forster was he soþelye As I gesse
There was Allso a Nonne A prioresse
That of hyr Smylenge was semple ⁊and koye
Her gretteste othe nas butte by Saynte loye
And sche was clepede Madame Eglentyne
Fulle welle Sche sange the saruyce deuyne
Entunede in her voyce welle semelye
And Fresche Sche spake Fayer ⁊and Fetuslye
Affter the scoole of Stratteforde atte þe bowe
For Frensche of paryce was to hyr vnknowe
Atte þe Mete welle ytaughte was sche Fulle welle
Sche lete no Morselle Frome her Mouthe Falle
Ne wete hyr Fyngurs in hyr Sawce deepe
Welle couþe sche carrye A morselle of Mete
That no droppe ne Felle vppon hyr breste
In curtasye was sette Fulle Meke hyr luste
Hyr ouer lyppe wypede sche so clene
That in hir cuppe þ̉er nas no Foylenge seene
Of grese whan sche hadde dronke her draughte
Fulle semelye Affter hyr Mete sche raughte
And sykerlye sche was of grete disporte
And Fulle plesaunte and Fulle Amyable of porte
And paynede hyr to Counterfette chere
Of courte to bene estatelye of Manere
And to be holden dygne of reuerence
Butte For to Speke of hyr Conscience
Sche was to Charitable ⁊and to pyteouse
For sche wolde wepe yefe sche sawe A Mouse
Caughte in A trappe yefe hitt were eyther dede or bledde
Of smale howndes hadde sche þat sche Fedde
With rostede Flesche other Mylke other wastelle brede
Butte sore wepte sche yefe one of hem were dede
Other yefe Men smote hitt wᵗith A yerde smerte
And all was conscyence And tendure herte
Fulle semelye hyr wymple pynchede was
Hyr nose strayte hyr eyene As graye as glasse
Hyr Mouthe Fulle smale ⁊and þ̉erto soffte ⁊and rede
Butte sikurlye Sche hadde A Fayer Forehede
Hitt was Almoste A Spanne of brede I trowe
For hardelye sche nas noughte vnder growe
Fulle Fete was hyr Cloke As I was ware
Of smale Coralle Abowte hyr Arme sche bare
A payer of bedes ygawdiede All with grene
And þ̉eron hynge A broche of golde welle schene
On whiche þ̉er was Firste wrytten A crownede A
And affter Amor vincit omia
Another nonne with hyr was sche
That was hyr chapelayne And preestes thre
A Monke þ̉er was A Fayer For the Maystrie
An owte ryder that louede venerye
A Manelye Man to be an Abbott able
Fulle manye A deynte horse he hadde in stable
And whan he rode Men myghte his brydulle here
Gyngelenge in A whystelenge wynde As clere
And eke As lowde as dothe A chapelle belle
There as this lorde was kepere of the selle
The rule of saynte Mawr oþ̉ere of saynte benette
Bicause itt was olde And somedele strayte
Thys ylke Monke lete olde thynges passe
And helde affter þe newe worlde the paase
He yafe noughte of the tyxte A pullede henne
That sayethe that hunters be none holye Men
Thoughe þat A Monke whan he is recchelese
Is lyckenede vnto A Fysche þat is waterlese
That is to saye A Monke þat is owte of cloystre
Thilke texte holte he notte worþe An oystre
And I sayde his openyou was gode
Whatt schulde he studye And make hym selfe woode
Vppon a boke allwaye in cloystre to pore
Other swynken wᵗith his handes ⁊and laboure
As Austyne bytte how schall þe worlde be saruede
Lette Austyne haue his swynke to hym resaruede
Therefor he was A predicator Arighte
Greyhowndes he hadde As swyffte as Fowle in Flyghte
Of pryckenge And of huntenge For the hare
Was all his luste For no Coste wolde he spare
I sawe his sleues purflede Atte the honde
Wᵗith Gryce ⁊and that þe Fyneste of A londe
And for to Festene his hode vnder the chynne
He hadde of golde wroughte A Fulle curiouse pynne
A loue knotte in þe gretter ende þ̉er was
His hede was ballede þat schone As the glasse
And eke his Face As hitt hadde be Anoynte
He was A lorde Fulle Fatte ⁊and in Fulle gode poynte
His eyene stepe ⁊and rollenge in his hede
That Stemede As a Fournayse of lede
His botes Souple his horses in grete estate
Now sartaynelye he was A Fayer prelate
He nas notte paale As A Sore pynede Goste
A Fatte swane louede he best of enye Roste
His pallfraye was As browne as is A berye
A Fryer þ̉er was A wantou ⁊and A Merye
A lymytour And a Fulle solempne Man
In all þe orders þ̉er nys none þᵗat better can
So moche of dalyaıı̄unce And So Fayer language
He hadde made Manye A Fayer Mariage
Of yonge wymmen Atte his owne Coste
Vntille þe ordre he was A noble poste
Fulle welle bilouede and Fulle Famylar was he
With Franklayns oủer all in that Contre
And with worthye wymmen of þe towne
For he hadde powere of Confessioun
And sayde hym selfe More þan A Curate
For his ordre he was licenciate
Fulle swetelye harde his Confessiou
And plesaunte was his Absolucou
He was An esye Man to yeue penᵃnce
There As he hopede to haue A gode petᵃunce
For vnto A poure ordre For to yeue
Is signe þat A Man is welle schryue
For yefe he yafe he durste make Auᵃnte
He wyste þat A Man was repentuᵃnte
For manye A Man so harde is of his herte
He maye noughte wepe All þoughe he sore smerte
Therefore in Stede of wepenge and of pᵃyours
Men mis Moste yeue siluer vnto powre Fryers
His typpette was Ay Farsede Fulle of knyues
And pynnes For to yeue Fayer wyues
And insartayne he hadde A Merye note
Welle couþe he synge ⁊and playe in A rote
Of ȝeddenges he bare vtterlye the pryce
His necke whyte was As Flower delyce
Therto he stronge was as A Champyoun
He knewe the tauerners welle in euerye Towne
And euerye hostyller And Tapsterr
Better þan A lazar or A beggestar
For vnto suche A Man as he
Acordethe noughte As by his Faculte
To haue wᵗith suche lazers Aqweyntance
Hit nys noughte honeste hitt maye notte auᵃnce
For to dele with Suche porrayle
Butte all with ryche And sellers of vytayle
And oủer all there As profytte schulde aryse
Curtayse he was And lowlye of Saruyse
There was no Man no where so vertuouse
He was the best begger in his howse
For þeye A wydowe hadde noughte A schoo
So plesaunte wh was his In principio
Yette wolle he haue A Ferthenge er þat he wente
His pʳchace was welle better where þat he wente
And Rage he couþe As hitt were A whelpe
In loue dayes þ̉er couþe he moche helpe
For þ̉er he was noughte lyke A Cloystre
With A threde bare Cope As is A Scoler
Butte he was lyke A Mayster or A pope
Of double worstede was his semye Cope
That rowndede was as A belle owte of presse
Somewhatt he lypsede For his wantounesse
To make his englysche swete vppon his tonge
And in his harpenge whan þat he hadde Songe
His eyene twynklede in his hede arighte
As doone the Starres on the Frostye nyghte
This worthy lymytour was callede hubert
A M̉erchaunte þ̉er was there wᵗith A Forkede berde
In Mottele on heyghe on horse he sate
Vppon his hede A Flawnders bevyr hatte
His bootes clapsede Fayer And Fetouselye
His resounes he spake Fulle Solepnelye
Schewenge allweye þe encrece of his wynnenge
He wolde the Se were kepte in enye þynge
Bitwyxe Myddelboroughe ⁊and Orwelle
Well couþe he in eschaunge Schyldes selle
This worthye man Fulle welle his wytte bisette
There wyste no wyghte þat he was in dette
So estatelye was he of goủernawnce
With his bargaynes And with his Cheuysaunce
Forsoþe he was A worthye Man with all
Butte soþe to Sayen I notte how Men hym calle
A Clerke þere was of Oxenforde Allso
That vnto logyke hadde longe tyme go
As lene was his horse As is A Rake
And he was notte Fatte I vndertake
Butte lokede hollowe And þ̉erto soburlye
Fulle threde bare was his oủereste kaurteby
For he hadde notte getene hym no bnfyce
Ne was noughte worthye to haue none office
For hym was leủere Atte his beddes hede
XXᵗⁱ bokes cladde in blacke oþ̉ere in rede
Of Aristotle ⁊and of his phillosophye
Than Robes Ryche or off Fyther or Sawterye
Butte all be that he was A phillosopher
Yette hadde he butte litulle golde in Cofure
Butte all þat he myghte of his Frendes helpe
On bokes And on lernenge he hitt Spente
And beselye ganne For tho sowles praye
For them þat yafe hym to scole huyre
Of studye toke he moste Cure ⁊and hede
Noughte one worde spake he more þan was nede
And that was Sayde in Fourme And in reủerence
And schorte ⁊and qwycke And of hyghe Sentence
Sownenge in Moralle vertue was his Speche
And gladelye wolde he lerne and gladely teche
A Sargaunte of lawe ware ⁊and wyse
That offten hadde bene hadde bene atte paruyse
He was allso Fulle ryche of excellence
Discrete he was And of grete reủerence
He semede suche his wordes were So wyse
Iustyse he was Fulle often in Assyse
By patente And by playne Comyssiou
For his Science And his heyghe renowne
Of Fees And Robes he hadde Manye one
So grete A pʳchasoure was no where none
As was Fee Semple to hym in effecte
His pʳchasenge myghte noughte be to hym in Suspecte
No where So besye A Man as he þ̉er nas
And yett he Semede besyer þan he was
In termes hadde causes And domes all
That Frome þe tyme of kynge willᵃm were Falle
Therto he couþe endyte And make a þynge
Ther couþe no wyghte pynche Atte his wrytenge
And euerye Statute couþe he playnelye by rote
He rode butte onelye in A Medelede Cote
Y gurdede wᵗith A gurdulle of Sylke ⁊and harneyse Smale
Of his Araye telle I no lenger tale
A Franklayne þ̉er was in his Componye
Whyte was his berde As is the Dayesye
Of his complexiou he was Sangweyne
Welle louede he by the Morowe A Soppe of wyn
To lyue in delyte was eủer his woone
For he was Epiorous his owne Sone
That helde openyone that playne delyte
Was vereye Felicite ⁊and parfytte
An howseholder And þat A grete was he
Saynte Iulyan he was in his Contre
His brede his Ale was all affter oone
A better envynede Man was þ̉er noone
Withouten bake Mete was neủer his howse
His Fysche his Flesche was so plenteouse
Hitt Snewede in his howse of Mete ⁊and drynke
Of all deyntees þat Men couþe thynke
Affter the sondery sesounes of the yere
So chaungede he his Mete ⁊and his Soupere
Fulle manye A Fatte partrycche hadde he in Mue
And Manye A breme ⁊and Manye A luce in Stue
Woo was his Cooke butte his Sawce were
Poynaunte And Scharpe ⁊and redye all his gere
His tabulle dormaunte in his halle was allwey
Stode redye coủerede All the longe daye
Atte Sessyans þ̉er was he lorde ⁊and Syer
Fulle offten tyme was he þe knyghte of Schyre
An Awlas ⁊and A Gypser bare he all of Sylke
Hynge Atte his girdulle As whyte as Morowe Mylke
A Schryve hadde he be And Acounter
Was no where Suche A worthy vauasour
An haberdasscher ⁊and A Carpynter
A Webberr A dyser A Tapestarr
And þey werne clothede All in oone lyvereye
Of A solempne ⁊and of A grete Fraternyte
Fulle Fresche And newe her gere was
His knyues was notte chapede of brasse
Butte all with Siluer wroughte clene ⁊and welle
Hyr gurdilles ⁊and hyr powches euerydele
Welle Semede ylke of hem A Fayer burgeyse
To Syttene in An hyghe halle on A dease
Euerye For þe wysedome that he can
Was Schapelye to haue bene an Alderman
For cattelle hadde þeye ynoughe ⁊and rente
And eke hyr wyues wolde hitt welle assente
And elles Sartayne þey were to blame
Hitt is Fulle Fayer to be clepede Madame
And to go virgilees All byfore
And haue A Mantelle afore hem ybore
A Cooke þey hadde with hem For þe nones
To boyle the Chyckunes with the Marybones
And powder Mᵃrchuᵃnte tarte ⁊and galyngale
Welle couþe he knowe A draughte of londou Ale
He couþe Roste Sethe boyle ⁊and Frye
Make Mortreuse ⁊and welle bake A pye
Butte grete harme was hitt As hitt þoughte me
That on his Schynne A Mormale hadde he
For blanke Maung made he with þe best
A schypeman was þ̉er wonenge by weste
For oughte I wote he was of Dartemouþe
He rode vppon A rouncye as he couþe
In A gowne of Foldenge to the knee
A daggar hangenge in A lace hadde he
Abowte his necke vnder his Arme adowne
The hote Somer hadde made his hwe all doune
And Sartayne he was A gode Fellowe
Fulle manye A draughte of wyn hadde he drawe
Frome Burdeuse warde whyle þe Schypman slepe
Of nyce Conscience toke he no kepe
Of that he Faughte And hadde þe heygher hande
By water he Sente hem home by euerye lande
Butte of his craffte to recken welle the Tydes
His Stremes And his daungeres hym besydes
His herborowe And his Moone ⁊and his lodemenage
There was no suche Frome hulle to Cartage
Hardye he was And wyse to vndertake
With manye A tempeste hadde his berde be schake
He knewe All þe havynnes as þey were
Frome Scottelande vntille Cape Fenestr
And Emarye Greke in Britaygne ⁊and in Spayne
His barge hitt was yclepede the Mawdelyne
With vs there was A doctoure of phisyke
In all þe worlde þ̉er was Man hym lyke
He spake of physike And of Surgerye
For he was groundede In Astronomye
He kepte his paciente A Fulle grete dole
In howre by his Magyke naturalle
Welle couþe he Fortune the Ascendent
Of his ymagike For the paciente
He knewe the cause of euerye Malladye
Were hitt of hete Colde Moyste or drye
And where engendereþe of whatt humoᵘure
He was A verye parfytte praktizer
The cause he knewe And of his harme þe roote
Anone he yafe þe Syke Man his boote
Fulle redye hadde he his Apottikaries
To sende hym his dregges And his lectuaries
For ylke of hem Made other For to wynne
Her Frendeschepe was notte newe to bigynne
Welle couþe he the olde esculapius
And Discordes And eke Ruphus
Of ypocrase halye And Galyene
Seraphyn Rasye And Auysenne
Aueroys Damassyen And Constantyne
Bernarde And Gatisden And Gybertyne
Of his dyette Mesurable was he
For hitt nas of no Suꝑperfluyte
Butte of grete noryschenge And digestible
His Studye was butte litulle on the bible
In Sangweyn And in perse ycladde was he wᵗith all
Y lynede with Taffata And with Sendelle
And yett he was butte esye of dispence
He kepte þat he wanne in pestilence
For golde in physyke is Acordaylle
Therefore he Sauede golde inespecialle
A gode wyfe þ̉er was of besyde bathe
Butte Sche was somedele deefe ⁊and þat was schat scathe
Of clothe makenge Sche hadde suche Anhᵃunte
Sche passede hem of ypryse And of Gawnte
In all þe parrische wyfe was þ̉er none
That to þe offerenge byforne her Schulde gone
And yefe þ̉er dydde Sartayne wrothe was Sche
That Sche was owte of all Charite
Her kerchuffes were Fulle Fyne of grounde
I durste Swere they wayede . x .li.
That vppon A Sonedaye were on her hede
Her hosene were of Fyne skarlette rede
Fulle Strayte ytayede ⁊and schoede Fulle newe
Bolde was her Face Fayer ⁊and rede of hwe
Sche was A worthy woman All her lyue
Husbandes Atte chirche þ̉er hadde sche Fyve
Withouten other Compaynye in youthe
Butte þ̉erofe nedethe notte to speke of nouthe
Atte yries hadde Sche be And atte Ierm
Sche hadde passede Manye A stᵃunge Streme
Atte Rome Sche hadde bene And atte boleygne
In Gales Atte Saynte Iames ⁊and Atte Coleygne
Sche couþe Myche of Iangelenge by the waye
Gappe tothede was Sche soþelye to saye
Vppon An Ambeler eselye Sche satte
Y wymplede welle And on her hede anhatte
As brode As is A buckeler other A Targette
A Foote Mantelle abowte her hyppes large
And on her Feete A payer of Spurres scharpe
Yn Fellischepe welle couþe sche lawghe ⁊and carpe
Of remedyes and loue Sche couþe ꝑperchaᵘunce
For Sche couþe of þarte Art the dawnce
A gode Man was there of Religiowne
And was A poure ꝑpersoune of A Towne
Butte ryche he was of holye werke ⁊and þoughte
He was allso A lernede Man A Clarke
That Cristis gospelle truelye wolde preche
His parrischons deuoutelye wolde he teche
Benynge he was And wonder diligente
And in Aduersyte Fulle paciente
And suche he was prouede offte Sythes
Fulle lothe were hym to cursene For his tythes
Butte rather wolde he yeuene owte of dowte
Vnto his poure parrischons Abowte
Of his offerenge And of his Substaunce
He couþe in litulle þynge haue Suffysaunce
Wyde was his parrische And howses Ferre asonder
Butte he ne leffte noughte For Rayne ne For thunder
In Syknesse More in Myschefe For to vesyte
The Ferreste in his parrische grete ⁊and lyte
Vppon his Feete And in his hande A Staffe
This noble ensample to his Schepe he yafe
That Firste he wroughte ⁊and affterwarde he taughte
Owte of the gospelle the wordes he caughte
And this Figure he Addede eke therto
That yefe golde Ruste whatte schall yren do
For yefe A preeste be Fowle in whom we truste
No wonder nys A lewde Man to Ruste
And Schame itt is yefe A preeste take kepe
A Schitten Scheparde ⁊and A clene Schepe
Welle aughte A preeste ensample to yeue
By his clennesse how þat his Schepe schulde lyue
He Sette noughte his bnfyce to huyere
And lette the schepe be Acombrede in the Myer
And rynne vnto londou to Saynte powles
And sechere hym A Chaunterye For Sowles
Other with A brotherhede to be wyþeholde
Butte dwelte Atte home ⁊and kepte welle his Folde
So that þe wolues ne made hitt noughte Myscarye
He was A Schepharde ⁊and noughte A M̉ercenarye
And þoughe he holye were And vertuouse
He was noughte to Synefulle Men disꝑperitous
Ne of his Speche daungerous ne digne
Butte in his Speche discrete ⁊and benygne
To drawe Folke to heuene by Fayernesse
By gode ensample this was his besynesse
Butte hitt were enye parsou of obstynacye
Who so he were of hyghe or lower estate
Hym wolde he Snybben schortelye For þe nones
A bettere preeste I trowe þ̉er no where is
He waytede Affter no pompe ne reủerence
Ne makede hym no Spycede Conscience
Butte Cristes lore ⁊and his Apostles twelue
He taughte butte Firste he Followede in hem selue
With hym þ̉er was A plowman was his brother
That hadde yladde of dounge Manye A Fother
A true Swynker And a gode was he
Lyenge in pease And in parfytte Charite
God louethe he best / with all his herte
Atte all tymes þoughe he gamede or Smerte
And þan hit neygheboure righte As hym Selue
He wolde thrassche And therto dyke and delue
For Cristes Sake For euerye poure wyghte
Withouten huyer For hitt laye in his Myghte
His tythes payede he Fulle Fayer And wele
Bothe of his propre Swynke And of his catelle
In the Tabbarde he rode vppon A Mere
There Allso was A Reve and A Myllere
A Somenoure And A pardoner allso
A Manciple and my selfe þ̉er was no Mo
The Myller was A Stowt Carle For þe nones
Fulle bygge he was of brayne And of bones
That prouede welle For All oủer there he cāme
Atte wrastelenge he wolde aweye haue þe Rame
He was schorte Schulderede A thycke knarre
There nas no durre þat he nolde heve on barre
Other breke hitt Atte rynnenge wᵗith his hede
And therto brode As hitt were A spade
Vppon the coppe righte on his nose he hadde
A werte ⁊and þ̉eron stode A Tuffte of heres
Rede As the brystulle of A Sowes Eares
His nosestrelles blacke were and wyde
A Swerde and bockeler bare he by his Syde
His Mouthe as grete As is A Fournayse
He was A Iangeler ⁊and A golyardeys
And that was Moste of Synne ⁊and of harlotryes
Welle couþe he Stele Corne ⁊and tolle hitt thryse
And þat he hadde A thombe of golde ꝑparde
A whyte Cote And a blewe hode werede he
A Bagge pype couþe he blowe And Sowne
And þ̉erwith all he broughte vs owte of Towne
A gentele Manciple þ̉er was of A Temple
Of whiche All doctours Mighte take ensample
For to be wyse in beyenge of vytayle
For whiche he payede other toke by entayle
Allgate he waytede So in his Acate
That aye he was Aforne ⁊and Aye in gode estate
Now is notte that of god A Fulle Fayer grace
That Suche A lewde Mannes wytte schall passe
The wysedome of An hepe of lernede Men
Of Maysters hadde he Mo þan thryse tenne
That were of lawe experte And curiouse
Of whiche þ̉er was A dossayne in þat howse
Worthye to be Stewardes of Rente ⁊and lande
Of enye lorde that is in Engelande
To make hym lyve in his propre gode
In honoure dettelese butte yefe he were wode
Other lyve As Scarselye as hym luste desyre
And able to helpen all A Schyre
In enye case that myghte Falle othyr happe
And yett this Manciple Sette her Alder Cappe
The Reve was A Sklendre Collerike Man
His berde was Schave As nyghe as eủer he can
His here was by his Eares rownde yschore
His toppe was dockede lyke A preeste byfore
Fulle longe were his legges And Fulle lene
Ylyke A Staffe þere was no Calfe yseene
Welle couþe he kepe A Garnarre ⁊and a bynne
There was none Auditoure couþe on hym wynne
Welle wyste he by the droughte ⁊and by the Rayne
The yeldenge of his Sede and of his Grayne
His lordes Schepe his Neete his dayerye
His Swyne his horse his Store ⁊and his pullterye
Was hole in this Reve his gouernenge
And by his couenᵃnte yafe the reckenenge
Sythen his lorde was of xxᵗⁱ yere of Age
There couþe no Man brynge hym in Arrage
That he ne knewe his Sleuthe ⁊and his couyne
There was no bayelyfe ne herde ne oþir hyne
They were Adradde of hym as of the dethe
His wonnenge was righte Fayer vppon an heethe
With grene treeis Schadowede was his place
He couþe better þan his lorde purchace
Fulle ryche he was Astorede preuelye
His lorde he couþe plese Crafftelye
To lene And to yeue hym of his owne gode
And haue a thancke And yett a Cote ⁊and an hode
In youthe he hadde lernede A gode Mayster
He was A welle gode wryghte A Carpynter
This Reve satte vppon A fulle gode Scotte
That was all pomelye grene ⁊and heyghe State
A longe Surcote of peers vppon he hadde
And by his Syde he bare A Rustye blade
Of Norfolke was þe Reve of whiche I telle
Besyde A Towne Men clepethe Baldiswelle
Tukkede he was As is A Fryer abowte
And euere he rode the hyndereste of ower Rowte
A somenour was þ̉er with vs in that place
That hadde A Smerede Cherubyns Face
For Sawcefflevme he was wᵗith eyene narrowe
All hote he was And lecherouse As a Sparowe
With Skallede browes blacke ⁊and pyllede berde
Of his vysage Childrone were Aferde
There nas qwycke Siluer litarge ne Brymston
Borace ceruce ne oyle of tartr none
Ne oynemente þat wolde Clanse ⁊and byghte
That hym myghte helpe of his whelkes whyte
Ne of the knobbes Syttenge on his Chekes
Welle louede he Garlyke oynons And lekes
And For to drynke Stronge wyn As rede as blode
Than wolde he speke And crye as he were wode
And whan þat he hadde welle drunken þe wyn
Than nolde he Speke no worde butte latyn
A Fewe termes hadde he ii othir thre
That he hadde lernede owte of Some degre
No wonder nys he hitt herde All þe daye
And eke ye knowe welle that A Iaye
Can clepe watte As welle as the pope
Butte whos couþe hym in other þynges grope
Than hadde he Spente All his phillosophye
A Questio quid Iuris þan wolde he crye
He was a gentulle harlatte And a kynde
A better Fellowe Schull Men notte Fynde
He wolde Suffere For A quarte of Wyn
A gode Fellowe to his Concubyne
A twelue Moneþe ⁊and excuse hym Atte þe Fulle
Fulle preuelye A Fynche eke couþe he pulle
And yefe he Fende Owhere A gode Fellowe
He wolde techene hym to haue none hawe
In Suche caase of the Archedecon Course
Butte yefe mannes Sowle were in his purse
For in his purse he Schulde yponnyschede be
Purse is the Archedecōns helle Sayde he
Butte welle I wote he lyede in dede
Of cursenge Aughte ylke Man drede
For Curse wolle Sle righte As asoylenge sauethe
And allso ware hym of A Signyficauit
In daunger hadde he Atte his owne gyse
The yonge Gurles of All his dyocise
And knewe her cownsayle And was of her rede
A garlande hadde he Sette vppon his hede
As grete as hitt were For An Ale Stake
A Bokeler hadde he made hym of A Cake
With hym þ̉er rode A gentulle pardoner
Of Rowncyuale his Frende And his compere
That strayghte was comenge Frome þe Courte of Rome
Fulle lowde he Sange come hyþer love to me
This Somenour bare to hym Affter Burdou
Was neủer Trumpe of halfe So gret Asowne
This pardoner hadde here As yellowe as waxe
Butte Smothe hitt henge As dothe a Stryke of Flaxe
By vncyse hynge his lokkes that he hadde
And þ̉erwith he his Schulders oủer Spradde
Butte thynne hitt laye by Culpounes one ⁊and one
Butte hode For Iolyte werede he none
For hitt was trussede vppe in his wallette
Hym þoughte he rode All of the newe engette
Vncoủerede Saufe his Cappe he rode All bare
Suche glarenge eyen hadde he As an hare
A vernycle hadde he Sewede vppon his Cappe
His wallette bifore hym in his lappe
Brytte Fulle of pardou come Fro Rome all hote
A voyce he hadde As Smale as A Gote
No berde hadde he ne neủer schulde haue
As Smothe hitt was As hitt / were newe schaue
I trowe he were A geldenge othir A Mare
Butte of his Craffte Frome Barwyke vnto ware
Ne was there Suche Anoþ̉ere pardoner
For in his Male he hadde A pillwbere
Whiche þat he sayde was ower ladye veyle
He Sayde he hadde A gobbette of þe Sayle
That Saynte Petir hadde whan he wente
Vppon the See tille Ihıı̄un Criste hym hente
He hadde A Crosse of lattou Fulle of Stones
And in A glasse he hadde pygges bones
Butte with thes Relickes whan þᵗat he Fonde
A poure parsou dwellenge vppon lande
Vppon A daye he gate hym more Moneye
Than þat the parsou gatte in Moneþes twey
And þus with Faynede Flaterynge ⁊and Iapes
He Made the parsou And the peple his Aprys
Butte truelye to tellen Atte the laste
He was in Chirche A noble Ecclesiastr
Welle couþe he rede A lessou othir A Storye
Butte alderbeste he sange An offretorye
For welle he wyste whan þat Songe was songe
He Muste prechen and welle affrayne his tonge
To wynne Siluer As he welle couþe
Therefor he Sange þe Meriorlye ⁊and lowde
¶ Now haue I tolde yow Soþelye in A Clawse
The estate the Araye the noumbir ⁊and eke the cause
Why that I Assemblede was with this Companye
In Sowthewerke Atte this gentille hostilrye
That hyghte the Tabbarde Faste by the belle
Butte now is tyme to you For to telle
How þat we beryne vs thylke nyghte
Whan þat we were in that Ostelrye Alyghte
And affter woll I telle of ower vyage
And all the remenawnte of ower pilgrymage
Butte Firste I praye you of your Curtasye
That ye ne Sette hitt notte My villanye
Thoughe þat I playnely Speke in this Matere
To telle you of her wordes And of her chere
Ne thoughe I speke notte her wordes proprelye
For this ye knowen As wele as I
Who schall telle A tale Affter A Man
He Muste reche As nyghe as eủer he can
Euerye a worde yefe hitt be in his charge
All speke he neủer So rudelye nor So large
Othir elles he Muste telle his tale vntrulye
Othir Fayne þynges oþ̉er Fynde wordes newe
He maye notte Spare All þough he was his brother
He Motte As wele Sayene one worde As Anoþ̉ere
Crist Spake hym selfe Fulle brode in holye wrytte
As wele ye wote no villanye nys hitt
Eke plato Sayethe who So can hym rede
The wordes Muste be Cosyne to the dede
Allso I praye you Foryeuethe hitt Me
All haue I noughte Sette Folke in her degree
Here in this tale As they Schullen stonde
My wytte is Schorte ye maye welle vnderstonde
¶ Grete chere Made ower Oste vs euerichone
And to the Souper sette he vs righte Anone
He Saruede vs with vittayle Atte the best
Straunge was the wyn And well drynke vs lyste
A Semelye Man ower Oste was with all
For to haue bene A Marchall in an halle
A large Man he was with eyen Stepe
A Fayerer burgeys nys none in Chepe
Bolde of his Speche wyse And well ytaughte
And of Manhode lackede he righte noughte
And eke þ̉erto was he righte Amery Man
And affter Souper playen he bigan
And Spake of Myrþe Amonge other þynges
Whan þat we hadde Made ower reckenenges
And Sayde thus now lordenges trulye
Ye bene to me wellcome righte hertelye
For by my trouthe yefe that I schall notte lye
I Sawe notte this yere So merye A companye
Atte ones in this herborowe As I do now
Fayne wolde I do you Mirthe And I wyste how
And of A Myrthe I am righte now bithoughte
To doone you ese ⁊and hitt schall coste you noughte
Ye goone to Camterbury god you Spede
The blysefulle Marter qwyte you your Mede
And wele ye wote As ye goone by the waye
Ye Schapen you to Iape And to playe
For trulye Comforte ne Myrthe nys none
To Ryde by þe waye As dowme as Stone
And þ̉erfore woll I make you disporte
As I Sayde erste And doone you Some comforte
And yefe ye lykeþe All by oone Assente
For to Standen Atte my Iugemente
And For to worken As I Schall you saye
To morne whan ye ryden by the waye
Now by my Fadurs Sowle þat is dede
Butte ye be Merye I woll yeuen you my hede
¶ Holden vppe your handes withouten more speche
Ower cownsayle was noughte longe For to seche
Vs þought hitt / was notte worþe to make hitt wyse
And guᵃntede hym withouten More Auyse
And badde hym Saye his vardytte As hym luste
Lordenges qd he now harkeneþe For the best
Butte takeþe hitt notte I praye you in disdaigne
This is the poynte to Speke schorte ⁊and playne
That ylke of you to Schorte with your waye
In this vyage Schall telle tales twey
To Caunterbury warde I Mene hitt so
And homewarde he Schall tellen othir two
Of Aventures þat whylome haue Falle
And whiche of you þat bereþe hym best of all
That is to Saye that tellethe in this caase
Tales of best Sentence And of moste Solaase
Schall haue a Souper Atte ower Alder coste
Here in this place Sittenge by this poste
Whan þat we comene home Frome Caunterbury
And For to Make you the more Merye
I woll my Selfe gladely with you ryde
Righte Atte myne owne Coste ⁊and be your gyde
And who þᵗat woll my Iugemente withsaye
Schall paye All þat is Spente by the waye
And yefe vouche saufe þat hitt So be
Telle me And withoute wordes Moo
And I woll erelye Schape me therfore
This þynge was guᵃntede And ower othes Swore
With Fulle gladde herte And pᵃyen hym allso
That he wolde vouchesaufe For to do so
And þat he wolde be ower goủernoure
And of ower tales Iuge ⁊and reportoure
And Sette A Souper atte A sartayne pryce
And we wollne ruelede be Atte thy deuyse
In hyghe ⁊and lowe And þus by oone Assente
We bene Acordede to thyne Iugemente
And þ̉eruppon the wyn was Fette Anon
We drunken And to Reste wente ylkeone
Withouten onye lenger taryenge
Amorne whan þᵗat daye gan to sprynge
Vppe Roste Rose ower Oste And was ower koke
And gaderede vs All in a Flocke
And Forþe we ryden A litulle more þan A paase
Vnto þe waterenge place of Saynte Thomas
And þ̉er ower Oste bigan his horse to Areste
And Sayde lordenges harkeneþe yefe you lyste
Ye wote your Forewarde And your recorde
Yefe Evne Songe And Morne Songe Acorde
Latte Se now how ho schall telle the Firste tale
As euer Motte I drynke wyn or Ale
Who So þat is Rebelle to my Iugemente
Schall paye For All that by the waye is Spente
Now draweþe Cutte Ar that ye Furþer twynne
The whiche þat haþe the Schorteste he schall bigyne
¶ Sir knyghte qd he my Mayster And my lorde
Now draweþe Cutte For þat is Myne Acorde
Comeþe nere qd he My ladye prioresse
And ye Sir Clarke lette be your Schamefastnesse
Ne Stondeþe notte leye hande þ̉erto euery Man
Anon to drawe eủery wyghte bigane
And Schortely For to telle As hitt was
Were hitt / by Aduenture oþ̉er sorte or caase
The seþe is this the Cutte Fylle to þe knyghte
Of whiche Fulle blyþe and glade was eủerye wyghte
And telle he Muste his tale As is Resoune
Bifore warde of his Composiciou
As ye haue herde whatt nedeþe wordes moo
And whan þis gode Man Sawe þᵗat hitt was So
As he þat wyse was And obediente
To kepe his Forewarde by his Free Assente
He Sayde Sythynnes I Schall bigyne þe game
Whatt well come be Cutte in goddes name
Now lette vs ryde And harken whatt I Saye
And with þat worde we rydde Forþe ower waye
And he bigane with righte Amerye chere
His Tale anon And Sayde as ye may here

div.l: (base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh

(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne

(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge

div.l: (base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town

div.l: (base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene

div.l: (base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large

Here endithe the tale of the knyght
And bygynnyth the ꝓprologe of the myller
Whan that þe knyghte hadde þus his tale tolde
In all þe companye ne was þ̉er yonge ne olde
That he ne sayde hitt was A noble storye
And worthye For to drawen vnto Memorye
And namelye the gentulles euerychone
Ower hoste loughe and swore as Motte I gone
This goethe aryghte vnbocklede is the Male
Lette se now ho schall telle Anothir Tale
For truelye this game is well bigonne
Now tellethe ye sir Monke yefe þat ye Con
Somewhatte to qwyte with the knyghtes tale
The Myller that Fordrunken was of Ale
So þat vnneþe vppon his horse he satte
He nolde Avalene neyther hoode ne hatte
Ne abyde no Man For his Curtasye
Butte in pylates voyce he gan to crye
And Swore by Armys blode ⁊and bony
I Cane a noble Tale for the nones
With whiche I woll now qwyte the knyghtes tale
Ower hoste saughe that he was drunke of Ale
And sayde abyde Robyn leue brothir
Some better Man schall telle vs Firste Anoþ̉er
Abyde and lette vs werke thryfftelye
By goddes sone cothe he þat woll notte I
For I woll speke or ellese go my waye
Ower hoste Answerede telle on Adevilwaye
Thou arte a Fole thy wytte is oủercome
Now harkeneþe cothe the Myller all ⁊and Some
Butte Firste I make a protestaciou
That I am drunke I knowe hitt by Sowne
And þ̉erfore yefe I Myse Speke or saye
Wyete hitt the Ale of Suþewerke I you praye
For I woll telle A legende ⁊and A lyfe
Boþe of A Carpynter ⁊and his wyfe
How that Clarke the wryghtes Cappe
The Reue answerede and sayde stynte thy clappe
Lette be thy lewde drunken harlatrye
Hitt is A synne ⁊and eke a grete Folye
To Apayren enye Man or hym defame
And eke to brynge wyues in Suche A name
Thou mayeste ynoughe of oþ̉er þynges Sayene
This drunken Myller spake Fulle Soone agayne
And sayde leue brothir Oswolde
Who that haþe no wyfe is no Cokolde
Butte I saye notte þ̉erfore þou Arte oone
There bene Fulle gode wyues Manye oone
Why arte þou Angryde with my Tale now
I haue a wyfe parde as welle as thou
Yette wolde I notte For the Oxen in my ploughe
Take vppon me More than ynough
As demene of my Selfe that I were oone
I woll bileve that I am none
An husbande schall notte be Inquesetyfe
Of goddes preuyte ne of his wyfe
So he maye Fynden goddes Foysou þere
Of the remenawnte nedeþe notte to enquere
Whatt schulde I more saye butte the Myller
He nolde his wordes For no Man Forbere
Butte tolde his Churles tale in his manere
Me Forþynkeþe þat I schall reherse hitt here
And þ̉erfore euery gentulle wyghte I praye
Demeþe notte For goddes loue þat I saye
Of euylle entente butte I motte reherse
Her tales all be they better or werse
Or ellese False some of my Matier
And þ̉erfore who so luste notte here
Turne oủer the lefe and chese anoþ̉er tale
For ye schulle Fynde ynow boþe grete ⁊and smale
Of historyall þynge that toucheþe gentullnesse
And eke Moralytee and holynesse
Blame notte Me yefe þat ye chese Amysse
The Myller is A Churle ye know well this
So was the Reue And eke othir Moo
And harlatrye they tolde bothe two
Auyse you and putte me owte of blame
And eke Men schall notte Make erneste of game

l.hi: And begynnyth the tale of the myller .

div.l: WHylome þ̉er was dwellenge in Oxenforde
A Ryche gnoffe that gestes helde to borde
And of his craffte he was a Carpynter
With hym þ̉er was dwellenge a poure Scolere
Hadde lernede Art butt all his Fantasye
Was turnede to lerne Astrologye
And cowde A Sartayne of Conclusioıı̄uns To demene by
To demene by Interogacions
Yefe þat Men Axede hym in sartayne howres
Whan þat Men schulde haue droughte or schowres
Or yefe Men Axede hym whatt schulde byfalle
Of euerye þynge I maye notte recken all
This Clarke was clepede hende Nycholas
Of derne loue he cowde ⁊and preuye solas
And yette he was sleyghte ⁊and Fulle puye
And lyke to a Mayde meke For to se
A chambre hadde he in that hostelrye
Aloone withouten enye Companye
Fulle Fetelye dyghte with herbes swote
And he hym selfe as soote as is the roote
Of lycoryce or of enye sytuale
His Almagist ⁊and bokes grete and smale
His Asterlabe longenge for his Art
His Awgrym stones layenge Fulle fayer Aparte
On schelues couchede Atte his beddes hede
His presse ycoủerede with a Foldenge rede
And all Aboue þ̉er laye a Gaye Sawtrye
On whiche he made on nyghte Mellodye
So swetelye þat all the chambre ronge
And Angelus ad virginem he sange
And after that he sange the kynges note
Fulle offte blessede was his merye þrote
And þus this swete Clarke his tyme spente
Affter his Frendes Fyndenge ⁊and his Rente
This Carpynter hadde weddede newe a wyfe
Whiche that he louede more þan his lyfe
Of xviij yere sche was of Age
Ielowse he was and kepte her strayte in Cage
For Sche was wylde ⁊and yonge and he was olde
And demede hym selfe to be lyke a Cokolde
He knewe notte Catton For his wytte was rude
That badde Men schulde wedde her simylitud
Men schulde wedde Affter her estate
For youthe ⁊and Age is offte atte debate
Butte syþe he was Fallen in the snare
He motte enduren as oþ̉er Folke his Care
Fayer was this yonge wyfe ⁊and þ̉er with all
As enye vesselle her bodye gente ⁊and smale
A saynte sche werede barrede all of sylke
A barme cloþe as whyte As Morne mylke
Vppou her lendes Fulle of Manye Agore
Whyte was her Smocke ⁊and enbrowdered all afore
And eke bihynde on her coller abowte
Of cole blacke sylke withyn ⁊and eke withoute
The tapes of her whyte volipere
Were of the same sute of her collere
Her Fyllette brode of sylke ⁊and sette fulle heyghe
And sikerlye sche hadde a lycorouse eye
Fulle smale ypullede were her browes two
And tho were bente and blacke as enye slo
Sche was Fulle more blysefulle For to se
Than is the newe ꝑperiente Tree
And soffter þan the wolle is of A wether
And by her girdulle hynge A purse of ledder
Tassede with sylke and perlede with lattou
In all this worlde to seke vppe and downe
Ner þ̉er is no Man so wyse that couþe thynche
So gaye a puppelote or A wenche
Fulle bryghte was the schynenge of her hwe
That in the towre the noble Forgede newe
Butte of her sange hitt was As lowde ⁊and iȝerne
As enye swallowe syttenge on A Berne
Therto sche couþe skyppe And make a game
As enye kydde or Calfe Followenge his dame
Her Mouþe was swete As bragotte or Methe
Or horde of Appulles leyde in haye or heth
Wynsenge sche was as is a Iolye Colte
Longe As a Maste ⁊and vppwarde As a bolte
A broche sche bare on her lowe Collere
As brode as is the Bose of A buckeler
Her schooes were lasede on her legges hyghe
Sche was A prymmerolle A pyggesnye
For enye lorde to lyggene in his bedde
Or yette For enye yeman to wedde
Now sir and effte sir ⁊and so bifelle the caase
That uppou A daye this hende Nicholas
Felle with this yonge wyfe for to playe
Whyle that her husbande was atte Osenaye
As Clarkes bene Fulle subtyle ⁊and fulle qwaynte
And preuelye he caughte her by the qwaynte
And sayde ywysse butte I haue my wylle
For derne loue of þe lemman I spylle
And helde her Faste by haunche bones
And sayde lemman welde Atte ones
Or I woll deye so god me saue
And sche sprange as A Colte in Traue
And with her hede sche wryede Faste awey
Sche sayde I wolle notte kysse the by my Faye
Why labbe qd ycche late be Nicholas
Or I woll crye owte harrowe and Alas
Doowaye your handes For your Curtesye
This Nicholas gan mercy For to crye
And spake so Fayer ⁊and proferde hym Fulle Faste
That sche her loue guᵃntede hym atte þe laste
And swore her othe by saynte Thomas of kente
That sche wolde bene Atte his Comawndemente
Whan that sche maye her leysor welle Aspye
Myne husbande is so Fulle of Ielowsye
That butte ye wayte well ⁊and be preuye
I wote righte wele I am butte dede quod sche
Ye motte be Fulle derne as in this case
Naye þ̉erofe care ye noughte quod Nicholas
A Clarke hadde lytherlye bysette his wylle
Butte yefe he couþe A Carpynter begyle
And þus accordede and sworne
To wayte a tyme as I haue sayde biforne
Whan Nicholas hadde doone þus euerye dele
And thackede her abowte the lendes welle
He kysseþe her swete and takeþe his sawtrye
And playethe Faste and makeþe Mellodye
Than Felle hitt þus that to the parrysche chirche
Cristes owne werkes to werche
This gode wyfe wente vppou an halydaye
Her Forhede schone As brighte as enye daye
So was hitt wasche whan sche lete her werke
Now was ther þ̉er of the chirche A parrysche Clarke
The whiche was clepede Absolou
Crullede was his hede As the golde hitt schone
And stroutede As a Fanne large ⁊and brode
Fulle strayghte ⁊and euene laye his Iolye shode
His rose was rede his eyen graye as Goose
With powles wyndowes Coruen in his schooes
In hosen rede he wente Fulle Fetislye
Y cladde he was Full smale ⁊and proprelye
All in a kyrtulle of lyghte wagette
Fulle Fayer ⁊and thicke bene the poyntes sette
And þ̉eruppou he hadde A gaye Surplyce
As whyte as is the blossome on Rys
A merye chylde he was so god me saue
Welle couþe he lette blode Clyppe ⁊and schaue
And make a Chartre of lande ⁊and or Aqwytawnce
In xxᵗⁱ Manere couþe he tryppe ⁊and dawnce
Affter the Scoole of Oxenford th
And with his legges Casten to ⁊and Fro
And playen songes on A smale rybybe
Sometyme he sange A lowde quynyble
And as well couþe he playe on gyterye
In all the towne was þ̉er brewhouse ne Tauerne
That he ne vysytte with his solas
There enye gallante Tapsterre was
Butte sothe to sayne he was somedele sqwaymous
Of Fartenge and of speche daungerouse
This Absolou that was Iolye and gaye
Gothe with the senser on the sonedaye
Sensenge the wyues of the parrysche Faste
And manye a louelye loke on hem he caste
And namelye on the Carpynters wyfe
To loke on her hym þoughte A merye lyfe
Sche was so propre swete ⁊and licoruse
I dare well saye and sche hadde bene a Mouse
And he a Catte he wolde her hunte Anōne
This parrische Clarke this Iolye Absolou
Haþe in his herte suche aloue longenge
That of no wyfe toke he no offerenge
For Curtasye he sayde he wolde noone
The Moone whan hitt was nyghte brighte ⁊and schone
And Absolou his gytirne haþe ytake
For ꝑparamoures he þoughte For to wake
And Forþe gothe Ielowse ⁊and Amorowse
Tylle he came to the Carpynters howse
A lytulle affter the Cocke hadde ycrowe
And dressede hym vnder A schytte wyndowe
That was vppou the Carpynters walle
He syngeþe in his voyce gentulle ⁊and smale
Now dere ladye yefe thy wylle be
I praye you that ye wolle Rwe on m
Fulle welle acordenge to his giternenge
This Carpynter Awoke ⁊and harde hym synge
And spake vnto his wyfe ⁊and sayde Anōne
Whatt Alysou hereste thou notte Absolou
That chaunteþe þus vnder ower Bowres walle
And sche answerede her husbande þ̉erwithall
Yesse god wotte Iohn I here hitt eủerydele
This passeþe Forþe wylle ye than butte wele
Frome daye to daye this Iolye Absolou
So woweþe her that hym was wo bygone
He wakeþe all the nyghte and all the daye
He kembede his lockes brode and made hem gaye
He woweþe her by Menes and brocage
And swore he wolde bene her owne page
He syngeþe brockenge as A Nyghtengale
He sente her pymente Methe ⁊and spycede Ale
And wafres pypenge hote owte of the glede
And For sche of the Towne he proffrede Mede
For some Folke woll bye wymmen For rycchesse
And some For strokes ⁊and some For gentullnesse
Sōmme tyme to schewe his lyghtnesse ⁊and Maystrye
He playeþe herawdes vppou A Scaffolde heyghe
Butte whatt Auayleþe hym As in this caase
So louethe sche this hende Nicholas
That Absolou maye playe the bucke horne
He ne hadde For his laboure butte A skorne
And þus sche makeþe Absolou her Maake
All his erneste turneþe butte to a Iape
Forsoþe this prouerbe hitt is no lye
Men sayen þat allwaye þe nyghe slye
Makeþe the Feer loue to be lothe
For þoughe that Absolou be woode or wroth
Bicause þat he Ferre was Frome her syghte
This nyghe Nicholas stode in his lyghte
Now bere þe wele hende Nicholas
For Absolou maye wayle ⁊and synge Alas
And so bifelle hitt on A saturdaye
This Carpynter was gone to Osnaye
And hende Nicholas And alysou
Acordede were to this Conclusiou
That Nicholas schall schapen hym A whyle
This selye Iellowse husbande to begyle
And yefe so be that þe game wente Aryghte
Sche schulde slepe in his Armes all nyghte
For this was his desyre ⁊and hyr Allso
And righte anone withouten wordes Mo
This Nicholas no lenger wolde tarye
Butte doþe Fulle soffte vnto his chambre carye
Boþe Mete ⁊and drynke For A daye or twaye
And to her husbande badde her For to saye
Yefe that he askede affter Nicholas
Sche schulde saye sche nyste where sche he was
Of all þat daye sche sawe hym notte with eye
Sche trowede that he was in Malladye
For no crye her Mayde couþe calle
He nolde answere For noughte þat myghte bifalle
This passeþe Forþe all the saturdaye
That Nicholas stylle in his bedde laye
And eete ⁊and slepe And whatte hym luste
Tylle sonedaye þat the sonne goþe to reste
This selye Carpynter haþe grete Marvayle
Of Nicholas or whatte þynge myghte hym Ayle
And sayde I am adradde by saynte Thomas
Hitt stondeþe notte arighte with Nicholas
God Schylde þat he deyede sodaynelye
This worlde is now butte tykulle sykurlye
I saughe to daye a Course bore to chyrche
That now on Monedaye laste I saughe hym worche
Go vppe qd he to his knaue Anōne
Clepe atte his durre or knocke with a stone
Loke how itt is And me boldelye
This knaue wente hym Fulle sturdelye
And atte the chambre durre whyle þat he stode
He cryede ⁊and knockede as þoughe he were wode
Whatt how whatt do ye Mayster Nicholaye
How maye ye slepe All þis longe daye
Butte all for noughte he harde neu A worde
A borde he Fonde lowe vnder a bedde
There As the Catte was wonte For to crepe
And atte þe hole he lokede in Fulle depe
And atte the laste he hadde of hym a syghte
This Nicholas sate eu gapenge vprighte
As he hadde lokede on the newe Moone
Adowne he gothe and tolde his Maystre soone
In whatt Araye he sawe this ylke Man
This Carpynter to blyssene hym biganne
And sayde helpe vs saynte Frydeswyde
A Man wotte lytulle whatt schall hym betyde
This Man is Fallen with his Astronomye
In some wodenesse or in some Agonye
I thoughte well how hitt schulde be
Men schulde notte knowe of goddes preuyte
Yett blessede allwaye be þe lewde Man
That notte butte oonelye his byleue can
So Ferde Anoþ̉er Clarke with Astronomye
He walkede into the Feldes For to praye prye
Vppou the starres to wytte whatt schulde bifalle
Tylle he was in A Marle pytte yfalle
He sawe notte butte yett by saynte Thoma
Me ruethe sore hende Nicholas
He schall be ratyde of his studyenge
Yefe þat I maye by Ihus heuene kynge
Gette me A staffe þat I maye vndersporre
Whyle that þow Roben heueste vppe þe durre
He schall owte of his studyenge as I gesse
And to þe chambre durre he gan hym dresse
His knaue was a stronge Carle For þe nones
And by þe haspe he hofe hitt atte ones
Into the Flore þe durre Fylle Anōne
This Nicholas satte ay As stylle as stone
And eủer gapede vppwarde into þe Ayer
This Carpynter wende he were in dispayre
And hente hym by þe schulders Myghtelye
And schoke hym harde ⁊and cryede spiteouslye
Whatt Nicholay whatt loke Adowne
Awake and thynke on Cristes passyoun
I Crouche the Frome Elues ⁊and Frome wycches
There with the myghte spelle sayde anon ryghtes
On Fower halues of the howses Abowte
And on the þrasscholde on the durre withoute
Ihu Criste And saynte Benedicte
Blysse þe howse Frome euery wyckede wyghte
For the nyghtes werye the with pater nr
Where whentestow þou saynte petirs suster
And atte the laste this hende Nicholas
Gan For to sore syghe ⁊and sayde Alas
Schall all the worlde be loste efftesones now
This Carpynter Answerede whatt sayest thou
Whatt thynke on god as we haue doone Men þat swynke
This Nicholas Answerede Fecche me drynke
And affter woll I speke in preuytee
Of sartayne thynge þat toucheþe the ⁊and m
I woll telle itt none othir Man sartayne
This Carpynter goeþe downe ⁊and comeþe agayne
And broughte of myghty Ale a large quarte
And whan þat eche of hem hadde drunken his parte
This Nicholas his durre Faste schete
And downe þe Carpynter by hym he sete
And sayde Iohn myne hoste lefe ⁊and dere
Thou schalte vppou thy trouþe swere me here
That to no wyghte þou schalte this cownsayle wraye
For itt is Cristes cownsayle þat I saye
And yefe þou telle itt Man þou Arte Forlore
For this vengeaunce þou schalte haue þ̉erfore
That yefe thou wraye me þou schalte be woode
Naye Crist forbede hitt For his holye blode
Quod tho þis selye Man I am no blabbe
Ne þoughe I saye I am notte leefe to gabbe
For whatt þou wylte saye I schall hitt neủer telle
To wyfe ne chylde by hym þat harrowede helle
Now Iohn qd Nicholas I wyll notte lye
I haue yfounden in myne Astrologye
As I haue lokede in the Moone brighte
That now on Monedaye nexte A qᵃrter nyghte
Schall Falle A Rayne ⁊and þat so wylde ⁊and wode
That halfe so grete was neủer Noyes Flode
This worlde he sayde in lesse þan in An howre
Schall all be draynte so hydouse is the schowre
This schall Mankynde drenche ⁊and lese her lyfe
This Carpynter answerede Alas my wyfe
And schall sche drenche Alas myne Alysou
For sorrowe of this he Felle Allmoste downe
And sayde is no Remedye in this caase
Whye yes Forgod quod hende Nichola
Yefe þou wolte worchen Affter lore ⁊and rede
Thou mayeste notte worken affter þyne owne hede
For þus sayethe Sallamon þat was Fulle true
Werke all by cownsayle ⁊and þou schalte notte rue
And yefe þou worken wolte by gode Cownsayle
I vndertake withouten Maste or sayle
Yette schall I saue her the And Me
Haste þou noughte herde how sauede was Nooe
Whan þat ower lorde haþe warnede hym biforne
That all the worlde with watre schulde be lorne
Yes quod this Carpynter Fulle ȝore Agoo
Haste þou noughte harde qd Nicholas allso
The sorowe of Nooe with his Fellyschepe
Er þat he myghte gette his wyfe to schyppe
Hym hadde leuer I dare well vndertake
Atte þylke tyme þan all his wethers blake
That sche hadde A schyppe her selfe Aloone
And therefor woste thou whatt is beste to doone
This Axeþe haste and of An hastye þynge
Men maye noughte preche ne make tarryenge
Anōne go gette vs Faste into this ynne
A knedenge Troughe or ellese A kymelyne
For eche of vs butt loke þat they be large
In whiche Men mowen swyme As in a barge
And hauen þayre vytaylles suffisaunte
Butte For A daye Fye on the Remenaunte
The watre schall Aslake ⁊and gone aweye
Abowte pryme vppou the nexte daye
Butte Robyn Maye notte wytte of this thy knaue
Ne eke thy Mayde Gylle I maye noughte saue
Aske notte whye For þoughe þou Aske me
I wylle notte tellen goddes preuyte
Suffiseþe the butte yefe thy wyttes Madde
To haue As grete A grace As Nooe hadde
Thy wyfe schall I well sauene owte of dowte
Go now thy waye and spede the here abowte
Butte whan þou haste For her the ⁊and me
Ygottene vs the knedenge Tubbes thre
Than schalte þou hange hem in þe Roofe Fulle heyghe
That no Man of ower purueawnce Aspye
And whan þou haste þus doone As I haue sayde
And haste ower vytaylle Fayer in hem ylayde
And eke an Axe to smyte þe Corde Atwo
Whan þat comeþe that we maye goo
And broke ⁊and hole on heyghe vppou the gable
Vnto þe gardeynwarde oủer the stable
That we maye Frelye passen Forþe ower waye
Whan þat the grete schowre is gooene Awaye
Than schalte þou swyme as Merye I vndertake
As doþe the whyte docke Affter the drake
Than wolle I Clepe how Alysou how Iohn
Be merye For þe Flode wolle passe Anone
And þou wolte sayene hayle Mayster Nicholaye
Gode Morrowen I se the well For hitt is daye
And þan schall we be lordes all ower lyfe
Of all the worlde as Nooe ⁊and his wyfe
Butte þat of o thynge I warne þe Fulle righte
Be welle Auysede on þat ylke nyghte
That we bene entrede into the schippes borde
That noone of vs speke noughte A worde
Ne clepe ne crye butte bene in his prayer
For hitt is goddes owne heste dere
Thy wyfe ⁊and þou Motte hange Ferre Atwynne
For þat bitwyxe you schall be no synne
No more in lokenge þan there schall in dede
This ordynawnce is sayde so god me spede
To Morne Atte nyghte whan Men bene all Aslep
Into ower knedenge Tubbes woll we Crepe
And sytten there abydenge goddes grace
Go now thy waye I haue no lenger space
To make of þis no lenger sarmonenge
Men sayen þus sende the wyse ⁊and saye no þynge
Thou Arte so wyse hitt nedeþe the notte to teche
Go saue ower lyfe and þat I the beseche
This selfe Carpynter gothe Forþe his waye
Fulle offte he sayde Alas ⁊and wayle awaye
And to his wyfe he tolde his preuytee

Yette was he blente and god wotte so be Mo
That wenene wyselye þat hitt is noughte so
Passe oủer is an Ese and saye no more
This Fresche Maye of whiche I spake of so ȝore
In warme waxe haþe enpntede the Clykette
That Ianuar bare of þat smale wykkette
By whiche vnto his gardeyne offte he wente
And damyan þat knewe his entente
The Clekette counterfettede preuelye
There nys no More to saye butte hastely
Some wonder by his Clykette schal betyde
Whiche ye schullne here of yefe ye wol abyde
O noble Ouyde sothe sayeste þou god wotte
Whatte sleyghte is hitt þoughe hitt be longe ⁊and hote
That he nyle Fynde hitt owte in some Manere
By pyramus and Thysbe Maye Men lere
Theyghe þeye were kepte Fule longe strayte oủeral
Theye bene acordede Rownenge þroughe a wale
There no wyhte couþe a Founde owte suche a sleyghte
Butte now to purpose er þat dayes viijᵉ
Werne passede of þe Moneþe of Iuyle byfele
That Ianuar haþe caughte so grete a wyle
Throughe eggenge of his wyfe hym For to playe
In his gardeyne and no wyhte butte þeye tweye
That in a Morrowe vnto his Maye sayde he
Ryse vppe My wyfe My loue My ladye Fre
The turtyls voyce is harde My dowfe swete
The wynter is gone with al his Raynes wete
Come Forþe now with thyne eyen Columbyne
How Fayerer bene thy brestes þan Is wyn
The gardeyne is enclosede alabowte
Come Forþe My whyte spowse owte of dowte
Thou haste me woundede in Myne herte O wyfe
No spotte in the nas in al thy lyfe
Come Forþe and lette vs take ower disporte
I chese the For my wyfe and My Comforte
Suche olde lowde wordes vsede he
On damyan a sygne Madeshe / /
That he schulde gone byforne with his Clykette
This Damyan hathe openyde the wyckette
And in he sterte and þat in suche a Manere
That no wyȝte Myghte hitt se ne here
And style he sytte vnder a Bussche anone
This Ianuar as blynde as is a stone
With Mayus in his hande and no wyȝte Mo
Into his Fresche gardeyne is he go And Clapte to
And Clapte to þe wyckette sodaynlye
Now wyfe qd he here nys butte þou and I
Thou arte the creature þat I beste loue
For by þat lorde that syttethe aboue
I hadde leuere deyen on a knyfe
Than the offendene true wyfe
For goddes sake thynke how I the cheese
Noughte For no couetyse dowtlese
Butte onelye For þe loue I hadde to the
And þoughe þat I be olde ⁊and maye notte se
Be to me true and I wol tele you why
Sertes iij thynges schule ye wynne þ̉erbye
Firste loue of Crist and to your selfe heuene honoure
And al Myne herytage Towne ⁊and Towre
I yeue hitt you Makeþe Chres as you luste
This schal be done to Morowe ar sonnes ryste
So wyselye god brynge my sowle to blysse
And praye I you on Couenᵃunte þat ye me kysse
And þoughe þat I be Ielowse wyete me noughte
Ye bene so depe enprentede in my thoughte
That whan þat I concidre your Bewte
And þ̉erwith al the vnlyckelye elde of me
I Maye noughte certes þoughe I schulde deye
Forbere to bene owte of your Companye
For verreye loue þis is withouten dowte
Now kysse me wyfe and lette vs Rome abowte
This Fresche Maye whan sche þese wordes harde
Benyngelye to Ianuar aunswerede
Butte Firste ⁊and Forewarde sche bigānne For to wepe
I haue qd sche a sowle For to kepe
Aswele as ye and allso Myne honoure
And of my wyfehode thycke tendre Flowre
With that I haue assurede in your hande
Wherefor I wol aunswere in þis Manere
With þe leue of you My lorde so dere
I praye god þat neủer dawe that daye
That I ne starue as Fowle as woman Maye
Yefe eủer I do vnto My kynne þat schame
Oþ̉ere ellese I empeyre so my name
That I be False and yefe I do þat lacke
To strype me and putte me in a sacke
And in þe nexte ryvere do me drenche
I am a gentule woman and no wenche
Why speke ye þus butte eủer Men vntrue
And wymmen haue reprefe of you ay newe
Ye cane none oþ̉ere cowntynawnce I leue
Butte to speke to vs as vntruste ⁊and in reproue
And with þat worde sche sawe where damyan
Sate in þe bussche and Coughe he begane
And with her Fyngur signes Made sche
That damyan schulde Clymben vppon a tree
That chargede was with Fruyte and vppe he wente
For verrelye he knewe al her entente
And euerye sygne þat sche couþe make
Wele better þan Ianuar his owne Make
For in a lre sche hadde tolde hym al
Of this Matere how he worchen schal
And þus I lette hym sytte in the pyrrye
And Ianuar and Mayus Rownynge Fule Merye
Brighte was the daye and blewe the Firmamente
Phebus of golde downe haþe his stremes sente
To gladene euerye Flowre with his warmenesse
He was þat tyme in Gemynys as I gesse
Butte lytule Frome his declynacioun
Of Cancer Iouis Exaltacioun
And so befele that brighte Morowe tyde
That in the gardeyne on þat Furþ̉ere syde
Pluto that is the kynge of Fayerye
And Manye a ladye in his Companye
Followenge his wyfe the qweene proserpyna
Whiche þat he rauysschede owte of ꝓproserpyna
Whyles þat sche gaderede Flowres in a Mede
In Clawdyan ye maye the storyes rede
How in his Gryselye Carte he her Fette
This kynge of Fayerye downe hym sette
Vppon a benche of Turues Fresche ⁊and grene
And righte anone sayde he þus to his qweene
My wyfe qd he þat Maye no wyȝte saye naye
The Exꝑperience proueþe hitt euerye daye
The tresoun whiche þᵗat woman dothe to Man
Tenne hunderde Thousande tellen I cane
Notable of your vntrouþe and bryttulnesse
O Salamon ryccheste of al rycchesse
Fulfilede of Sapience and of worldelye glorye
Fule worthye bene thy wordes to Memorye
To euerye wyȝte þat wytte and resoun cane
Thus praysethe he yette the bownte of Man
Amonge a thousande Men yette Fonde I one
Butte of al women yette Fonde I neủer none
Thus sayethe þis kynge that knoweþe your wyckednesse
And Ihc filius Cyrak as I gesse
Ne spekeþe of you butte selden reủerence
A wylde Fyere a Corrumpte Pestylence
So Fale vppon your bodyes yette to nyghte
Ne se ye noughte þis honourable knyghte
Bycause alas þat he is blynde ⁊and olde
His owne Man schal make hym kokolde
Lo where he sytte the lechoure in the tre
Now wol I grᵃunten of Myne Mageste
Vnto þis olde blynde worthy knyghte
That he schal haue agayne his eyen syghte
Whan þat his wyfe wolde done hym vylenye
Than schal he knowe al her harlottrye
Bothe in reprefe of her and oþ̉ere Mo
Ye schal qd ꝓproserpyn and wol ye so
Now by my Moders syres sowle I swere
That I schal yeuen her suffysaunte aunswere
And al women affter For your sake
That þoughe they be in onye gylte ytake
With Face bolde they schulne hem selfe excuse
And bere hem downe þat wolde hem accuse
For lacke of aunswere none of hem schul deye
And hadde ye seyen a þynge with boþe your eyen
Yette schulne we hitt so vysage hardelye
And wepe ⁊and swere ⁊and Chyde subtyllye
That ye schulne be as lewde as her geese
Whatte reckethe Me of your auctorytees
I wotte wel this Iwe this Salamon
Fande of vs women Folyes Manye one
Butte þoughe þat he ne Fonde no gode woman
There haþe I Founde Manye anoþ̉ere Man
Wymmen Fule true Fule gode ⁊and vertuouse
Wyttenesse on hem þat dwellen in Cristes howse
With Marterdome þese prouyde her Constance
The romayne gestes Maken remembrᵃunce
Of Manye a verreye true wyfe allso
Butte sir ne be notte wroþe as be hitt so
Thoughe þat he sayde he Fonde no gode woman
I praye you take the sentence of the Man
He Mente þus þat in souerayne bounte
Nys none butte god butte neyþ̉ere he ne sche
Eye For verrey god þat nyse nys butte oone
Whatte make ye so moche of Salamon
Whatte þoughe he Made a temple goddes howse
Whatte þoughe he were ryche ⁊and gloryous
So Made he eke a temple of False goddes
Who myghte do a þynge þat More Forbode is
Parde as Fayer as ye his name enplaystre
He was a lecchoure ⁊and an ydolastre
And in his elde he verrey god Forsoke
And yefe þat god Made as sayethe the boke
Ysparede hym For his Faders sake he schulde
Haue loste his Reygne souner þan he wolde
I sette noughte of al that vyllanye
That ye of wommen wryte a butterflye
I am a woman nedes Motte I speke
Oþ̉ere ellese swele tyle my herte breke
For seþens he sayde þat we bene Iangelers
As eủer Motte I broke boþe my tresse
I schal notte spare For no Curtasye
To speke hym harme þat wolde vs vyllanye
Dame qd this pluto be no lenger wroþe
I yeuen hitt vppe butte syþens I swere myne othe
That I wolde grᵃunten hym his syghte agayne
My worde schal stonde þat warne I the sartayne
I am a kynge hitt sytte me notte to lye
And I qd sche a qweene of Fayerye
Her aunswere sche schal haue I vndertake
Lette vs no Mo wordes Make
Forsoþe I wol no lenger you contrᵃye
Now lette vs turne agayne to Ianuarye
That in þis gardeyne with þis Fayer Maye
Syngeþe Fule Meryer than the popengaye
You loue I beste and schal ⁊and other none
So longe abowte the alyes he is gone
Tylle he was cone comen agayne þylke pyrrye
Where as þis damyan sytteþe Fulle Merye
On heyȝe amonge the Fresche leues grene
This Fresche Maye þat is so brighte ⁊and schene
Gan For to syghe and sayde alas My syde
Now sir qd sche For oughte þat maye betyde
I Muste haue of þese peres þat I see
Or I Muste deye so sore longethe Me
To eten of the smale peres grene
Helpe For her loue þat is of heuene qweene
I tele you wele a woman in my plyghte
Maye haue to Fruyte so grete an appetyte
That sche maye deyen butte sche hitt haue
Alas qd he þat I ne hadde here a knaue
That coþ couþe clymbe allas allas qd he
For I am blynde ȝe sir no Force qd sche
Butte he wolde vouchesaufe For goddes sake
The pyrrye bytwene your armes For to take
For wele I wotte þat ye Mystruste Me
Ellese schulde I clymbe wele ynoughe qd sche
So I my Foote Myghte sette vppon your backe
Forsoþe sayde he in Me schal be no lacke
Mighte I you helpe with My herte blode
Sche stoupeþe downe ⁊and on his backe sche stode
And caughte her by a twyste and vppe sche gothe
Ladyes I praye you þat ye be notte wrothe
I can notte glose I am a rude Man
And sodeynlye anone this Damyan
Gane pule vppe the smocke ⁊and in he þrange
And whan þat pluto sawe þis grete wronge
To Ianuar anone he yaue sis syghte
That he þan righte wele se myghte
And whan þat he hadde caughte his syghte agayne
Ne was þ̉er neuer Man of þynge so Fayne
Butte on his wyfe his þoughte was eủermo
Vppe to the tre he caste his eyen two
And sawe how damyan his wyfe hadde dressede
In whiche Manere hitt maye be expressede
Butte yefe I wolde speke vncurteyslye
And vppe he yafe a rorenge ⁊and a crye
As doþe the Moder whan the chylde schal deye
Owte helpe allas harrowe gane he crye
O stronge ladye stowre whatte doeste thou
And sche aunswerethe sir whatte eylethe you
Haue pacyence and resoun in your Mynde
I haue you holpen on boþe your eyen blynde
Vppe ꝑperele of My sowle I schale notte lyen
As Me was taughte to hele with your eyen
Was no þynge better For to make you se
Than strugle with a Man vppon a Tree
God wotte I dydde itte in Fule gode entente
Strogle qd he allgate in hitt wente
God yeue you boþe on schames deþe to deyen
He swyued the I sawe hitt with myne eyen
And elles be I hangede by the halse
Than is qd sche the Medecyne False
For sertaynelye yefe þat ye maye see
Ye wolde notte seye tho wordes vnto me
Ye haue some glemerenge ⁊and no ꝑparfyte syghte
I se qd he aswele as eủer I Myghte
Thanked be god with boþe Myne eyen two
And by my trouþe Me þoughte he dydde the so
Ȝea Maase Mase gode sir quod sche
This þanke haue I For I haue Made you se
Allas qd sche þat eủer I was kynde
Now dame qd he lette al passe owte of Mynde
Come downe My leefe and yefe I haue Myssarede
God helpe me so as I am euyle apayede
Butte by My Faders sowle I wende I haue sayne
How þat this Damyan hadde by the layne
And þat that thy smocke hadde leyne vppon thy breste
Ȝea sir qd sche ye maye wene as ye lyste
Butte sir a Man þat wakeþe owte of his slepe
He maye sodaynlye wel take kepe
Vppon a þynge ne seene hitt ꝑparfyttelye
Tyle þat he be adawede verrelye
Righte so a Man þat long9 haþe blynde ybe
Ne maye notte sodaynlye so wele I se
Firste whan þe sighte is newe come agayne
As he that haþe a daye or two ysayne
Tyle þat your syghte ystablede be awhyle
There Maye Fule manye a syghte you begyle
Beþe ware I praye you For by heuene kynge
Fule manye a Man weneþe to se a þynge
And yette hitt is al anoþ̉ere þan hitt semeþe
He þat Mysse consayuethe Mysse demeþe
And with þat worde sche lepe downe of the tree
This Ianuarie who is gladde butte he
He kysseþe her and clyppeþe her Fulle offte
And on her wombe he strokeþe her Fule soffte
And to his palleyce home he haþe her ladde
Now gode Men I praye you to be gladde
Thus endeþe here My tale of Ianuarie
God blysse vs and his Moder Saynte Marye Amen

l.hi: Here endithe the tale of the Marchaunt

div.l: And begynnyth þe prolog / of the wyf of bathe
Exꝑperimente þoughe none Auctoryte
Were in þis worlde righte ynoughe For me
To speke of woo þat is in maryage
For lordenges sythen I twelue yere was of Age
Thankede be god þat is eterne Alyu
Husbandes atte chirche durre haue I hadde Fyve
Yefe I so offte myghte haue weddede be
Butte al were worthy men in her degre
Butte me was tolde sertayne notte longe Agones
That Cryste wente neủer butte ones
To weddenge in the Cane of Galyle
That by the ylke ensample taughte he Me
That I ne weddede schulde be butte ones
Harken loo whiche A scharpe worde For the nones
Besyde A wele Ihu God ⁊and Man
Spake in reprefe to the samarytan
Thou haste y hadde Fyve husbandes qd he
And þat ylke Man þat now haþe the
Is notte thyne husbande þus sayde he sartayne
Whatte he Mente þ̉erbye I can notte sayne
Wele butte I Aske why the Fyfte Man
Was none husbande to the samarytan
How Manye myghte sche haue in Maryage
Yette harde I neủer tellen of Myne Age
Vppon this nombre diffiniciou
Men maye devyne And glose vppe ⁊and downe
Butte wele I wotte expsse withouten lye
God badde vs For to waxe ⁊and to Mltiplye
That gentule texte can I wel vnderstonde
Eke wele I wotte he sayde Myne husbande
Schulde lette Fadre and Moder and take to Me
Butte of none nombre Mencyou made he
Of Bigamye or of Octogomye
Why schulde Men þan of hitt haue vylanye
Looke here the wyse Man salamon
I trowe he hadde wyues Moo þan oone
Now wolde god itt lefule were to M
To be refresschede halfe so offte As he
Whiche yeffte of god hadde he For al his wyues
No man haþe suche þat in þis worlde Alyue is
God wotte þis noble kynge As to My wytte
The Firste nyghte hadde Manye A merye Fytte
With eche of hem so wele was hym Alyue
Blessede be god þat I haue weddede Fyue
Of whiche I haue pykede owte the beste
Boþe of her neþ̉ere purse And of her cheste
Diuerse scoles Makeþe diuerse Clarkes
And diuerse pracktyk in Manye Asondrye werkes
Makethe the parfytte Man sykurlye
Of Fyue husbandes scolenge Am I
Welcome þe sexte whan þat eủer he schal
For sythe I wol notte kepe chaste in al
Whan my husbande is Frome þe worlde gone
Some Crysten Man schal wedde Me Anone
For þan the Apostle sayeþe that I Am Free
To wedde A goddes halfe where hitt lykeþe Me
He sayeþe that to be weddede is no synne
Better is to be weddede þan to brenne
Whatte reckeþe Me þoughe Men saye villonye
Of schrewde lamethe And his Bigamye
I wotte wele Abrahᵃm was An holye Man
And Iacob eke as Ferre As I tele can
And eche of hem hadde wyues Mo þan too
And Manye Anoþ̉ere holye Man also
Where can ye saye in enye Mane Age
Þat vs god defendede Maryage
By expresse worde I praye you telleþe Me
Or where he Comawndede he virgenyte
I wotte aswele As ye itt is no drede
The Apostle whan he spekeþe of Maydenhed
He sayde þ̉erofe precepte hadde he none
Men maye Cownsayle A woman to be oone
Butte counsaylenge is none Comaundemente
He putte itt in ower owne Iugemente
For hadde god comaundede Maydenhode
Than he hadde dampnede weddenge wᵗith the dede
And certes yefe þ̉er were no sede ysowe
Virgenyte þan whereof schuld hitt growe
Poule durste notte comaunden atte leste
A þynge of whiche his Mayster yafe hym none heste
The darte is sette vppe For virgenyte
Chace who so maye renneþe beste latte se
Butte þis worde is notte take of euerye wyȝte
Butte þ̉er As god wolde yeue hitt of his Myghte
I wotte wele that þe Apostle was A Mayde
Butte neủerþeles þoughe þat he wrote or sayde
He wolde þat euerye wyȝte were suche As he
Al nys notte butte counsayle to virgenyte
And For to be A wyfe he yaue me leue
Of Indulgence so is no repreue
To wedde me yefe þat my Make deye
Withoute excepciou of Bigamye
Al were itt gode no woman For to touche
He Mente As his bodye or in his couche
For ꝑperele is boþe Fyer ⁊and Towe to Assemble
Ye knowe whatte þis ensample Maye resemble
This is Al ⁊and some he helde virgenyte
More ꝑparfytte þan weddede in Frealte
Frealte clepe I notte butte þat he ⁊and sche
Wolde lede hur lyfe Al in Chastyte
I grᵃunte itt wele I haue none Envye
Thoughe Maydenhede pferre bigamye
Hitt lykeþe hem to be clene in bodye ⁊and goste
Of Myne estate I wol Make no bost
For wele ye knowe A lorde in his howsolde
Hathe notte euerye vesselle of goulde
Some bene of tree And doone her lorde saruyce
God clepethe to hym Folke in sondery wyse
And euere haþe of god A propre yeffte
Some þis some þat As hym lykeþe hem schyffte
Virgenyte is grete ꝑperfecciou
And contynence eke with deuociou
Butte Crist þat of Affecciou is wele
Bydde notte euerye wyȝte he schulde sele
Al þat he hadde And yeue itt to þe poure
And in suche wyse Folowe hym ⁊and his lore
He spake to hem þat wolde lyue ꝑparfyttelye
And lordenges by your leue þat Am notte I
I wol bestowe þe Flower of Myne Age
In the Actes ⁊and the Fruyte of Maryage
Telle me Allso to whatte Conclusioun
Were Membres made of Generacioun
And of so ꝑparfytte wyse ⁊and whye I wroughte
Trusteþe righte wele þey were notte made For noughte
Glose who so wol ⁊and saye boþe vppe ⁊and downe
That þey were made For purgacioun
Of vryne And oþ̉ere bothe þynges smale
Were eke to knowe A Female Frome A Male
And For none oþ̉ere cause whatte saye ye noo
The exꝑperience wotte itt is notte so
So þat the clarkes be notte with me wroþe
I saye þis that þeye Makede be For boþe
This is to sayene For offyce ⁊and For ease
Of engendrenge þare we notte god displese
Why schulden Men elles In her bokes sette
That Man schal yelde to his wyfe his dette
Now wherewith schulde he paye his payemente
Butte yefe þat he vsede that selye Instrument
Than were þeye Made vppon A Creature
To purge vryne And eke For engendrewre
Than schulde Men take of Chastite no cure
That haþe suche harneyse I you ensewre
To gone ⁊and vsen hem in engendrynge
What schulde thei thynk oủer Chastyte eny thynge
Crist was A Mayde ⁊and schapen as a Man
And Manye a saynte seþen þe worlde began
Yette lyuede þeye eủer in ꝑparfytte Chastite
I wol envye with none virgenyte
Lete hem ete wh brede of purede whete sede
And lette vs wyues ete barlye brede
And yette with barlye brede Mark tele can
Ower lorde Ihu refresschede Manye A Man
In suche estate that god haþe clepede vs
I wol ꝑperseuere I Am notte precyous
In wyfehode wol I vse Myne Instrumente
As Frelye As my Maker haþe hitt sente
Yefe I be daungerous god yeue me sorowe
Myne husbande schal haue boþe euen ⁊and Morowe
Whan þat hym lyste come Forþe And paye his dette
An husbande I wol haue I wol notte lette
Whiche schal boþe be my dettoᵘur⁊and my þrale
And to his tribulaciou withal
Vppon his Flesche whyle þat I Am his wyfe
I haue þe powere durenge Al my lyfe
Vppon his propre bodye And notte he
Righte þus the Apostle tolde vnto Me
And badde ower husbandes For to loue vs wele
Al this sentence Me lykethe euerydele
Uppe starte the pardoner þan Anone
Now dame qd he by god ⁊and saynte Iohn
Ye bene A noble prechoure in this cas
I was Abowte to wedde A wyfe Allas
Whatte schulde I bye on My Flesche so dere
Yette hadde I leuere none wedde to yere
Abyde qd sche My tale is notte bygonne
Naye þou schalte drynken of Anoþ̉ere Tonne
Ar þat I go schal be worse þan Ale
And whan þat I haue tolde Forþe my tale
Of Tribulacioun in Maryage
