But as yow lust nought greve me at al
They that my doughter and my sone be slayn
At yowre comavdement this is to sayn
I have had no part of children tweyne
But first sikenes and after woo and peyne
¶ Ye bien oure lord do with yowre owne thyng
Right as yow list askith no rede at me
For as I left at home al my clothyng
Whan ifirst cam to yow Right so quod she
Left I my wille and al my liberte
And toke yowre clothyng wherfor I yow praye
Doth yowre plesaunce I wil yowre lust obey
¶ And certes if I had presciens
And wille to knowe or ye yowre lust me told
I wol it do with oute necligence
But now I wote yowre lust and what ye wold
Al yowre plesaunce forme and stable I hold
For wist I that my deth wold do yow ease
Right gladly wold I deye yow to please
¶ Deth may nat make no comꝑperisoun
Vnto oure love and whan this Marqwys say
The constaunce of his wif he cast adowne
His eyen two and wonndrith that she may
In pacience suffre althis array
And forth he goth with drery contynaunce
But to his herte it was grete plesaunce
¶ This vggly S̉eriaunt in the same wise
As he hir doughter caught right so he
Or worse yif men can devise
Hath hent hir sone that was ful of beaute
And eủer in oon so pacient was she
That she no chiere made of hevynesse
But kisses hir sone and after gan it blesse
¶ Save this she pᵃyed hym that he myght
Hir litel sone he wold in erth grave
His tendre lymes delicat to sight
Fro foules and from bestis for to save
But she none annswer of hym myght have
He wente his wey as hym nothyng ne rought
But to Boloigne he tendrely hym brought
¶ This Marquyse wondrith eủer lenger the more
Vpon hir pacience and if that he
Ne hadde ⁊andabsent:hehe sothly knowen therbefore
That ꝑparfitly hir chieldren loved she
He wold have wend that of som sotilte
And of malice outher of cruel corage
That she hadde suffred this with sadde visage
¶ But wele he knew that next hym self certayn
She loved hir children best in any wise
But now of Wymmen wold I asken fayn
If these assayes myght I nough suffise
What cowde a sturdy husbond more devise
To proven hir wifhode and hir stidefastnesse
And the contynueng eủer in stidefastnessestidefastnessestidefastnesse sturdinesse
¶ But ther bien folke of whiche the condicioun
That whan they han acerteyn purpos take
They kan nat stynt of theyr entencioun
But right as they were bounde to a stake
They wil nat of theyr purpos slake
Right so this Marqwys fully hath purposid
To tempt his as he was first disposed
¶ He a waiteth if be word or countenaunce
That she to hym were chaunged of corage
But neủer cowde of any variaunce
She was ay oone hert and visage
And ay the further that she was in Age
The more triewe if it were possible
She was to hym in loue and more penyble
¶ For whiche it semed thus that of them two
Ther nas but oone wille for as walter lust
That same lust was hir plesaunce also
And god be thanked al fille for the best
She shewid wele for no worldly vnrest
A wif as of hir self nothyng ne shold
Wilne in effecte but as hir husbond wold
¶ The sclaundre of walter oft and wide spradde
That of a cruel hert he wikkedly
For he a pore womman weddid hadde
Hath murthred both his children privily
Whiche murmʳ was amonge hem comonly
No wonder nys for to the peplis ere
Ther cam no word but that the murdred were
¶ For which there as his peple therbefore
Had loved hym wele the sclaundre of his defame
Made theym that they hatid hym therfore
To ben a mortherer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel purpos nold nat stynt
To tempt his wif was al his entent
¶ Whan that his dought̉er xij yeere was of Age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enfoᵃmed of his wille sent his message
Comaundyng hem suche bulles to devise
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
How that the pope for his peples reste
Badde hym to wedde another if that hym leste
¶ I say he badde he shulde countrefete
The popes bulles makyng mencioun
That he hath leve his first wif to lete
As by the popis dispensacioun
To stynte rancour and distencioun
Be twixt the peple and hym thus spak the bulle
The whiche they have puplisshed at the full
¶ The rude peple as no wonder nys
Wenden ful wel that it hadde be so
But whan these tidynges com to Gresieldes
I deme that hir hert was ful woo
But she I like sadde for eủermo
Disposed was this humble creature
The aduersite of fortune al to endure
¶ Abidyng eủer his lust and his plesaunce
To whom she was yeve both hert and al
As to hir worldly suffisaunce
But shortly if I this story telle shal
This Marqwys wryten hath in special
A lrēletre in whiche he shewith his entente
And secretely he to Boloigne hath it sent
¶ To the Erl of Pavike whiche had tho
Weddit his suster pᵃy hir specially
To bryng hom ayen his chieldren tow
In honurable estate al opinly
But othyng he hym prayed vtterly
That he to no wight though men wold enquere
Shulde nat telle whos children that they were
¶ But say the mayden shuld iweddid be
Vnto the Marqwyse of Saluce anon
And as this Erle was preyed right so dide he
For at day sette he on his wey is gon
Towarde Saluce and lordis many oon
In riche array this mayden for to guyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir be side
¶ Arrayed was to ward hir mariage
This fressh mayde ful of gemmes cliere
Hir brothir whiche that viii yeere was of Age
Arraied eke ful fressh in his manere
And thus in grete noblesse and with gladde chiere
Toward Saluce shapyng theyr ioᵘurnay
From day to day they ryden her way
Explicit quarta pars
¶ Among althis after his wikked vsage
This Marqwyse yit his wif to tempt more
To the vttrest preef of hir corage
Fully to han exꝑperience and lore
If that she were as stidefast as bifore
He on aday in opyn Audience
Ful boystously hath sayde hir this sentence
¶ Certis Gresield I hadde ynough plesaunce
To have yow to my wif for youre goodenesse
As for trowth and for yowre obeisaunce
Nought for yowre lynage ne for yowre richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in grete lordship if I wil me avise
There is grete suitute and in sundry wise
¶ I may nat don as eủery plawman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wif and cryen day be day
And eke the popes rancoᵘur for to slake
Consentith it that dare I vndrestonde
And triewly thus moche wil I saye
Myn newe wif is comyng bi the way
¶ Be strong of hert and voyde anon hir place
And thilk dowary that ye brought to me
Take it agayn I graunt it of my grace
And tornyth to youre fadres house quod he
Noman may alwey han prosꝑperite
With meke herte I rede yow to endure
The stroke of fortune other of aventure
¶ And she agayn answerd in pacience
My lord quod I wote and wist al way
How that betwixt yowre magnificence
And my pouert no wight can ne may
Make comꝑperisoun it is no nay
I hield me neủer digne in no manere
To be yowre wif ne yit yowre chambrere
¶ And in this house there ye me lady made
The high god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neủer hield me lady ne maystresse
But humble suᵃnt to youre worthynesse
And eủer shal whiled that my lif may dure
Aboven eủery worldly creature
¶ That I so longe of yowre benyngte
Han hold me in honoᵘur and noblay
Where as I was nat worthi for to be
That thank I god and yow to whom I prey
Foryield it yow ther nys nomore to say
Vnto my fader gladly wil I wende
And with hym dwelle to my lives ende
¶ There I was fostred of a chield ful smal
Til I be dede my lyf there wil I lede
A widew clene in hert body and all
For sithens I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am yowre triewe wif it nis no drede
God shield suche alordis wif to take
Another man to husbond other to make
¶ And of yowre newe wif god of his grace
So graunt yow hele and high prosꝑperite
For I wil gladly yielden hir my place
In whiche that I was wont blisful to be
For sythens it likith yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertis rest
That I shal go I wil go whan yow lest
¶ But there as ye me profren suche dowarye
As I first brought it is wele in my my mynde
It were my wrecchid clothis nothyng fayre
The whiche to me were now ful hard to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by youre speche and yowre visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
¶ But soth is saide algate I fynde it triewe
For in effecte it proved is on me
Love is nat olde as whan it is newe
But certis lorde as for non aduersite
To deyen in the case it shal nat be
That eủer in word or werk I shal repent
That I yow yaf myn herte in hole entent
¶ My lord ye wote that in my fadres place
Ye dide me stripe out of my pore weede
And richely me clad of yowre grace
To yow brought I nought ellis owte of drede
But feyth and nakidnesse and maydenhede
And here agayne yowre clothyng I yow restore
And eke yowre weddyng ryng for eủermore
¶ The remenᵃnt of yowr Iewels redy be
Withynne yowre chambre dare I wele sayn
Nakid out of my faders house quod she
I cam and naked I must torne agayn
Al yowre plesaunce wolde I folwe fayn
But yit I hope it be nat yowre entent
That I smokles out of yowre paleys went
¶ Ye cowde nat do so dishonest athyng
That thilk wombe in whiche youre children lay
Shuld beforn the peple in my walkyng
Bien seyn al bare wherfor I yow pray
Late me nat like a worm go bi the way
Remembre yow myn owne lord so deere
I was yowre wyf though I vnworthy were
¶ Wherfor in gwerdoun of my maydenhede
Whiche that I brought and nat ayein bere
As vouchesauf to yeve to my mede
But suche asmok as I was wont to were
That I may therwith wry the wombe of her
That was yowre wif and here I take my leve
Of yow myn owne lord lest I yow greve
¶ The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Late it be stille and bere it forth with the
But wele vnnethis that word he spak
But went his wey for rowth and pite
Be forn the folk hir selven stripith she
And in hir smok with hede and foote albare
Toward hir faderhous is she fare
¶ The folk hir folwe wepynge in the wey
And fortune ay they cursyn as they gon
But she fro wepyng kept hir eyen drey
Ne in this tyme worde spak she non
Hir fader that these tidynges herd anon
Cursith the day that tyme and nature
Shope hym to be alyves creature
¶ For out of dowte this olde pore man
Was eủer in suspect of hir mariage
For eủer he demed sith it first began
That whan the lord fulfilled had his corage
Hym wolde thynk it were a disꝑperage
To his estate so lowe to alight
And voyden hir as sone as he myght
¶ Ageyns his dought̉er hastily goth he
For he by noyse of folk knewe hir comyng
And with hir old cote as it myght be
He coủered hir with sorwful wepyng
But on hir body myght he it nat bryng
For rude was the cloth and more of age
Be dayes fele than was hir mariage
¶ Thus with hir fader for a certayne space
Dwellith this flowre of wifly pacience
That neyther be hir wordis ne be hir face
Beforne the folke ne eke in theyr absence
Ne shewed she that hir was done offence
Ne of hir high estate no remembraunce
Ne had she as by hir countenaunce
¶ No wounder nys for in hir grete estate
Hir gost was eủer in grete humylite
No tender mowth ne hert delicate
No pompe no semblant of rialte
But ful of pacient benyngnite
Discret and prideles ay honurable
And to hir husbond eủer meke and stable
¶ Men speke of Iob and most for his hunblesse
As clerkis whan hem list can wele endite
Namly of men but as in sothfastnesse
Though clerkis preysen wymmen but alite
Ther can noman in humblesse hem acquyte
As wymmen can ne can be half so triewe
As wymmen bien but it be falle of newe
¶ From Boloyngne is this Erle of Pavyk Icome
Of whiche the fame vp sprang to more and lesse
And to the peplis eris al and some
Was cowth eke that a newe Markquysesse
He with hym brough in whiche pompe and richesse
That never was Iseen with mannes eye
So noble array in al west lumbardye
¶ The Marqwys that shoope and knew althis
Or that this Erle was come sent his message
For thilke sely pore Gresildis
And she with humble hert and sad visage
Nought with no swellyng though in her coaige
Cam at his hest and on knees hir sette
And reủerently and wisely she hym grette
¶ Gresield quod he my wil is vtterly
This mayde that shalbe weddid vnto me
Receyved be to morne as rially
As possible is in myn house to be
And eke that eủery wight in his degre
Have his Estate in sittyng and servise
And by plesaunce as I can best devise
¶ I have no womman suffisaunt certayn
The chambres for to array in ordynaunce
After my lust and therfor wolde I fayn
That thyn were al suche goủernaunce
Thow knowest eke of old al my plesaunce
Though thyn array be badde and evil beseye
Do thow thy deủer at the lest wey
¶ Nought only lord that I am gladde quod she
To done yowre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serve and please in my degre
Without feyneng and shal eủermo
Ne neủer for no wele ne for no woo
Ne shal the gost withynne myn hert stynte
To love yow best with al my triewe entente
¶ And with that worde she gan the house to dight
And tablis for to sette and beddis make
And peyned hirys to do althat she myght
Prayng the chambreris for goddis sake
To hasten hem and faste to swepe and shake
And she the most seruisable of al
Hath eủery chambre arrayed and his hal
¶ Aboute vndren gan this Erle alight
And with hym brought his noble children twey
For whiche the peple ran to se the sight
Of hir array so richely be sey
And thanne at erst among theym they sey
That Walter nas no foole theygh that hym leste
To chaunge his wif for it was for the beste
¶ For she is fayrer as they demen alle
Thanne is Gresield and more tendre of age
And fayrer fruyte betwixt hem shuld falle
And more plesaunt for hir high lynage
Hir brother eke was so faire of visage
That hem to se the peple hath caught plesaunce
Comendyng now the Marqwise goủernance
¶ O stormy peple vnsad and eủer vntriewe
Ay vndiscrete and chaungyng as a sane
Delityng ay in rumbil that is newe
For Ilike the mone wayxith ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng dere Inow a Iane
Yowre dome is false yowre counstaunce provith
A ful grete foole is he that on yow levith
¶ Thus sayden sad folke in that Citee
Whan that the peple gasid vp and downe
For they were glad right for the nouelte
To have a newe lady of the towne
Nomore of this make I now mencioun
But to Gresielde anon I wil me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir besinesse
¶ Ful busy was Gresield in eủer thyng
That to the fest was aꝑpartinent
Right nought was she abasshed of hir clothyng
Though it were rude and somdel to rent
But with gladde chere to the yate is went
With other folke to grete the Marqwisesse
And after that doth forth hir besynesse
¶ With so glad chere his gistes she receyvith
And konnyngly eủeriche in his degree
That no defawte noman aꝑperceyvith
But ay they wondre what she myght be
That in so pore array was for to se
And kowde suche honour and reuerence
And worthy they preysen hir prudence
¶ In al this meane while she ne stynt
This mayde and eke hir brother to comende ??is there a florish above commende??
With al hir hert with ful benyngne entent
So wel that noman cowde hir prase amende
But at the last whan these lordes wende
To sitten downe to mete he gan to calle
Gresield as she was busy in his halle
¶ Gresield quod he as it were in his pley
How likith the my wif and hir beaute
Right wele my lord quod she and in goode fey
A faerer saw I neủer none than she
I pray to god yeve yow prosꝑperrite
And so hope I he wil to yow sende
Plesaunce ynough vnto yowre lyves ende
¶ But othyng beseche I yow and warne also
That ye ne pryk with no tormentyng
This tendre mayden as ye han don mo
For she is forstrid in hir norisshyng
More tendrely and to my supposyng
She cowde nat adủersite endure
As cowde a pore fostred creature
¶ And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad chiere and no malice at al
And he so often had don hir offence
And she ay sadde and constaunt as a wal
Contynueng his:hishishir Innocence oủer al
This sturdy Marqwise gan his herte dresse
To rewe on hir wifly stidefastnesse
¶ This is ynough Gresield myn quod he
Be now nomore evil agast ne evil apaied
I have thy feyth and thy benyngnite
As wele as eủer womman was assaied
In grete astate and eke porely arraied
Now know I dere wyf yowre stidefastnesse
And hir in armys toke and gan hir kisse
¶ And she for wonder toke of it no kepe
Sher herd nat what thyng he to hir sayde
She firde as she had stirt out of hir sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir masidnesse abrayde
Gresield quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wif ne nonother I have
Ne neủer had so god my soule save
¶ This is thy dought̉er whiche thow hast supposed
To bien my wif that other feithfully
Shalbe myn Eyre as I have eủer suppesid
Thow bare hym in thy body triewly
At Boloigne have I kept hem privily
Take hem ayen for now maystow nat sey
That thow hast lorn any of thi children tweye
¶ And folkes that other wise han sayde of me
I warne hem wele that I have done this dede
For no malice ne for no cruelte
But for to assay in thy wommanhede
And nat to sle my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem prively and stille
Tille I thy purpos knewe and al thi wille
¶ Whan she this herd a swonne downe she fallith
For pitous Ioye and after hir swonnyng
She both hir chieldren to hir callith
And in hir armes pitously wepyng
Embrasith hem with tendre kissyng
Ful like amoder with hir salt teris
She bathith both hir visage and hir heris
¶ O whiche a pitous thyng it was to see
Hir swonnyng and hir fieble voys to here
Graunt mercy lord god thank it yow quod she
That ye han saved me my children deere
Now rekke I neủer to be ded right here
Sithens I stond in yoᵃ love and in yowre gᵃce
No fors of deth ne whan my spirit passe
¶ O tender o dere o yonge children myn
Yowre woful moder wende stidefastly
That cruel houndis or som foule vermyn
Had etyn yow but god of his mercy
And yowre benygne fader tenderly
Hath don yow kept and in the same stounde
Al sodainly she swapt doun to grounde
¶ And in hir swonne so sadly holdith she
Hir chieldren two whan she gan hem brace
That with grete sleyght and difficulte
The chieldren from hir armes they gan vnbrace
O many atere and many a pitous face
Downe ran of hem that stode hir beside
Vnnethis abowte hir myght they abide
¶ Walter hir gladith and hir sorw slakith
She rasith vp abaisshed from hir traunce
And eủery wight hir Ioye and fest makith
Tille she hath agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir doth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deynte to Ise the chiere
Betwixt them two now they ben met Ifeere
¶ These ladyes whan they her tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre gon
And stripen hir out of hir rude array
And in a cloth of gold that bright shon
With a corowne of many ariche ston
Vpon hir hed they in to halle hir brought
And there she honoured as she ought
¶ Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For eủery man and womman don theyr myght
This day in myrth and revel to dispende
Til on the wekken shone the sterris bright
For more solempne in eủery mans sight
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the revel of hir mariage
¶ Ful many ayeere in high prosꝑperite
Lyven these two in concord and in rest
And richely his doughter maryed he
Vnto alord on of the worthiest
Of al Italie and than in peas and rest
His wifes fadir in his court he kepith
Til that his soule out of his body crepith
¶ His sone succedith in his Eritage
In rest and peas after his faders day
And fortunate was eke in mariage
Al put he nat his wif in grete assay
This world nys nat so stronge it nys no nay
As it hathe bien in yeeris and tymes old
Herkenyth these auctours sayeng therfor
¶ This story is saide nought for that wifes shold
Folwen Gresield as in humylite
For it were vnportable though they wold
But for that eủery wight in his degre
Shuld be constant in aduersite
As was Gresield therfore petrak writith
This story whiche he with high stile enditith
For sithens a womman was so pacient
Vnto amortal man wele more vs ought
Receyven al in gre that god vs sent
For gret skille is that he prove that he wroughte
But he temptith no man that he bought
As saynt Iame who his Epistle rede
He provith folk alday it is no drede
And suffrith vs as for oure ex̉ercise
With sharpe skourgis of adủersite
Ful often to be beten in sundry wise
Nought for to knowen oure wille for c̉ertis he
Er we were born knewe al oure frealte
And for oure beste is alle his goủernaunce
Late vs than lyve in vertu and soeffraunce
But lordynges o word herknyth or I goo
It were fulhard to fynde now adayes
The gold of hem now hath so bad alayes
With brasse that though the koyne be fayre at eye
It wil rather brest a two than plye
For whiche haere for the wifes love of bath
Whos lyf and al hirs swete god maynteigne
In high maistrie and ellis were it skath
I wil with lusty hert fressh and grene
Say now a song to gladde yow I wene
And late vs stynt of Ernesteful mattiere
Herknyth my song that saith in this manere
Gresield is dede . and eke hir pacience
And both attones . buryed in Itaile
Wherfor I crye . in opyn Audience
No witty mān . be hardy to assaile
His wifes pacience . in hope to fynde
Cresieldes . for in ʆsertayne he shal faile
O noble wyfes . ful of prudence
Late non humylite . youre tunge nayle
Ne lete no clerk . have cause ne diligence
To write of yow . a story of such mervaile
And of Cresield . pacyent and kynde
Lest Chicheuache . yow swolow in his entraile
For with Ekko . that haldith no silence
But eủer aunswerith . at the countretaile
Be nat bedaffid . for yowre Innocence
But shortly takith on yow . the goủernaile
Emprintith yow this lesson . in yoᵘur mynd
For comvne profite sithens it may availe
Ye archewifes . standith at defens
Syn ye be stronge . as is a grete Camaile
And suffre nat men . do . yow offence
And sklendre . fel as in bataile
Beth Egre . as is a Tigre yonde in ynde
And clappith as a mylle . I yow counsaile
Ne drede hem nought . do hem no reủerence
For though youre husbond armed be in maile
The arrowes . of youre crabbid Eloquence
Shal perce his brest . and eke his adventaile
Ingelousy I rede . thow hym bynde
And thow shalt make hym cowche as doth aqwaile
If thow be faire . there folke be in presence
Shewe thow thy visage . and thyn Apparaile
If thow be foule . be fre of thy dispense
To gete the friendis . ay do thyn travaile
Be ay of chiere . as light as lef on lynde
And lete hym care waile wepe and wrynge

div.l: (base) And this Chanoun right in the mene while

div.l: (base) As men recorde many mo than I
(base) This philosophres speken so mystily

(base) O fy for schame they that haue be brent

(base) Ȝe that it vsen I rede ȝe it lete
(base) Lest ȝe lese al for bet than neuer is late

(base) Though ȝe prolle ay ȝe schull it neuer fynde
(base) Ȝe ben as bolde as is bayard the blynde

div.l: (base) For if ȝe doon ȝour thrift is gon ful clene /

div.l: (base) What is magnasia goode sire I pray /

div.l: WHan that this yoman . his tale ended had
Of this false chanou . whiche that was so bad
Oure host gan sey . triewly and certayn
This priest was begyled . soth for to sayn
He wenyng . for to be a philosophre
Til he right no gold . left in his cofre
And sothly this priest . had alither Iape
This cursed chanon . put in his hode an Ape
But althis wil I . passe oủer as now
Sir doctour of phesyk . I pray yow
Telle vs a tale . of som honest matiere
It shalbe don . if that ye wil it here
Sayde this doctour . and his tale began anon
Now goodemen quod he . herkenyth eủerychon

div.l: (base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
(base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
(base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
(base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
(base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
(base) Which afterward may greve þeim sore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
(base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
(base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede
(base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
(base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
(base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede

div.l: (base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
(base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde

div.l: (base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
(base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
(base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye

(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius

div.l: (base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors

div.l: (base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas

Here endeth þe ꝓprolog
and begynnyth the
tale of þe ꝑpardoner
LOrdynges quod he . In chirche whan I preche
I peyne me to have . an haunteyn speche
I rynge out . as rounde as doth a belle
For I can al by rote . that I telle
My tyme is alwey oon . and eủere was
Radix omnium malorum . est cupiditas
First I pronounce . whens that I come
And than my bulles . showe al and some
Oure liege lordis seale . on my patent
That shewe I first . my body to warent
That noman . be bold . priest ne clerk
Me to distourbe . of cristes holy werk
And after that . telle I forth my talis
Bulles of Popes . and of Cardinales
Of patriarkes . and bisshoppes I shewe
And in latyn . I speke a wordes fewe
To savoure withal . my predicacioun
And for to stire men . to devocioun
In eủery village . and eủery towne
Cupiditas est Radix . omi malorum
Than shewe I forth . my long cristal stones
I crammed ful of clowtes . and of bones
Reliques they bien . as weene they ichon
Than have in laton . a shulderbon
Whiche that was . anholy Iewes sheepe
Goode men I say . at my wordis take kepe
If that this bon . bien wasshen in a welle
If kowe or calf . sheepe or oxe swelle
That any worme . hath ete or stonge
Aboute the hert . or ellis the lounge
And it is hole anon . and furthermore
Of pokkes and of scabbe . and of eủery sore
Shal eủery shepe be hole . that of this welle
Drynketh a draught . take hede what I telle
If that the goode man . that the bestis owith
Wil eủery wike . or that the cok hym crawith
Fastyng drynk . of this welle a draught
As thilk holy Iewe . oure elders taught
His bestis and his store . shal multeplye
And sirs also . It helpith Ialousye
And though aman be falle . in Ialouse rage
Late make with this water . his potage
And neủer shal he . his wyf mystrust
Though he the soth . of hir defaute wist
Al had she taken . priestis tweyne or three
Here is a myten eke . that ye may se
He that his hand wil put . in this myteyne
He shal have multiplyeng . of his greyne
Whan he hath sowen . be it whete or otes
So that he bryng me . goode pans or grotes
And men and wymmen . oo thyng I warne yow
If any wight . be in this chirche now
That hath don synne . horible that he
Dare nat for shame . of it shryven be
Or any womman . be she yong or old
That hath made . hir husbonde cukkold
Suche folk shal have . no power ne grace
To offre to my reliques . in this place
And who so fyndith hym . out of suche blame
They wil come vp . and offre in goddis name
And I assoile hym . bi the auctorite
Suche as my bulle . was graunted me
By this gawd . have I wonne eủery yeere
A hundred mark . sith I was pardonere
I stonde like a clerk . in my pulpitte
And shewe lewde people . synne I sette
I preche so as I have lered bi fore
And telle . an hundred Iapes more
Than peyne I me . to strecche forth the nekke
And est and west . vpon the people I bekke
As doth a dowf . sittyng on a bierne
Myn handes and my tunge . gon ful yerne
That it is Ioy . to se my busynesse
And auarice . and suche cursidnesse
Is al my prechyng . for to make hem fre
To yeve hir pans . and namly vnto me
For myn entent . is nat but for to wynne
And nothyng . for correccioun of synne
I rekke neủer . whan they bien buryed
Though that theyr soulis . gon ablacburyed
For certis . many a predicacioun
Comyth oft tyme . of evil intencioun
Som for plesaunce of folk . and som for flaterye
To bien avaunced . by Ipocrasie
And som for veyne glorie . and for hate
For whan I dare nat . none otherwise debate
Than wil I stynge hem . with my tonge smert
In prechyng so . that he shal nat stert
To be defamed falsly . so that he
Hath trespaced . to my brother or to me
For though I telle nat . his propre name
Men shal wele knowe . that it is the same
By som signe . and other circumstaunces
Thus smyte I folk . that doth vs displesaunces
Thus spete I out my venym vnder hewe
Of holynesses . to semen holy and triewe
But shortly myn entent . I wil devise
I preche of nothyng . but of covetise
Therfor my tyme is yit . and eủere was
Radix omnium malorum . est cupiditas
Thus can I preche . ayenst the same vice
Whiche that I vse . and that is auarice
But though my self . be gilty in that synne
Yit can I make . other folke to wynne
From auarice . and sore hem repente
But that nys nat . my principal entent
I preche nat . but for couetise
Of this matier . it ought Inow suffice
Than telle I hem . ensamples manyon
Of olde storyes . longe tyme agon
For lewde peple . loven talis olde
Suche thynges . konne they reporte and holde
What trowe ye . that whiles I may preche
And wynne gold and silủer . for to teche
That I wil lyve . in poủerte wilfully
Nay nay . I thought it neủer triewly
For I wil preche . and begge in sundry londes
I wil do no labour . with my hondes
Ne make baskettis . and lyve therby
Be cause I wil nat lyve . Idully
I wil non of the apostels . countrefete
I wil have money . malt chese and whete
Al were it yeven . of the porest page
Owther of the porest widowe . in a village
Al shuld her chieldren . sterue and famyne
And I wil drynke . the licorest of the wyne
And have a Ioly wenche . In eủery towne
But herkenyth lordynges . in conclusioun
Youre likyng is . that I shal telle a tale
Now that I have dronk . a draught of corny ale
By that I hope . I shal telle yow a thyng
That shalbe reason . at youre likyng
For though my self . be a ful vicious man
A moral tale . yitte I yow telle can
Whiche Iames to preche . for to wynne
Now holdith youre peas . my tale I wil begynne
IN flaundres whilom . was a company
Of yong folk . that haunted foly
As hasard ryot . stwes and taủernes
Harpes rubibes . lutes and gyternes
They dauncen and playen . at the dyse nyght and day
And ete also oủer . that theyr myght may
Thurgh whiche they do . the devil sacrefice
Withyn the devils temple . in sundry wyse
By suꝓprofluite . abhomynable
Theyr othes bien so grete . and dampnable
That it is grisly . for to here hem swere
Oure blissed lordis body they alto tere
Hem thought Iewes . rent hym nat I nough
And ilke of hem . at others synne lowgh
And right anon . in there come tomblesters
Fetys and smal . and yonge fruterers
Syngers with harpes . bawdes and wafrers
Suche bien verray . the devils officers
To kyndle and blowe . the fuyre of lecherye
That is annexed . vnto glotenye
The holy writte . take I to wittnesse
That lechery is in wyne . and dronkennesse
Lo how that dronken loth . vnkyndely
Lay by his doughtres two . vnwityngly
So dronk he was . he nyst nat what he wrought
Herodes who that hath the story sought
Whan he of wyne . was replete at his feste
Right at his owne table . yaf his hest
To sle the Baptist Iohn . ful giltles
Senek sayth . a goode worde doutles
He sayth he can no difference fynde
Betwixt aman . that is out of his mynde
And a man . that is dronklew
But that woodenesse . is fallen in a shrewe
ꝒProseuerith lengger . than doth dronkennesse
O gloteny ful of cursidnesse
O cause first . of oure confusioun
Origynal . of oure dampnacioun
Til crist had bought vs . with his bloode agayn
Lo how dere . shortly for to sayne
Abought was . the cursid vilanye
Corrupt was al this world thurgh glotony
Adam oure fader . and his wif also
From paradice . to laboure and to wo
Were dryven for that vice . it is no drede
For whiles that Adam fasted . as I rede
He was in paradice . and whan that he
Ete of the fruyte . defended of the tree
Anon he was . cast out . to woo and peyne
O gloteny on the . wele ought vs pleyne
O wist a man . how many maladyes
Folowith of excesse . and of glotonyes
He wold be the more . mesurable
Of his dyete . sittyng at his table
Alas the short throte . the tender mowth
Makith that Est west . north and sowth
In erth in ayre . in water men to synke
To gete a gloton . deynte mete and drynke
Of this matier . O powle wele canstow trete
Mete vnto wombe . and wombe vn to mete
Shal god distroy . both as paule sayth
Alas a foule thyng . it is be my fayth
To say this worde . and fowler is the dede
Whan men so drynkyth . of the white and rede
That of his throte . makyth his pryve
Thurgh thilke . cursed suꝓprofluite
The Apostel wepyng . saith ful pitously
Ther walken many . of whiche told have I
I say it now wepyng . with pitous voyce
There bien enemyes . of cristes croys
Of whiche thende is deth . wombe is her god
O wombe . o bely . o stynkkyng cod
Fulfilled of dong . and of corrupcioun
At oyther ende . of the foule is the seasou
How grete acost . and laboᵘur is to fynde
These cokes how they stampe . streyne and grynde
To turne substaunce . in to accident
To fulfille . al the licorous talent
Out of the harde bones . knokken they
The mary . for they cast nat a way
That may go thurgh the golet sauf and soote
Of spicery of levis . bark and Roote
Shal bien his sawe . made bi delite
To maken hem . a newe appetite
But certis he that hauntith suche delices
Is ded . while he livith . in tho vices
A lecherous thyng . is wyne and dronkennesse
It is ful of stryveng . and wrecchidnesse
O dronken man . disfygured in thi face
Fowle is thy breth . fowle artow to enbrace
And thurgh thy dronken nose . sownyth the sown
As though thow saydest . ay Sampson sampson
Thow fallest . as it were a dronken swyne
As yit god wote . Sampson drank neủer wyne
Thy tonge is lost . and al thyn honest cure
For dronkennesse . is verray sepulture
Of mannes witte . and his discrecioun
In whom that drynk . hath domynacioun
He can no counseile kepe . it is no drede
Now kepe yow from the white . and from the rede
Namly from the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle . in fissh strete . and in chepe
This wyne of spayne . crepith subtilly
In other wynes . growyng fast by
Of whiche risith . suche fumosite
That whan a man hath dronk a draught too or thre
And weneth that he be . at home in chepe
Than is he in spayne . at the towne in lepe
Nought at the Rochel . ne at Burdewx towne
And than wil they say . sampson sampson
But herkenyth lordis . oo thyng I yow pray
That al the soủerayn actes dare I say
Of victories in the old testament
That thurgh verray god . that is omnipotent
Weren done in abstynence . and in prayere
Loke the bible . and there ye may it lere
Lokith Actila . the grete conquerour
Deyd in his sleepe . with shame and dishonoᵘur
Bledyng at his nose in dronkennesse
A Capitayne . shud live in sobrenesse
And oủer al these . avise yow right wele
What was comavded . vnto lamuele
Nat samuel . but lamuel say I
Redith the bible . and fyndith it expresly
Of wyne yevyng . of hem that arn Iustice
No more of this . for it may suffice
And now that I have spoken of gloteny
Now wil I defende yow . hasardry
Hasard is verray moder . of lesynges
And of disceyt . and cursid forswerynges
Blaspheme of crist . manslaughter and wast also
Of bataile of tyme . and of furthermo
It is repref . and contrary to honoᵘur
For to beholden . a comou hasardoᵘur
And eủer the hygher . he is of estate
The more he is holden desolate
If that a prince . vse hasardy
In al goủernaunce . and policie
He is . as by comvne oppyniou
Holde the lasse . in reputacioun
Stilbon that was holde . a wise ambassiatoᵘur
Was sent in to Corynthy . with ful grete honoᵘur
For Calidoyne . to make hym allyaunce
And whan he com . happed this chaunce
That al the grettest . that wore of that lond
Pleyeng at the hasard . he hem fond
For whiche as soone . as it myght be
He stale hym . home ayen . in to his contre
And sayde there wold I nat leese my name
I wold take on me . nat so grete diffame
For to allye yow . to no hasardours
Sendith other wiser . ambassatours
For be my trowth . me were lever dye
Than I shuld yow . to hasardours allye
For ye that bien . so glorious in honours
Shal nat ally yow . with hasardours
As bi my wille . ne by my trete
This wise philosophre . thus sayde he
Looke eke that the kyng . Demetreus
The kyng of Parthes . as the booke saith thus
Sent hym a peyre of dyse . of gold in scorn
For he had vsed hasardy . ther beforn
For whiche he hielde . his glorie and his Renown
For no value . of reputacioun
Lordis myght fynde . other man play
Honest I nowgh to dryve the day a way
Now wil I speke . of othes false and grete
A worde or two . as other bookes entrete
Grete sweryng is a thyng abhomynable
And false sweryng . is moche more reprovable
The high god . forbad sweryng at al
Witnesse of Mathew . but in special
Of sweryng the holy . Ieromye
Thow shalt swere thyn othes . and nat ly
And swere in doome . and eke in Rightwisnesse
But Idel sweryng . is a cursidnesse
Byholde and se . that in the first table
Of high god his hestis . honorable
How that two hestis . is this
Take nat my name . In ydulnes amys
Lo rather he forbedith . suche sweryng
Than homycide . or any othor . thyng
I say as thus . by ordre it standith
This knowith . that his hestes vndirstandith
How that the secunde hest . is that
And further oủer . I wil telle the al plat
That vengeaunce . shal nat parte from his house
That of his othes . is so outrageous
By goddis precious hert and his nayles
And bi his bloode . that is in hailes
Seven is my chaunce . and his fyve and thre
By goddes armes . If thow falsly play me
This dagger shal thurgh . thyn hert goo
This fruyt comyth . of thylk bones twoo
Forsweryng Ire falsenesse . homycide
Now for the love of Crist that for vs deyd
Levith these othes . both grete and smale
For I shal telle yow . a mervilous tale
These Riotours . of whiche I telle
Long erst or pryme . rong any belle
Were sette in a taủerne . for to drynke
And as they satte . they herd a belle clynke
Beforn acorps . was caryed to his grave
That oon of hem . gan calle to his knave
Go bot quod he . and aske redily
What corps is that . that passith forby
And loke thow reporte . his name wele
Sir quod this man . it nedith neủer adele
It was me told . or ye com here twoo houres
He was parde . anold felawe of yowres
Al sodainly . was he slayn to nyght
For dronken as he sat . vpon his benche vpright
There came a prince thieft . men clepen deth
That in this contre . al the peple sleth
And with his spore . he smote his hert a two
And went his . with out wordis moo
He hath a thowsand slayne . this pestilence
And mayster . ar ye come . in his presence
Me thynk that it wore . necessarie
For to beware . of suche an aduersarie
Beth redy . for to mete hym eủermore
Thus taught me my dame . I say nomore
Be seynt Marie . saide this taủernere
The chield saith soth . for he hath slayn to yeere
Hens oủer a myle . withyn a grete village
Both man and womman . chield and page
I trowe his habitacioun . be there
To bien avised . grete wisdom it were
Or that he dide aman . dishonoᵘur
Yee goddisarmes . quod this Riatoᵘur
Is it suche ꝓproile . with hym for to meete
I shal hym sechen . by stie and by streete
I make a vow . bi goddis digne bones
Herkenyth felawes . we thre bien al oones
Late eche of vs . holde vp hand to other
And eche of vs . by come others brother
And we wil sle . the false traitoᵘur deth
He shalbe slayne . he that so many sleth
Bi goddis dignite . or it be nyght
To gydre han these thre . theyr hertis plight
To live and deye . ilkon of hem with other
As though he were . his owne born brother
And vp they starten . and dronken in this Rage
And forth they gon . toward that village
Of whiche the taủernere . hath spoken of to forn
And many a grisly oth . than hath they sworn
And cristes blessid body . they al to rent
That deth shalbe ded . If that we may hym hent
Whan they han gon . nat fully half amyle
Right as they wolden . have troden oủer a stile
Anold pooreman . with hem mette
This old man . ful mekely hym grette
And sayde thus . now lordes god yow se
The proudest of these riatoᵘurs thre
Answerde ayen . what cherole with harde grace
Why artow al forwrapped . save thi face
Why lyvestow so longe . in so grete age
This old man loked . in his visage
And sayde thus . for I can nat fynde
Aman though I walked in to ynde
Neyther in cite . ne in no village
That wil chaunge his yowth for myn age
And therfor mote I . have myn age stille
As long tyme . as it is goddis wille
Ne deth alas . nyl nat have my lif
Thus walke I lyke . a restles caytef
And on the grounde . whiche is my moder gate
I knok with my staf . both erly and late
And say lief moder . late me Inne
Lo how I wanshe . flessh bloode and skynne
Allas whan shal my bones . bien at reste
Moder with yow . wold I chaunge my chest
That in my chambre . long tyme hath be
Yee for an hayre clowte . to wrappe in me
But yit to me . she wil do no grace
For whiche ful welked . is my face
But sirs to yow . it is no curtasye
To speke to anold man . vilanye
But he trespaced . in worde or ellis in dede
In holy writ . ye may youre self wele rede
Ayenst anoldman . hore vpon his hede
Ye shul arise . therfor I yeve yow rede
Ne doth to anold man . harme as now
No more than ye wold . aman did yow
In age if that yee . so longe abide
And god be with yow . where yee go or ride
I mote go thider . as I have to goo
Nay old cherol by god . thow shalt nat soo
Sayde these other hasardors anon
Thow partist nat so lightly . be seynt Iohn
Thow spak right now . of thilk traitoᵘur deth
That in this contre . al oure friendis sleth
Have here my trowth . as thow art his espie
Telle where he is . or ellis thow shalt dye
Bi god . and bi the holy sacrament
For sothly . thow art of his assent
To sle S vs yong folk . thow false thief
Now sirs if it be to yow . so lief
To fynde deth . turne vp this croked way
For in that grove . I left hym be my fay
Vnder a tree . and there he wil abide
Ne for youre bost . he nyl hym nothyng hyde
Se ye that eke . right there ye shul hym fynde
God save yow . that bought ayen mankynde
And yow amend . thus sayde this old man
And eủeriche . of the riatours Ran
Til they cam to the tre . and there they founde
Floreyns of gold fyn . I koyned rounde
Wilnygh a seven busshels . as theym thought
No lenger than after deth they sought
But eche of them . so glad was of that sight
For that the floreyns . so fayre bien and bright
Than downe they sette hem . by that precious horde
The worst of hem . he spak the first worde
Brethern quod he . take heede what I say
My witte is grete . though I bourde and play
This tresour hath fortune . to vs yeven
In myrth and Iolite . oure lyf to lyven
And lightly so as it comyth . so wil we spende
Eye goddis precious hert . who wende
To day that we shuld have . so faire a grace
But myght this gold . be caryed from this place
Home vnto myn house . or ellis to yowres
For wele I wote . that al this gold is oures
Thanne were we . in high felicite
But triewly be day . it may nat be
Men wold sayen . that we were thiefs strong
And for oure tresour . do vs anhonge
This tresour must I caryed be . by nyght
As wisely and as sleightly . as it myght
Wherfor I rede . lete loke amonge vs alle
To drawe and lete se . where the cut wil falle
He that hath the cut . with hert blyth
Shal renne to towne . and that ful swith
To bryng vs brede . and drynk ful prively
And two of vs shal kepen ful subtily
This tresour wele . and if he wil nat tarye
Whan it is nyght . we wil this tresour carye
By oon assent . where as vs likith best
That oon of hem . brought gras in his fest
And bad hem drawe . and loke on whom it wold falle
And it felle . on the yongest of hem alle
And forth toward the towne . he went anon
And also soone . as he was gon
That oon of hem . spak vnto that other
Thow wost wele . thow art myn owne sworn brother
Thy profite wil I telle the anon
Thow wost wele . that oure felawe is gon
And here is gold . and that right grete plente
That it shalbe departid . among vs thre
But natheles . if I can shape it soo
That it departed were . among vs two
Had I nat don . a friendes toᵘurne to the
That other answerd I not how that myght be
I wold wele that the gold were oures two
What shuld we doo . that it myght be soo
Shal it be counsaile . sayde the first shrewe
And I shal tellen . in wordes fewe
What we shul don . and bryng it aboute
I graunt quod that other . out of doute
That be my trowth . I wil the nat be wreyen
Now quod the first . thow wost wele we be tweyn
And two of vs . stronger shalbe than oon
Looke whan he is sette . and that anon
Arise as though . thow woldest with hym play
And I shal ryve hym . thurgh the sides twey
While that thow strogelest . with hym as in game
And with thy dagger . loke thow do the same
And thanne shal al this goode . departed be
My dere friende . betwixt the and me
Than may we both . oure lustes fulfille
And play at the dys . right at oure owne will
And thus accorded bien these shrewes twaye
To sle the thridde . as ye have herd me saye
This yongest whiche that went vnto the towne
Ful oft in his hert . it rolled vp and downe
The beaute of these floreyns . fayre and bright
O lord quod he . If so were I myght
Have al this tresour . to my self alon
There is noman . that livith vnder the thron
Of gold that shuld live . so mery as I
And at the last the fiend oure enemy
Put in his thought . that he shuld poyson beye
With whiche he myght . sleen his felawes twey
For why the fiend . fonde hym in suche livyng That he had
That he had lever . hym to sorow bryng
For this was vtterly . his entent
To sleen hem both . and neủer to repent
And forth he goth . no lenger wold he tarye
In to the towne . vnto apothecarie
And prayd hym . that he wold hym selle
Som poyson . that he myght his rattis kille
And eke ther was . a polcat in his hawe
That as he sayde . his capons had I slawe
And sayde he wold . wreke hym if he myght
Of vermyn . that distroyed hym be nyght
The potecharye answerd . thow shalt have
A thyng as god my soule save
In al this world . there nys no creature
That ete or drynk . of this confecture
Nought but the montenaunce . of a corn of whete
That he ne shal . his lyf anon forlete
Ye sterve he shal . and that in lasse while
Thanne thow wilt gon . a pace nat but a myle
This poyson that is so hard and violent
This cursid man hath it in hand I hent
This poyson in a box . and sithens he ran
In to the next strete . vnto a man
And borwed hym . large botels thre
To his felawes . ayen repayrith he
The thridde he kept clene for his drynk
For al the nyght . he shope hym to swynk
In caryeng of that gold . out of that place
And whan this Riatoᵘur . with sory grace
Had filled with hym . hise grete botelꝭes thre
To his felawes . ayein repayrith he
What nedith it to sermon therof more
For right as they had cast his deth bi fore
Right . so they han hym slayne . and that anon
And whan this was don . than spak that oon
Now late vs sitte and drynk . and make vs merye
And afterward we wil his body berye
And after that . it happed hem ꝓpro cas
To take the botel . therin the poyson was
And dranke and yaf his felaw drynk also
Thurgh whiche anon . they starf both two
But certis I suppose . that avycen
Wrote neủer in no canon . ne in no fen
Mo wondre sorwis . of enpoysenyng
Thus had these we wrecchis two . theyr endyng
And eke this false . enpoysener also
Thus endid bien . these homycides two
O cursid synne . ful of al cursidnesse
O traytours homycides . of wykkidnesse
O glotonye luxurie and hasardye
Thow blasphemor of crist . with vilanye
And othes grete . of vsage and of pride
Allas mankynde . how may it be tide
That to thy creator . whiche that the wrought
And with his precious bloode the bought
Thow art so false . and so vnkynde allas
Now goode men . god foryeve youre trespas
And kepe yow . from the synne of auarice
Myn holy pardon . may yow al warice
So that ye offre . nobles or sterlyngges
Other ellis silủer . spones broches or rynges
Bowith youre hede . vnder this bulle
Comyth vp ye wyfes . and offreth yowre wulle
Youre name I entre here . in my rolle anon
In to the blisse of heven . shul ye al gon
I yow assoile . be my high power
Ye that wiln offre . as clene and as cliere
As ye were born . and lo sirs thus I preche
And Ihıı̄un crist . that is soulis leche
So graunt yow his pardon to resceyve
For that is best . I wil nat yow disceyve
But sirs oo worde . for gate I in my tale
I have reliques . and pardon in my male
As fayre as any man . in ynglond
Whiche were yeve me . bi the popis hond
If any of yow . wil of deuocioun
Offren and han myn absolucioun
Cometh forth anon . and knelith here a down
That ye may have part . of my pardoun
Or ellis takith pardon . as ye wende
Al newe and fressh . at eủery townes ende
So that ye offren alwey . newe and newe
Nobles and pans . whiche beth goode and triewe
It is an honoᵘur . to eủeriche . that bien here
That ye may have . a suffisiaunt pardonere
To assoile yow . in contre . as ye ride
For aventures . whiche that may be tyde
For ꝓproauenture ther may falle . oon or two
Doun of his hors . and breke his nekke a too
Loke whiche a suerte . it is to yow alle
That I am . in youre felawship falle
That may assoile yow . both more and lasse
Whanne the soule shal . from the body passe
I rede that oure host . shal begynne
For he is most . envolupte in synne
Com forth sir host . and offre first anon
And thow shalt kisse . the Reliques eủerychon
Yee for a grote . vnbokle anon thy purs
Nay nay quod he . thanne have I Cristes curs
Late be quod he . it shal nat be so theche
Thow woldest make me . kysse thyn old breche
And swere it were . a relique of a seynt
Though it were . with thy fondement I peynt
But bi the crosse . whiche seynt helene fonde
I wold I had thy coliou . in myn honde
In stide of reliques . of seynt vaurye
Lete cut hem of . and I wil hem carye
They shul be shryned . in an hogges torde
This pardon aunswerd . nat a worde
So wroth he was . he wolde no worde say
Now quod oure host . I wil no lengger play
With the . ne with nonother angry man
But right anon . the worthy knyght began
Whan that he saugh . that al the people lough
Nomore of this . for it is right I nowgh
Sir ꝓprodoner be mery . and glad of chiere
And ye sir host . that bien to me so dere
I pray yow . that ye kysse the ꝓprodonere
And pardonere . I pray yow draw yow nere
And as we dide . late vs laugh and play

l.hi: And anon they kyssed . and ryden forth ther way

div.l: A Marchaunt whilom . dwelt at Seynt Denyce
That riche was . for men hield hym wise
A wyf he had . of excelent beaute
And companable . and reủerently was she
Whiche is a thyng . that causith more dispence
Than worth is al . the chiere and the reuerence
That men han don at festis and owther at daunces
Suche salutaciouns . and countenaunces
Passith as doth . the shadow on a wal
But wo is hym . that pay mote for al
The sely husbond . algatis he mote pay
He v must vs cloth . and vs array
Al for his owne worship . richely
In whiche array . we daunce Iolily
And if that he nought may ꝑparaduenture
Owther ellis lust nought . Suche spence to endure
But thynkkyth . it is wast and I lost
Than mote another . payen for oure cost
Owther leene vs gold . and that is ꝑperilous
This noble Marchaunt . hield a worthy hous
For whiche he had alday . grete repayre
For his largesse . and for his wif was fayre
That wondir is . but herkenyth to my tale
Amonge al his gestis . grete and smale
Ther was a monke . a fayre man and a bold
I trowe a .xxx. wynter he was old
That eủer in oon . was drawyng to that place
This yong Monke . that was so fayre of face
Aqueynted was . so with this goode man
Sith that theyr first knowlege bygan
That in his house as famulyer was he
As it is possible any friend to be
And for asmochel . as this goode man
And eke this monke . of whiche I be gan
Were both two born . in oo village
The monke hym claymeth . as for cosynage
And he ageyn . saith nat ones nay
But was as glad therof . as fowle of day
For to his hert . it was a grete plesaunce
Thus bien they knyt . with et̉erne allyaunce
And ilk of hem . gan other for to assure
Of brotherhed . whiles theyr lif may dure
Fre was Daun Iohn . and manly of dispence
As in that house . and ful of diligence
To don plesaunce . and also grete costage
He nat forgate . to yeve the lest page
In al that house . but after theyr degre
He yaf the lord . and sythens al his meyne
Whan that he com . som man honest thyng
For whiche they were . as glad of his comyng
As fowle is fayn . whan sonne vprisith
No more of this as now for it suffisith
But so bifel . this marchᵃunt vpon aday
Shope hym to make . redy his array
Toward the towne . of Bruges for to fare
To byen there . a porcioun of ware
For whiche he hath . to parice sent anon
A messangier . and pᵃyed hath daun Iohn
That he shuld come . to Seynt Denys and pleye
Wyth hym and his wyf . a day or twey
Or he to Bruges went in al wise
This noble monke . of whiche I yow devise
Hath of his Abbot . as hym lust licence
Because he was a man . of high prudence
And eke anofficer . out for to ride
To se theyr graunges . and theyr biernys wide
And vnto Seynt Denys he comyth anon
Who was so welcom . as my lord Daun Iohn
Oure dere cousyn ful of curtesye
With hym brought he . a Iobbe of Maluesye
And eke another . ful of fyne vernage
And volatile . as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete . drynk and pleye
This marchaunt and this monk . a day or tweye
The thrid day . this marchaunt vparisith
And on his nedis . sadly hym avisith
And vp in to his comptyng house goth he
To rekne with hym self . as wele may be
Of thilk yeere . how that with hym stoode
And how that he . dispendid . had his goode
And if that he . encresid were or none
His bokes and his bagges . manyon
He layd beforn hym . on his comptyng boorde
Ful riche was his tresoure . and his hoorde
For whiche ful faste . his countre dore he shette
And eke he nold . that noman shuld hym lette
Of his acomptis . for the mene tyme
And thus he sitte . til it was past pryme
Daun Iohn was risen . in the morn also
And in the gardyn . walkyth too and fro
And hath his thynges . sayde ful curteysly
This goode wif cam walkyng . ful prively
In to the gardyne . there he walkyth softe
And hym salweth . as she hath don ful ofte
A mayden chield cam in hir companye
Whiche as she lust . she may goủerne and guye
For yit vnder the yerd . was the mayde
O dere cosyn myn . Daun Iohn she sayde
What eylith yow . so rathe to arise
Nece quod he . it ought Inough suffice
V . howres for to slepe . on a nyght
But it were . for anold palled wight
As bien these weddid men . that lyen and dare
As in a forme . thei sitte a wery hare
Were alforstraught . with houndes grete and smale
But dere nece why . be ye so pale
I trowe certis . that oure goode man
Hath yow so laboured . sith the nyght began
That yow were nede . to rest hastily
And with that worde . he lough ful merily
And of his own thought . he was ful rede
This faire wif . gan to shake hir hede
And sayde thus . ye god wote al quod she
Nay cosyn myn . it stant nat so with me
For be that god . that yaf me soule and lyf
In al the Realme of fraunce . is there no wyf
That lasse lust hath . to that sory play
For I may syng alas . and welaway
That I was born . but to no wight quod she
Dare I nat tellen . how it stant with me
Wherfor I thynk . out of this land to wende
Other ellis of my self . to make anende
So ful am I . of drede and eke of care
This monk bigan . vpon this wiff to stare
And saide alas . nay nece god forbede
That ye for any sorwe . aI for any drede
For do youre self . but tellith me youre grief
ꝑparauenture . I may in youre myschief
Counseil or help . and therfor tellith me
Al youre annoye . for it shalbe secre
For on my portows . I make anoth
That neủer in my lif . for lief ne for loth
Ne shal I of no counseile . yow be wreye
The same ayain to yow . quod she I seye
By god and by this portows . I swere
Thoygh men me wold . in x pecis to tere
Ne shal I neủer . for to go to helle
Be wrye a word . of thyng that ye me telle
Nought for the cosynage . and the alliaunce
But verily for the love . and affiaunce
Thus bien they swore . and he hir verrily kist
And eche of hem . told other what hem list
Cosyn quod she . if I had a space
As I have none . and namly in this place
Than wold I telle . a legent of my liff
What I have suffred . sythens I was a wyf
With myn husbond . although he be youre cosyn
Nay quod this monk . bi god and seynt Martyn
He nys nomore cosyn vnto me
Than is this leff . that hangith on the tre
I clepe hym so . bi seynt Denys in Fraunce
To have the more cause . of acqueyntaunce
Of yow . whiche I have loved specially
Aboven al wymmen . in this world sikerly
This swere I yow . on my professioun
Tellith youre grieff . lest that he com doun
And hastith yow and goth youre wey anon
My dere love quod she . O daun Iohn
Ful lief me were . this counseil to huyde
But out It mote . it may no lengger abyde
Myn husbond is to me . the worst man
That eủer was sithens this world bygan
But sythen I am a wif . It sit nat me
To telle no wight . of my privite
Nother abedde . nor in nonother place
God shield I shuld . telle it for his grace
A wyf ne shal nat sey . of hir husband
But al honour . as I can vndrestand
Sauf vnto yow . thus moche telle I shal
As help me god . he nys nat worth at al
In no degre . the valu of a flye
But yit me grevith most his nygadye
And wele ye wot . that wymmen naturally
Desiren thynges .vj. as wele as I
They wold that theyr husbondes shuld be
Hardy and wise . Riche and therto fre
And buxum to his wyf . and fressh a bedde
But bi that ilk lord . that for vs bledde
For his honour . my self to array
A Sonday next . I must pay
An hundred frankes . or ellis am I lorn
Yit were me lever . that I were vnborn
Than me were don ashame . or a vilanye
And if myn husbond . eke myght it aspye
I nere but lost . and therfor I pray
Leene me this somme . or ellis must I dey
Daun Iohn I say . lene me this hundred frankes
Parde I nyl nat faile the . my thankes
If that yow list . to do that I yow pray
For a ʆsertayn day . I wil yow pay
And do to yow . what plesaunce and service
That I may do . right as ye wol devise
And but I do . god take on me vengeaunce
As fowle as had Geviloun of Fraunce
This gentil monk . answerd in this manere
Now triewly . myn owne lady dere
I have quod he . on yow so grete arowth
That I yow swere . and plight yow my trowth
That whan yowre husbond . is to flaundres fare
I wil delyủere yow out . of al this care
For I wil brynge yow . an hundred frankes
And with that he caught hir bi the flankes
And hir embraced . and kissed ofte
Goth now yowre wey quod he . stille and softe
And lete vs digne . as soone as ye may
For bi my chilyndre . it is pryme of day
Goth now . and beth as triew as I shal be
Now ellis god forbede . ʆsir quod she
And forth she goth . as Ioly as a pye
And bad the cokes . that they shuld hem hye
So that men myght digne . and that anon
Vp to hir husbond . is this wif gon
And knokkith at his comptoᵘur boldily
Qi la quod he . petir it am I
Quod she . what how longe wil ye fast
How longe tyme . wil ye rekene and cast
Yowre sommes yowre bokes . and yowre thynges
The devil have part . of al suche rekenynges
Ye han I nough parde . of goddis sond
Com doun to day . and lete yowre bagges stonde
Ne be ye nat ashamed . that daun Iohn
Shal fastyng al this day . Elyng gon
What lete vs here masse . and gowe dyne
Wyf quod this man . luytel canstow divyne
The curious busyness that we haue
For of vs chapmen . so god me save
And bi that lord . that clepid is seynt yve
Skarsly amonges . xij . ij . shal thryve
Continuanly lastyng . vntil owre age
We may wele make . chiere and goode visage
And dryve forth the world . as it may be
And ken oure estate in privite
Til we be ded . or ellis that we pley
A pilgremage . or gon out of the wey
And therfor have I . grete necessite
Vpon this qweynt world . to avise me
For eủermore we mote . stande in drede
Of hap and fortune in oure chapmanhede
To Flaundres wil I go . to morwe at day
And com agayn . as soone as eủer I may
For whiche my dere wif . I the beseche
As be to eủery man . buxum and meke
And for to kepe oure goode . be curyous
And honestly . goủerne wele oure hous
Thow hast I nowgh . in eủery man wise
That to a thrifty houshold . shuld suffice
The lakkith none array . ne no vitaile
Of siluer in thy purse . thow mayst nat faile
And with that worde . his comptoᵘur dore he shitte
And doun he goth . no lengger wold he lette
But hastly a masse . ther was I saide
And spedily the tables . were I layde
And to the dyner . fast they hem spedde
And richely this monk the chapman fedde
And after dyn . Daun Iohn sobirly
This chapman toke a part provely
He saide hym thus . cosyn it standith so
That wele I se . to Brugis wol ye go
God and Seynt Austyn . spede yow and guyde
I pray yow cosyn . wisely that ye ride
Goủernyth yow also . of yowre dyete
Temꝑparatly . and namly in this hete
Betwix vs to . nedith no straunge fare
Fare wele cosyn . god shield yow fro care
If any thyng ther be . bi day or be nyght
If it ligge in my power . and my myght
That ye me wil comawde . in any wise
It shalbe don . right as ye wil devise
O thyng er that ye gon . if it may be
I wold pray yow . for to lene me
An hundred frankes . for a wike or twey
For certayn bestis that . I must bey
To store with a place . that is oures
God help me so . I wold it were yowres
I shal nat faile . surely of my day
Nat for a Mˢ. frankes . amyle way
But lete this thyng . be secre I yow pray
For yit to nyght . these bestes must I bey
And fare now wele . myn owne cosyn dere
Gᵃunt mercy of yowre cost . and of yowre chiere
This noble marchaunt . gentilly anon
Answerd and saide . O cosyn Daun Iohn
Now sikerly . this is a smal request
My gold is yowres . whan that yow lest
And nat only my gold . but my chaffare
Take what ye list . god shield yow that ye spare
But othyng as ye knowe it wele I nowgh
Of chapmen . that hir money is theyr plowgh
We may creaunce . whiles we han a name
But goldles for to be . It nys no game
Payeth it agayn . whan it lith in yoᵘur ease
