And of prudence . and hir benyngnite
Oure host sayde . as I am a feythful man
And by the precious corpus . Madryan
I had lever than . a barell ale
That goode lief my wyf had herd this tale
For she nys nothyng . of suche pacience
As was this Melibeus wif . Dame prudence
By goddes bones . have I bette my knaves
She brynggeth me / the grete clubbed staves
And cryeth / sle the dogges eủerichon
And brekith . both bak and boon
And if that any neyghburgh of myne
Wil nat in chirche . to my wif enclyne
Or be so hardy . vnto hir trespace
Whan she comyth hom . she reimyth in my face
And cryeth false coward wreke thy wif
By corpus bones . I wil have thy knyf
And thow shalt have my distaf and go spynne
Fro the day to the nyght thus she wil begynne
Alas she seyth . that eủer I was shape
To wedde a mylke soppe or so grete anape
That wilbe oủerlad . with eủery wight
Thow dorst nat stonde . be thy wyfes right
This is my lyf . but if that I wold fight
And out at the dore . anon I mote me dight
Or ellis I am lost . but if that I
Be like a wielde lyoun . foole hardy
I wote wele she wil do me slee som day
Som neyghburgh . and than go my way
For I am ꝑperilous . with knyf in honde
Albe it that I dare nat . hir withstonde
For she is bigge . in armes bi my feyth
That shal he fynde . that hir myseyth
But lete vs passe oủer . of this matiere
My lord ʆsir monke . he sayth be mery of chiere
For ye shal telle . a tale triewly
Lo Rowchester . stondith here fast by
Ride forth myn owne lord . brekith nat yoᵘur game
But be my trowth . I know nat yoᵘur name
Whether I shal calle yow . my lord daun Iohn
Or daun Thomas . or daun Albon
Of what hous be ye . bi youre fader kynne
I avow to god . thow hast a ful fayre skynne
It is a gentil pasture . ther that thow goost
Thow art nat like . a penaunt or a gost
Vpon my feyth . thow art som officer
Som worthy sexteyn . or som cl Celarer
For be my fadir soule . as to my dome
Thow art a mayster . whan thow art at hom
No pore cloysterer . nor no pore novice
But a goủernour . wily and wise
And therwith al . with brawnes and with bones
A wele faire ꝑpersone . for the nones
I pray to god . yeve hym confusioun
That first the brought . in to religioun
Thow woldest have bien . atrede foule aright
Haddestow as grete leve as thow hast myght
To ꝑperforme al thy lust in engendrure
Thow haddest bygoten . many a creature
Alas why werest thow . so wyde . a cope
God yeve me sorw . and I were pope
Nat only thow . but eủery myghty man
Though he were shore hye vpon the pan
Shuld have a wif . for al this world is lorn
Religioun han take vp al the corn
Of tredyng . and we borel men bien shrympes
Of febil trees . comen wrecched ympes
This makith oure children . bien so sklendre
And fieble that they may nat engendre
This makith . that oure wifes wil assay
Religiouns folke . for they may bettir pay
Of venus payement . than may we
God wote no lusshbornes payen she
But beth nat wroth . my lord though that I play
Ful oft in game . a sooth I have herd say
This worthy monke . toke al in pacience
And sayde I wil do al my diligence
As fer as sownith . vnto honeste
To telle yow a tale . or too . or thre
And if yow list . to herken hiderward
I wil yow say . the lyf of seynt Edward
Or ellis first tragedyes . I wil yow telle
Of whiche I have . anhundred in my selle
Tragedies is . so to telle a certeyn storie
As old bookes maken memorie
Of hem that stoden . in grete prosꝑperite
And is falle out of high degre
In to myserie . and ended wrecchidly
And bien verˢified comonly
Of six feete that men clepen examytron
In prose eke . bien enditen many on
And eke of meter . in many sundry wise
Lo this . ought yow . Inowgh suffice
Now herkenyth . if ye list it for to here
But first I yow beseche . in this matiere
Though I be ordre . telle nat these thyngges
Be it of popes . emꝑperours or kynges
And after theyr age . as men writen fynde
But telle hem . som bifore and som behynde
As it comyth now . to my remembraunce
Have me excused . of myn ignorance
I wil bewaile . in man of tragedie
The harme of hym . that stondith in hye degre
And fellen so . that ther nas no remedie
To brynge hem out . of theyr adủersite
For certeyn whan fortune . list to flee
There may noman . of hir the cours withhold
Lete noman trust . of blynde prosꝑperite
Be ware be this ensample yong and old
¶ At lucifer . though he an angel were
And nat a man . at hym I wil begynne
For yowre fortune . may non angel dere
From high degre . yit fille he for his synne
Doun in to helle . where as he is yit Inne
Of lucifer brightest . of aungels alle
Now artow Sathanas . thow mayst nat twynne
Out in to myserie . in whiche thow art I falle
¶ Loo Adam in the field . of Damascene
With goddis owne fyngre . wrought was he
And nat bi getyng . of mannes sꝑperme vnclene
And welt al paradise . savyng o tree
Had neủer wordely man . so high degre
As Adam hadde til he of his goủernaunce
Was dryven out . of his hygh prosꝑperite
To laboure . and to helle . and to myschaunce
¶ Loo Sampson . whiche was annunciat
By the aungel longe . or his nativite
And was to almyghti god consecrat
And stode in noblesse . whiles he myght se
Was neủer suche another . as was he
To speke of strength . and therto of hardynesse
But to his wifes tolde he his secre
Thurgh whiche he slough hym self for wrecchidnesse
¶ Sampson this noble and myghti champioun
Withouten wepen . save his handis twey
He slough and alto rent . the lyoun
Toward his weddyng . walkyng bi the wey
His false wif . cowde hym so plese and prey
Til she his counseil knewe . and she vntriewe
Vnto his foos . his counseil gan be wrey
And hym forsoke . and toke another newe
¶ An hundred foxes . toke Sampson for Ire
And al hir tailes . he to gyder bonde
And sette the foxis . al on fuyre
For he in eủery taile . had put a bronde
And they brent al the cornes in that londe
And al theyr olyves . and vynes eeke
A thowsand men . he slough eke with his owne honde
And had no wepen . but an asses cheke
¶ Whan they were slayne . so therstid hym that he
Was wele nygh lorn . for whiche he gan to prey
That god wold of his mercy . have som pite
And sende hym drynke . or ellis must he dey
And of this asses cheke . that was so drey
Out of a wang toth . ther sprang anon a welle
Of whiche he drank Inowgh . shortly for to sey
Thus halp hym god . as Iudicum can telle
¶ By verray force . at Gasan on a nyght
Mawgre philistiens . of that citee
The gates of the towne . he hath vp plight
And on his bak . I caryed hem hath he
High on an hille . wher as men myght se
O noble and myghty . Sampson lief and deere
Ne haddestow tolde . to wymmen thy secre
In althis world ne had be thy pere
¶ This Sampson neủer syther . drank nor wyne
Nor on his hede . rasoᵘur none ne shere
Bi the precepte of the messangier devyne
For al his strength was in his here
And fully twenty . yere bi yere
He had of Israel . the goủernaunce
But soone after wept . he many a teere
For wymmen brought hym . vnto myschaunce
¶ Vnto his lemman . Dalida he told
That in his heres . al his strength lay
And falsely to his foomen . she hym sold
And slepyng in his barme . vpon a day
She made to clippe . or shere his here away
And made his foomen al his craft espyen
And whan they hym fonde in suche array
They bond hym fast . and put out his yen
¶ But or his here . were clypped or I shave
Ther was no bond . that myght hym bynde
But now is he in prison . put in a kave
Where as they made hym . at the querne grynde
O noble Sampson strengest of man kynde
O whilom Iuge . in glorie and richesse
Now maistow wepe . with thyn Ien blynde
Sithen thow art I falle . in to wrecchidnesse
¶ Thend of these caytifs . was I shal say
His foomen made a fest . vpon a day
And made hym as her foole . bifore hem play
And this was a temple of grete array
But at the last . he made a foule affray
For he two postis shooke . and made hem falle
And doun fel temple . and al there it lay
And slough hym self . and eke his foomen alle
¶ This is thende . the princis eủerychon
And eke a thowsand bodyes . were there slayn
With fallyng of the grete temple of ston
Of Sampson wil I nomore sayn
Beware of this ensample old and playn
That noman telle his counsail to theyr wifes
Of suche thynge . as they wolde have secre fayn
If that it towche . theyr lymmes or theyr lyves
¶ Of hercules . the soủerayne conquerour
Signed his werkes hend . and hye renoun
For in his tyme . of strength he bare the floure
He slough and bi raft . the skynne from the lyoun
He of seynt awres . leyd the bost adoun
He appies slough . the cruel bridde felle
The golden apples . he biraft the dragoun
He drew out Cerberoys . the hounde of helle
¶ He slough the cruel tyraunt Buserous
And made his hors . to frete hym flessh and boon
He sh slough the verray ʆserpent venymous
Of achilles two hornes . brak he oon
And he slough Cacus . in a cave of ston
He sh slough the Geaunt . Andteus the strong
He slough the grisly bore . and that anon
And bare his hede . vpon his spere long
¶ Was neủer wight sythen the world began
That slough so many monstrous as did he
Thurghout this wyde world his name ran
What for his strength and his bounte
And to eủery Realme . went he for to se
He was so strange . that noman myght hym lette
And at the worldes . as sayth Trophee
In stide of boundes . he a piler sette
¶ A lemman had this noble champioun
That hight Dyainyre . as fressh as may
And as the clerkis . maken mencioun
She hath hym sent . a shert fressh and gay
Allas his shert and wellaway
Envenymed was . subtily with all
Or that he had werid it . half a day
It made his flessh . from his bones fall
¶ But natheles som clerkis hir excusen
By oon that hight . Nessus that it maked
Be as be may . I wil hir nat accusen
But on his bak . this shert he wered al naked
Til that his flessh was for the venym blaked
And whan he saugh . nonother remedy
In hote coles . he hath hym self raked
For with no venyme . deyned hym to dy
¶ Thus starf this worthy myghti hercules
Loo who may trust . on fortune any throwe
For hym that folwith . al this world of pres
Or he be ware . is oft I leyd ful lowe
Ful wise is he . that hym self can knowe
Be ware for whanne . that fortune lust to glose
Than waytith she . hir man doun to throwe
Be suche awey . as he wold lest suppose
¶ The myghty throne . the precious tresor
The glorious sceptre . and Royal mageste
That had the kyng Nabugodonosor
With tonge vnneth . may discryved be
He twyes wan . Ierlm the citee
The vessell of the temple with hym ladde
At Babiloyne . was his soủerayne see
In whiche his glorie . and his delite he hadde
¶ The fairest chieldren . of the bloode Royall
Of Ierlm . he dide do gelde anon
And made eche of hem . to be his cherl
Amonges alother . Danyel was oon
That was the wisest chield of eủerychon
For he the dreames . of the kyng expowned
Where as in Caldey . clerk was ther noon
That wist to what fyne . his dreames sowned
¶ This prowde kyng lete make astature of goold
Sixti cubites longe . and seven in breede
To whiche Image . both yonge and old
Comavdid he to loute . and have in drede
For in a fourneys . ful of flawmes reede
He shuld be brent . that wold nat obeye
But neủer wold assent . vnto that dede
Danyel . ne his yonge felawes twey
¶ The kyng was prowde . passyng his degre
He wende god that sit in mageste
Had nat be so grete a lord as he
But sodeinly he lost his dignite
And like a best . hym semed for to be
And ete hay as anoxe . and lay theroute
In Reyne with wield bestis walked he
Til certeyne tyme . was comen aboute
¶ And like an egles fethers . was his heres
His nayles like . briddes clawes were
God releved hym . a certeyn yeeris
And yave hym witte . and than with many a tere
He thanked god . and eủer his lyf in feere
Was he to don amys . or more to trespace
And or that tyme he leyde was on his beere
He knew wele that god was ful of myght and grace
¶ His sone whiche that hight Balthazar
That hield the Reigne . after his fadir day
He bi his fader . cowde nat be war
For prowde he was . of hert and of array
And eke an ydolastre . was he ay
His hye estate . assured hym in pride
But fortune cast hym doun . and ther he lay
And sodeinly his reigne . gan devide
¶ A feste he made . vnto his lordis alle
Vpon atyme . he made hem blith to be
And than his officers . gan he calle
Com bryngeth forth . the vesselꝭes quod he
Whiche that my fadir . in his prosꝑperite
Oute of the temple . of Ierlm bi raft
And to oure high goddis thanke we
Of honoᵘur that oure elders with vs laft
¶ His wif his lordes . and his concubynes
Ay drynken whiles . theyr appetit last
Out of these noble vessels . sundry wynes
And on a walle . he his Ien cast
And sawe an hande armeles write ful fast
For fere of whiche he quaked and sighed sore
This hand hath Balthasar . made so sore agast
Wrote Mane Techel Phares and nomore
¶ In althat land . Magician was there none
That cowde expowne . what this lre ment
But Daniel expounde it anone
Glorie and honour . Reigne . tresour . and rent
And he was prowde . and nothyng ne dradde
Therfor god grete wreche vpon hym sent
And hym beraft . the Reigne that he hadde
¶ He was cast out . of mannes companye
With Asses was his habitacioun
And ete hay as a beste . in wete and drye
Til that he knowe . bi grace and be resoun
That god of heven . hath domynacioun
Oủer eủery Reigne . and eủery creature
And thanne had god . of hym compassioun
And hym restored . his reigne in his figure
¶ Eke thow that art his sone and prowde also
And knowest al these thynges privily
And Rebel to god . and art his foo
Thow drankkest eke . of his vesselꝭes boldily
Thy wyf eke . and thy wenchis synfully
Drank of the same vessels . sundry wynes
And heryed false goddis cursidly
Therfor to the . shapen grete peyne is
¶ This hand was sent from god . that on the wal
Wrote Mane techel phares trustith me
Thy Reigne is doo thow weldest it not at al
Devided is thy Reigne . and it shalbe
To Medes and to ꝑperces . yoven quod he
And thilk same nyght . the kyng was slawe
And Darious . occupieth his degre
Though he therto . had neyther right ne lawe
¶ Lordynges here bi ensample may ye take
How that in lordship . is no sikernesse
For whanne fortune . wil a man forsake
He berith a way his Reigne and his Richesse
And eke his friendis . both more and lesse
And whan a man hath friendis thurgh fortune
Myshap wil make hym . enemyes I gesse
This prouerbe is fulsoth . and ful comvne
¶ Cenobia of Palamere . the qwene
As writen ꝑpersians . of hir noblesse
So worthy was . in armes and so kene
That no wight . passed hir in hardynesse
Ne in lignage . ne in other gentillesse
Of the kynges blode of perce she is discended
I sey she had nat most fayrnesse
But of hir shappe . she myght nat bien amended
¶ From childhod . I fynde that she fledde
Office of womman . and into woode she went
And many a wielde hertis bloode she shedde
With arowes brode . that she to hem sent
She was so swyft . that she anon hent
And whan she was elder . she wold kille
Lyons and libardes . and beres alto rent
And in hir armes . welde hem at hir wille
¶ She durst wielde beres . dennes seeke
And renne in the mounteyns al the nyght
And slepe vnder a bussh . she cowde eeke
Wrastelen . bi verray force and myght
With any man . were he neủer so wight
Ther myght nothyng . in hir armes stonde
She kept hir mayden hede . from eủery wight
To noman deyned she . to be bonde
¶ But at the last hir friendis . han hir maryed
To Ovenak . a prince of that citee
Al were it so . that she hym long taryed
And ye shal vnderstonde . hov that he
Had suche fantasies . as had she
But natheles . whan they were knett in feere
They liueden in Ioye . and in felicite
For eche of hem had other . lief and deere
¶ Save oothyng that she nolde neủer assent
By no wey that he shuld be hir lye
But oones . for it was hir playn entent
To have a chield the world to multiplie
And also soone . as she myght espye
That she was nat with chield with that deede
Than wold she suffre hym . do his fantasie
Eft soone . and but oones out of drede
And if she were with chield at thilke cast
Nomore shuld he pley that ilke game
Til fourty dayes were past
Thanne wold she suffre hym do the same
Al were this Ovenak . wielde or tame
He gate nomore of hir but thus she sayde
It was the wifes . lechery and shame
In other caas if men with hem playde
¶ Two sones . bi this Odenak had she
The whiche she kept in vertu and lettrure
But now in to oure tale torne we
I say that worshipful creature
And wise therwith . and large with mesure
So penyble in the werre and curteys eke
Nomore labour . myght in werre endure
Was none though al this world shuld seeke
¶ Hir riche array . myght nat betold
Aswele in vessel . as in clothyng
She was clad al in perre in goold
And eke she laft nat . for none huntyng
To have of sundry tonges . folk knowyng
Whan that she leyser had . and for to entende
To lierne bookes . was al hir likyng
How she in vertu . myght al hir lyf dispende
¶ And shortly of this storye . for to entete
As doughty was hir husbond as was she
That they conquered . many reignes grete
In the orient . with many a faire cite
Apꝑpertynent . vnto the mageste
Of Rome and with stronge hand . hield hem fast
Ne neủer her foomen . doon hem flee
As longe as Onedakkes dayes last
¶ Her batailles . he so left hem for to rede
Ageyn soper . the kyng and other moo
And how that al the processe . fil in dede
Whi she conquere . and what title had therto
And after of hir myschief . and of hir woo
How she was bisieged . and I take
Lete hym vnto my Maister Petrak goo
That writeth I nowgh of this I vndretake
¶ Whan Odenak was ded . she myghtili
The reignes hield . and with hir propre hond
Ageyn hir foos . she faught triewly
That ther nas kyng . ne prince in that lond
Thatt he nas gladde . if he that grace fonde
That she wold vpon his lond werrey
With hir they made . alliaunce bi bond
To bien in pees . and lete hir ride and pley
¶ The Emꝑperoue of Rome . Claudius
Ne hym before . the romayn Galidus
Ne durst neủer . be so corageous
Ne non Ermy . ne non Arabien
That durst oone . befor hir be seen
Withynne the field . that durst with hir fight
Or with hir meyn . put hem to flight
¶ In kynges habite . went hir soones too
As heyres . of hir . reignes alle
And hermanno . and Tintalite both twoo
Her names were . a ꝑpercians hem calle
But ay hath fortune . in hir hony galle
This myghti qwene . may no while endure
Fortune out of hir reigne made hir falle
To wrecchidnes . and mys auenture
¶ Aurelious whan that the goủernaunce
Of Rome com in to his hondis tweye
He shoope vpon this qwene to do vengeaunce
And with his legioıı̄uns . he toke his wey
Toward Cenobie . shortly for to sey
He made hir flee . at at the last hir hent
And fettred hir . and hir chieldren twey
And wan the londe . and home to Rome went
¶ Amonge other tynges that he wanne
His chare that wrough was . with gold and perrey
This grete Romayn . this Aurelian
Hath with hym ladde . for that men shuld sey
Biforn his Tryumphe . walkith she
With gilt cheynes . on hir nekke hongyng
Crowned she was . and after hir degree
And ful of perrey . charged was hir clothyng
¶ Alas fortune . she that whilom was
Dredeful to kynges . and to emꝑperours
Now gawrith al the peple . on hir allas
And she that helmed was . in stark stowres
And bifore wan townes . stronge and towres
Shal on hir heede . now a vttremyte
And she that bare the sceptre ful of floures
Shal bere a distaf . he cast for to quyte
¶ O noble o worthy . petre glorie of spayne
Whom fortune hielde . so high in mageste
Wele ought men thi pitous deth compleyne
Thy bastard brother . made the to flee
And after that a siege by subtilite
Thow were betrayed . and h lad to his tent
Wher as he with his owne hand slough the
Succedyng in thy Reigne . and in thy rent
¶ The field of snowe . with the Egle blac therinne
Caught with the lyme rodde colours of the gleede
He brewed this cursidnesse . and al this synne
The wycked nest . was werker of this nede
Nat Charles Olyver . that ay toke goode heede
Of trowth and honoᵘur . but Armorek
Glembloun Olyver . corrupt for mede
Brought this worthy kyng in suche a brek
¶ Worthy petir . kyng of Cypre also
That Alisaundre wan bi hy maystrie
Ful many anhethen . wroughtest thow ful woo
Of whiche thyn owne liegis had envye
And for nothyng . but for thy cheualrie
They in thy bedde . han slayne the bi the morow
Thus can fortune goủerne and guye
And out of Ioye . brynge in to sorwe
¶ Of Melane grete . Barnabe viscounte
God of delite . and scoure of lombardye
Why shuld I nat . thi fortune accompte
Sithen in estate . thow clomben were so hye
Thy brother sone . that was thy double allye
For he thy nevew was . and thi son in lawe
Withynne his prison . made the to dye
But why ne how wote I . that thow were slawe
¶ Of hugh Erle of pyse . the langoure
Ther may nothyng telle for pitee
But litel fro pyse . there stant a towre
In whiche towre . in prisoun put was he
And with hym bien . his litel chieldren thre
The eldest scarsly . fyve yeere was of age
Allas fortune . It was grete cruelte
Suche briddes to putte . in so narow cage
¶ Dampned he was . in that prison to dye
For Roger whiche . that bisshop was of pise
And on hym a false suggestioun to espye
Thurgh whiche the peple . gan on hym arise
And putten hym in prisoun . in suche a wise
As ye han herde . and mete and drynk hadde
So smal . that it vnneth may suffice
And ther withal . It was ful poore and badde
¶ On a day bifel . that in that oure
Whan that this was . wont to be brought
The gailer shit the doores of the towre
He herde it wele . but he sawe it nought
And in his hert . anon ther fil a thought
That for hunger . they wolde don hym deye
Allas quod he . allas that I was wrought
Therwith the teeris falle from his eye
¶ His yonge sone . thre yeere was of age
Vnto his fadir sayde . why do ye wepe
Whanne wil the gayler . bryng oure potage
Is ther no morsel brede . that ye doo kepe
I am so hungry . that I may nat sleepe
Now wold god I myght slepen ever
Than shuld none hunger . in my wombe crepe
Ther nys nothyng save brede . that me were lever
¶ Thus fro day to day . the chield began to crye
Til in his fadir barme . adoun it lay
And sayde fadir . fare wele I mote dye
And kist his fader . and deyd the same day
And whan his woful fader . dide hym say
For wo his armes tho . he gan to byte
And sayde fortune allas and welaway
Thi false wiles my woo . I may wite
¶ His chieldren wend . that it for hungre was
That he his armes gnew . and nat for woo
And saide fadir do nat so allas
But rather ete the flessh . vpon vs too
Oure flessh thow yavest vs . take oure flessh vs fro
And ete Inowgh . right thus to hym they sayde
And after that withyn a day or twoo
Thei leyde hem doun . in his lappe and deyde
¶ Hym self dispeyred . eke for hunger starf
Thus endid is the myghti Erle of pyse
From hye estate . fortune from hym carf
Of this tragedye . it ought Inowgh suffice
Who so wil here . in a lengger wise
Redith the grete pooete if Italle
That hight Daunte . for he can devise
From poynt to poynt . nat o word wil he faile
¶ Although that nero . were as vicious
As any fiende that lith ful lowe adoun
Yitte he as tellith . vs swotheneus
This wield world . hadde in subieccioun
Both Est and West . and Septemptrioun
Of Rubies . Saphires . and of perlis white
Were al his clothis . browded vp and doun
For he in gemmys . gretely gan delite
¶ More delicat . more pompous of array
More prowde was neủer . Emꝑperour than he
That ilke . that he had wered a day
After that tyme . he nolde it neủer se
Nettes of golden threde . had he grete plente
To fysshen in Tymbre whan hym list to play
His lustes were as lawe . in his degree
For fortune as his friende . wolde hym obey
¶ He Rome brent . for his delicasye
The Senatours he slough . vpon a day
To here whether men wolde . wepe or crye
And slough his brother . and bi his suster laye
His moder made he . in pitous array
For he hir wombe slitte . for to beholde
Where he conceyved was . so welaway
That he so litel . of his moder tolde
¶ No tere out of his Ien . for that sight
Ne cam but saide . a faire womman was she
Grete wondre is . that he cowde or myght
Be domes man . of hir deede beaute
Thy wyne to bryng . comavdid he
He drenke anon . and nonother was he made
Whanne myght is Ioyned . vnto cruelte
Allas to deepe . wil the venyme wade
In yowth a maister . had this emꝑperoure
To teche hym lettrure . and curiosite
For of moralite . he was the floure
As in his tyme . but if bookes lye
And whiles his mayster . had of hym maistrie
He made hym so konnyng . and so souple
That long tyme it was . or tirannye
Or any vicl vice of hym . durst vncouple
¶ This Seneca . of whiche I devise
Bicause Nero . had of hym suche dreede
For he from vices . wold hym chastice
Discretely as bi worde . and nat by drede
Sir wold he sayn . anemꝑperour mote nede
Be vertuous . and hate tyrannye
For whiche in a bath . he made hym blede
On both his armes . til he must dye
¶ This Nero had eke . of a customaunce
In thought ayeinst his . maister for to rise
Whiche hym thought afterward . a grete grevaunce
Therfor he made hym . dye in this wise
But natheles . this senek the wise
Chese a bath . to dye in this manere
Rather than any . other turmentise
And thus hath Nero . slayn his maister dere
¶ Now fille it so . that fortune list no lengger
The high pride of Nero . to cherice
For though that he were strong . yit was she strengger
She thought thus . by god I am to nyce
To sette a man . that is fulfilled with vice
In hye degre . and emꝑperour hym calle
By god out of his seete . I wil hym trice
Whanne he lest weneth . sounest shal he falle
¶ The peple roos vpon hym . on a nyght
For his defaute . and whan he it aspyed
Out of his doores . anon he hath hym dight
Allon . and there he wend had bien allyed
He knokkyd fast . and ay the more he cryed
The faster shit they . the doores alle
Thoo wist he wele . he had hym self mysgiued
And wenst his wey . no lengger wold he calle
¶ The peple cryed . and rombled vp and doun
That with his eris . herd he what they sayde
Where is this false traitour . this nerou
For fere almost . out of his wit he brayde
And to his goddis pitously he saide
For socour but it myght nat betide
For drede of this . hym thought he diede
And ran in to a gardyn . hym self to hide
¶ And in this gardyn fonde he cherlis tweye
That saten bi a fuyre . ful grete and rede
And to these cherlis twey . he gan to prey
To slen hym . and gyrd of his hede
That to his body . whan that he were dede
Were no dispit I doo . for his defame
Hym self he slough . he cowde no better rede
Of whiche fortune lough and made a game
¶ Was neủer captayne . vnder a kyng
That Reignes more . put in subieccioun
Ne strengger was . in the fielde of althyng
As in his tyme . ne gretter of Renoun
Ne more pompous . in hie presumpcioun
Than Olifern whiche ay fortune ay kist
So licorously . and lad hym vp and doun
Til that his heede was of . or that he wist
¶ Nat oonly that this world had of hym awe
For lovyng of Riches . and of liberte
But he made eủery man . reneye his lawe
Nabugonosor was lord . saide he
Nonother god . shuld honoured be
Agenst his hest . no wight durst trespace
Save on Bethulia . a stronge citee
Where Eliachym a prist . was of that place
¶ But take kepe of the deth of Oliferne
Amyddes . his host . he dronk lay anyght
Withynne his tent . large as is a berne
And yit for al his pompe . and al his myght
Iudith a womman . as he lay vpright
Sleepyng his hede of smote . and fro his tent
Ful pⁱrivily she stale . from eủery wight
And with his hede . vnto hir towne she went
¶ What nedith it . of Antiochus
To telle his hye . and Royal mageste
His high pride . his werkes venymous
For suche another . was neủer none but he
Redith what he was . in Machabee
And redith the prowde wordis that he saide
And why he felle . from his prosꝑperite
And in an hille . hov wrecchidly he deyde
¶ Fortune had hym . enhaunsid soo in pride
That verrily he went . he myght atteyne
Vnto the sterres . vpon eủery side
And in a balaunce . to way the mountaygne
And alle the floodis . of the see restreyne
And goddis peple . hadde he most in haate
Hym wolde he slee . in torment and in peyne
Wenyng that god myght . nat his pride abate
¶ And for that Nychanor . and Tymothe
With Iewes were . venquysshed myghtily
Vnto the Iewis . suche anhate had he
That he had greved his chare . ful hastily
And swore and saide . ful spitously
To Ierlm wold he eft sone
To wreke his Ire . on it ful cruelly
But of his pʳpos . he was i let ful sone
¶ God of his manace . hym so sore smote
With invisible woundes . ay vncurable
That in his guttes . carf so aboute
That his peynes were Importable
And certeinly the wreche . was resonable
For many amannes guttis dide he peyne
But from his purpos cursid and dampnable
For al his smert . he nold hym restreyne
¶ But bad anon . apparaile his host
And sodaynly or he was of it ware
God daunted al his pride . and al his bost
For he so sore felle out of his chare
That hurt hys lymmes . and his skynne to tare
So that he ne myght . go ne ride
But in a chayer . men about hym bare
Al for brused . both bak and side
¶ The wrecche of god . hym smote so cruelly
That in his body . wikked wormes crept
And therwith al . he stonk so horrribly
That none of al his meyne that hym kept
Whether that he wooke . or ellis slept
Ne myght nat the stynke of hym endure
In this myschief . he wailed eke and wept
And knewe god his lord . to fore any creature
¶ To al his host . and to hym self also
Ful fulsom was . the stynk of his coreyne
Noman myght hym . bere to and fro
And in his stynke . and in his horrible peyne
He starf ful wrecchidly . in a mountayne
Thus hath this Robboᵘur and this homycide
That many a man made . to wepe and pleyne
Suche gwerdou . as bilongeth vnto pride
¶ The storye of Alisaunder . is so comvne
That eủery wight that hath discrecioun
Hath herd somwhat . or alle of his fortune
This wyde world . as in conclusioun
He wanne bi strength and for his hye renoun
They were glad for pees . vnto hym sende
The pride of man . and best he leyde adoun
Where so he cam . vnto the worldis ende
¶ Comparisoun myght neủer be maked
Betwene hym . and another conquerour
For althis worlde . for drede of hym hath quaked
He was of knyghthod . and of fredom floure
Fortune hym made . heyre of his honoure
Save wyne and wymmen . nomyght aswage
His high entent in armes and laboure
So was he ful . of lovyng corage
¶ What pris were it to hym . though I yow told
Of Darius and anhundred thousand moo
Of kynges princes . and erles bold
Whiche he conquered . and brought vnto woo
I sey as ferre . as men may ride and goo
The world was his . what I shuld more devise
For though I write . and tolde yow eủermoo
Of his knyghthode . it myght nat suffice
¶ Twelue yeere he Reigned . as seyth Machabee
Philippus sone . of Macedonye was he
That first was kyng . of Grece that contre
O worthy gentil Alisaundre . allas quod he
That eủer shuld falle . in suche degre
Empoysened . of thi folk thow were
Thy fortune in to an aas . hath turned the
And for the she wepeth neủer ateere
¶ Who shal yeve me teeris . men to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse . and of fraunchise
That al the world weldid . in his demeyne
And yit hym thought . it myght nat suffice
So ful was his corage . of hye emprise
Allas he shal . me helpe to endite
False fortune . and poysou to dispise
The whiche two . of althis woo I wite
¶ By wisdam manhede . and bi laboure
For humblehed . and Ryal mageste
Vp roos Iulius . the noble conquerour
That al the occident . bi lond and bi see
By strength of hond . or ellis bi tretee
And vnto Rome . made hem tributarye
And sythens of Rome . this emꝑperour was he
Til that fortune . wax his adủersarie
¶ O myghty Cesar . that in Thesalye
Agenst Pompeyus . fadir thyn in lawe
That of the Orient . had al the cheualrye
As ferre as the day . begynneth to dawe
Thurgh thy knyghthode . hastow take and slawe
Saue a fewe folke . that with pompeyus fledde
Thank fortune . that the so wele spedde
¶ But now a litel while . I wil be waile
This Pompeyus . this noble goủernoᵘur
Of Rome whiche that flye . at this bataile
I say oon of his men . a false traytoᵘur
His hede of smote . to wynne hym fauoᵘur
Of Iulius . and hym the hede brought
Allas Pompeyus . of the orient conquerour
That fortune vnto suche a fyne the brought
¶ To Rome ageyn . Repairith Iulius
With his Tryumphe . laureat ful hye
But on a tyme Brutus Casseus
That eủer had . of his estate envie
Ful privily had made . conspiracie
Agenst this Iulius . in sundry wise
And cast that place . where he shul dye
With Bodkyns . as I shal yow devise
¶ This Iulius . to the Capitaile went
Vpon a day . as he was wont to gon
And in the Capitoile . anon hym hent
s false Brutus . and his false soon
Han styked hym . wyth Bydokyns anon
With many a wounde . and thus they lete hym lye
But neủer gront he . at no strok but oon
Or ellis at two . but yif his storye lye
¶ So manly was Iulius . of herte
And so wele loved . estately honeste
And though his dedly woundes so sore smerte
His mantel oủer his hippes . casted he
For noman shuld . se his privite
And as he lay . dyeng in a traunce
And wist verraily . that ded was he
Of honeste . yit had he remembraunce
¶ Lucane to this storie . I recomende
And to Sweton . and to Valerius also
That of this storie . writeth werde and ende
How that these conquerours twoo
Fortune was ther friend . and after ther foo
Noman trust . vpou hir fauour longe
But have hir in wayte eủermo
Witnesse of althese conquerours stronge
¶ This riche Cresus . whilom kynge of lyde
Of whiche Cresus . Sequius sore hym dradde
Yit was he caught . among al his pride
And to be brent . to the fuyre hym ladde
But suche a rayne . downe from the walken shadde
That slough the fuyre . and made hym to escape
But to be ware . yit no grace he hadde
Til fortune on the galwes . made the gape
¶ Whanne he escaped was . cowde he nat stynt
For to begynne . a newe reigne ageyne
He wend wele . for that fortune hym sent
Suche happe . that he escapid thurgh the Reyne
That of his foos . he myght nat be slayne
And suche a sweuen . vpon anyght he mette
Of whiche he was so prowde . and eke fayne
That he in vengeaunce . al his hert sette
¶ Vpon a tree he was . as hym thought
There Iupiter hym wisshe . both halse and side
And phebus eke . a faire towaile hym brought
To drye hym with . and therfor was his pride
And to his doughter . that stoode hym be side
Whiche that he knewe . in hye sentence habounde
He bad hir telle . what it sygnified
And she his dreame . thus expounde
¶ The tree quod she . the galowes is to meane
And Iupiter betokenyth . snowe and Rayne
And phebus with his towaile . so cliere and cleen
Tho bien the sonnes . for to sayne
Thow shalt anhonged be . fadir certayne
Rayne shal the wassh . and the sonne shal the drye
Thus warned she hym . ful plat and ful playne
His doughter that callis was Phadpye
¶ An honged was Cresus . the prowde kynge
His Royal throne . myght hym nat availe
Tragedyes is . nonother maner thynge
Ne can in synnyng . crie ne be waile
But that fortune . alwey wil assaile
With vnware stroke . the reynes that bien prowde
For whan men trusten hir . than wol she faile
And coủere hir bright fase . with a derk clowde

l.hi:
Here endith the tale
of þe monke And be //
gynnyth þe ꝓprologe of
the none prest /

div.l: HO quod the knyght . no more of this
And more . for litel hevynesse
Is right Inough . to many folk I gesse
I sey for me . it is a grete disease
Where as men han bien . in grete welth and ease
To here of theyr sodayn falle allas
And the contrary is Ioy . and grete solas
And whan a man hath bien in poủer estate
And clymbith vp . and wexith fortunate xxij
And ther abydith . in prosperite
Swiche thyng is gladsom . as it thynkyth me
And of swiche thynges . were goodely for to telle
Ya quod oure host . be seynt poulis belle
Ye say right soth . this monk he clappid lowde
He spak how fortune . was coủered with a clowde
I not neủer what . and als of a tregedye
Right now ye herd . and parde no remedye
Is it for to be wailen . and compleyn
That . that is don . and als it is a peyn
As ye have sayd . to here of hevynesse
Sir monke nomore of this . so god yow blisse
Yowre tale anoyeth . al this company
Swiche thyng is nat worth . a boterflye
Yowre tales don vs . no disport ne game
Wherfor ʆsir monke . dan piers be yowre name
I pray yow hertly telle vs somwhat ellis
For sikerly ne were . clynkkyng of youre bellis
Thatt on youre brydel hanges . on eủery syde
By heven kyng that for vs al dide
I shuld afalle . adoun for sleepe
Although the slough . had be neủer so deepe
Than had yowre tale . bien tolde in vayne
For certainly . as these clerkis sayne
Where as a man . may have non audience
Nought helpith . to telle his sentence
And wele I wote . the substaunce is in me
Of any thyng . that shal reported be
Sir say somwhat . of huntyng I yow pray
Nay quod the monk . I have no lust to play
But lete another telle . as I have tolde
Than spak oure host . with rude speche and bolde
And sayde to the nonnes prist anoon
Come nere ʆsir prist . com neere ʆsir Iohn xxij
Telle vs suche athynge . as may oure hertis glade
Be mery though ye ride . vpon Iade
And though thy hors . be fowlo and leene
If he wil ʆserve the . rekke thow nat a beene
Looke that thyn hert . be mery eủermo
Yis host quod he somote I goo
But I be myrry . I wis I wil be blamed
And right anon . he hath his tale attamed
And thus he sayde . to vs eủerichon
This swete prist . this goode man ʆsir Iohn

l.hi:
And begynnyth the tale
of the nones prest

div.l: A pore widowe . dwellid in a narow cotage
And was somdel . stopen in age
Besides a grove . dwellyng in a dale
This widowe of whiche . I telle yow my tale
Sithen that day . that she was last a wif
In pacience ladde . a symple lyf
For litel was hir catel . and hir rent
Of husbondrye of suche . as god hir sent
She fonde hir self . and hir doughters two
Thre large sowes had she . and nomo
Ful sotty was hir boure . and eke hir halle
Thre kyen and eke a shepe that hight malle
In whiche she ete . many a sclender mele
Of poynaunt sawce . hir nedis neủer adele
No deynte morsel . passed hir throte
Hir dyete was accordyng . to hir cote
Repleccioun . made hir neủer sike
A temꝑparat diete . was al hir phisike
And excercise . and hertis suffisaunce
The gowte letted hir nothyng to daunce
Ne poplexie . shent nat hir hede
She dranke no wyne . neyther white ne rede
Hir boorde was ʆserved . most with whit and blac
Milke and whete brede . in whiche she fonde no lak
Seynt Bacon . and somtyme an ey or twey
For she was as it were . a man dey xxij
A gardyn she had . enclosid al aboute
With stykes drye . and diched withoute
In whiche she hadde . that hight chauntcliere
In al the land of krowyng . nas nat his piere
His voyce was myrrier . than the mery orgon
On massedayes . that in the chirche gon
Ful sykerer was the crowyng . in his logge
Than is a clokke . or an abbey orlogge
By nature he knewe . eche ascencioun
And equinoxial . of that town
F or whan degres . xv . were ascendid
Thanne krow he . it myght nat be amendid
His combe was redder . than the fyne corall
And batailled . as it were a castel wall
His bill was blak . and as the geete it shone
Like Ivorye . were his leggis and his tooıı̄un
His nailes whitter . than the lily floure
And burnysshed gold . like was his coloure
This gentil cok . had in his goủernaunce
Vij . hennys . for to do hym plesaunce
And wondre like to hym . as of colours
Whiche weren his sustres . and his ꝑparamours
Of whiche the fairest hewed in hir throote
Was callid faire damysel ꝑpartilote
He fethred hir . an hundred tyme of the day
And she hym pleasith . al that eủer she may
Curteys she was . discrete and debonayre
And companable . and bare hir self so faire
Sithen that day . that she was . of seuenyght old
That triewly she hath the hert in hold
Of chauntcliere . loken in eủery lith
He loved hir so . that wele was hym therwith
But suche aIoye as it was . to here hym syng
Whanne the bright sonne . began to spryng
In swete accord . my lief is fare in lond xxij
For thilke tyme . as I vndirstande
Bestis and briddis . cowde speke and synge
And as for to telle . of the Infortunyng
It so bifel . that in a dawenyng
Chauntclier fil . in a sweuenyng
As he sat among his wifes alle
Vpon his ꝑperke . that was in the halle
And next hym sat . this fayre ꝑpartilote
This chauntclier . gan grone in his throte
As a man that in his dreame . is drecchid sore
And whan that ꝑpartelot . thus herd hym rore
She was agast . and sayde hert deere
What ayles yow to grone . in this manere
Ye are a verray sleper . fy for shame
And he answerd and sayde . thus madame
I pray yow that ye take it . in no grief
By god me mette . that I was in suche myschief
Right now . that yit myn hert . is sore a fright
Now god quod he . my swevon recche a right
And kepe my body . out of foule prisoun
Me mette that I romed vp and doun
Withyn oure yerde . where as I sawe abest
Was like anhounde . wold han made arest
Vpon my body . and wold have had me ded
His colowre . was be twixt white and rede
And tipped was his taile . and both his eris
With blak vnlike . the remenᵃnt of his heris
His snowte smal . with glowyng Ien tweyne twey
Yit for his looke . for feere almost I dey
This causith me . my gronyng doutles
A way quod she . fy on yow hertles
Allas quod she . for by that god above
Now have ye lost . myn hert and my love
I can nat love . a coward be my feyth
For certis what so eủer . wymmen seyth xxij
They wold desire . if it myght be
To have husbondis . hardy riche and free
And syker . no nygard . ne no foole
Ne hym that is agast . of eủery toole
Ne non avauntoᵘur . bi god above
How durst ye say . for shame vnto yowre love
That any thyng myght make yow aferd
Have ye no mannes hert and have aberd
Allas and can ye be aferd of sweuenes
Nothyng god wote . but vanite in sweuene is
Sweuenes bien engendred of replecciouns
And oft of synne . and of complexiouns
Whan humoᵘurs bien habundaunt in a wight
Certis this dreame . whiche ye sawe to nyght
Comyth of the grete suꝑperfluite
Of yowre rede coloure ꝑparde
The whiche causith folke . to dreame theyr dreames
Ofarowes and of fuyre . with rede leames
Of rede bestis . that wil hym bite
Of contek and of whelpis grete and lite
Right as the humoᵘur and of malencolye
Causith many aman . in sleepe to crye
For feere of beris . and of bulles blake
Or ellis blac devils . wil hem take
Of othe humoᵘurs . cowde I telle also
That werkith many aman in sleepe . moche woo
But I wil passe . as lightly as I can
Lo Caton whiche that was so wise a man
Sayde he nat thus . ne do no force of dreames
Now ʆsir quod she . whan we flee from the beames
For goddis love . take som laxatif
Vp perel of my soule . and of my lyf
I counsaile yow the best . I wil nat lye xxij
That both of Coler . and malencolye
Ye purge yow . and for ye shall nat tarye
Though in this towne . be no poticarie
I shal my self . tho herbis seeke to yow
That shalbe yowre hele and yowre prow
And in the gardyn . two herbis shal I fynde
The whiche of theyr . propirte be kynde
To purge yow beneth and above
Forgete nat this . for cristes owne love
Ye are ful coleryk . of complexioun
Were the sonne . in his ascencioun
Ne fynde yow replete . of humoᵘurs hoote
And if it do . I dare wele lay a grote
That ye shul have . a feuere tercian
Or an agu . that may be youre ban
A day or two . ye may digestives
To comfort yow . of yowre myschieves
Of lauriol Centaur . and of fumytere
Orellis henbane . that growith there
Of Catapuce . or of gates buries
Of herbe Ive growyng . wher merye is
Pike hem vp as they growe . and ete hem Inne
Beth merye husbond . for youre fadir kynne
Dredith no dreame . I dar say nomore
Madame quod he gramercy of youre lore
But neủertheles as touchyng Dan Caton
That hath of wisdam . suche a grete Renoun
By god men may . in olde bookes rede
Dyủers storyes . so god me speede
Of manyoon . of more auctorite
Than eủer Caton was somote I the
That al Reủers sayth . of this sentence
And hath wele founde . bi exꝑperience
That dreames beth significaciouns xxij
As wele of Ioye . as tribulaciouns
That folke enduren . in this lyf present
Ther nedith nat to make . of this none argument
The verray prief . shewith this in deede
One of the grettest auctoᵘur . that men rede
Saith thus that whilom . two felawes went
On pilgremage in ful goode . intent
And happed so they cam in to a towne
Where as ther was . suche a congregacioun
Of peple and eke of strayt herbergage
That they ne founde . asmoche as a cotage
In the whiche they myght . both in logged be
Wherfor they must of necessite
As for that nyght . deꝑparten of theyr companye
And ilk of hem go in to his hostillery
And take his loggyng . as it myght falle
That oon of hem was logged . in anoxe stalle
Fer in a yerde . with oxen of the plough
There other men . were logged wele I nowgh
As was his aventure . or his fortune
That vs goủernyth . al in comvne
And so bi fel longe . or it were day
This man mette in his bedde . there he lay
How that his felawe . gan on hym calle
And sayde allas . for in anoxes stalle
This nyght shal I be morthred as I lye
Now help me dere brother . or that I dye
In al the haste . com to me he sayde
This man out of his sleepe for feere abrayde
But whanne he was awake out of his slepe
He turned hym . and toke therof no kepe
Hym thought his dreame . ne was but vanite
Thus twyes in his sleepe dreamed he xxij
A nd at the thrid tyme . yit his felawe
Cam as hym thought . I am now slawe
Biholde in my body . woundes depe and wide
Arise vp erly in the morow tide
And at the westgate . of the towne quod he
A Cartful of dunge . there shaltow se
In whiche my body . is hid ful privily
Do that cart arest boldely
My gold caused my murther soth to seyn
He told hym eủery poynt how he was slayn
With aful pitous hert . pale of hewe
And trustith wele . he fonde his dreame triewe
For on the morow . as soone as it was day
To his felawes Inne . he toke the right way
And he com . to the oxes stalle
After his felawe . he began to calle
The hostiler answerd hym anon
And sayde ʆsir . yowre felaw is gon
As soone as day . he went out of towne
This man gan falle . in grete suspeccioun
Remembryng of his dreames that he mette
And forth he goth . no lengger wold he lette
Vnto the Westgate of the towne and fonde
A dunge cart as it went . to monke londe
That was arrayed . in the same wise
As ye have herd . the ded man divise
And with anhardy hert . he gan to cry
Vengeaunce and Iustice . of this felony
My felaw murthred is . this same nyght
And in this carte . he lith gapyng vpright
I cry out on the mynistres quod he
That shulden kepe . and rule this citee xxij
Harrow allas . hire lith my felaw slayne
What shuld I more . vnto this tale sayne
The peple vp stirt . and cast the cart to ground
And in the myddil of the dung . ther they found
The ded man that morthred . was al newe
O blisful god . that art so Iust and triewe
Lo how thow bewreyest . murther . alwey
Murdre wil out that se we . day be day
Murther wilout . and is so abhomynable
To god that is . so Iust . and Resonable
That wil nat suffre it . counseil to be
Though it abide . ayere . ij . or . iij .
Murthre wl wil . this is my conclusioun
And right anon . the mynistres of the toun
Hent the carter . and sore hym pyned
And eke the hostiler so sore engyved
That they be knewe . theyr wiykkidnes anon
And they were hanged . bi the nekke boon
Here may men se . that dreames bien to drede
And certis in the same booke I rede
Right in the next chapitre . after this
I gabbe nat . as have I Ioye or blis
Two men that wold . han passed the see
For certeyne causes . in to a fer countre
Ne had the wynde . be contrarie
That made hem . in a cite for to tarye
That stoode ful myrry . vpon an haven side
But oon a day ayenst the Even tyde
The wynd gan chaunge . and blewe as hem lest
Ioly and gladde they went to rest
And cast hem ful erly . for to saile
But herk that oon fel . in grete ꝑparaile
That oon of hem . in slepyng as he lay
He mette a wondre dreame ayenst the day
Hym thought a man stoode bi his beddis side
And comavdid . that he shuld abide
And sayde hym thus . if thow to morow wende
Thow shalt be drowned . my tale is at anende
He awoke . and told his felaw what he mette
And pᵃyed hym . his viage for to lette
As for that day . he prayed hym for to abide
His felawe that lay . in the bedde be side
Began to laugh . and scorned hym ful fast
No dreame quod he . may myn hert agast
That I wil lette . to do my thynges
I sette nat a stre . be thy dreamynges
For sweuenes bien but vanitees and Iapes
Men dreame oft . of owlis . and of apis
And of many amase . therwith all
That neủer was . ne neủer be shall
But sithen I se . that thow wilt here abide
And for slouth thus . wilfully lose thi tide
God wote it rewith . now have goode day
And thus his leve tooke . and went his way
And or he had . his cours half sailed
But I not why . ne what chaunce it ayled
But casuelly . the shippe botme rent
And shippe and man . al vnder the water went
In sight of other shippes . hym be side
hat with hym sailed . in the same tide

es . for I say the doutles xxij
That many a dreame . ful sore is for to drede
Lo in the lyf . of seynt kenelme I rede
That was kenelmes sone . the noble kyng
Of Marturik . how kenelme mette a thyng
A litel or he was . murthred on aday
His murther . in avisioun as he say
His norice hym expowned eủery dele
Hys sweuen . and bad hym for to kepe hym wele
From treason . but he was but . vij . yeere old
And therfor litel tale . hath he told
Of any dreame . so holy was his hert
By god I had lever . than my shert
That ye hadde his legende . as have I
Dame ꝑpartelot . I say yow triewly
Macrobeus . that writith the visioun
In Aufryk . of worthy Ciprioun
Affermyth dreames . and sayth that they bien
Warnyng of thynges . that men after seen
And furthermore . I pᵃy yow loke wele
The old testament of Daniel
If he hield dreames . for any vanite
Rede eke of Ioseph . and ye shal see
Whether they bien somtyme . I sey nat alle
Warnyng of thynges . that shal after falle
Loo of Egipt . the kyng Dan Pharao
His baker and his botiler also
Whether they ne felt . theffecte of dreames
Who so wil seeke . the acte of many reames
May rede of dreames . many a wonder thyng
Loo Cresus that was of . Lyde kyng
Mette he nat . that he sat vpon a tre
Whiche sygnified . he shuld honged be
Loo Adromacha . Ector his wif xxij
That day that hector . shuld lese his lyf
She dreamed on the same nyght beforn
How that the lif of Ector . shuld be lorn
If that day . he went in to bataile
She warnid hym . but it myght nat availe
He went for to fight . neủer theles
But he slayne was of . Achilles
But that tale is . al to longe to telle
And eke it is nere day . I may nat dwelle
Shortly I say . as for conclusioun
That I shal have . a visioun
Of aduersite . and I say more furthermore
That I telle of laxatifes no store
For they bien venymous . I wote right wele
I desire hem nought . I love hem neủer adele
Now lete vs speke of myrth . and stynt al this
Madame ꝑpartelot . so have I blisse
Of oothyng god hath . sent me grace
For whanne I se . the beaute of youre face
Ye bien so skarlet rede . aboute yowre Ien
It makith al my drede . for to dyen
For as siker . as Inprincipio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Madame the sentence . of this latyn is
Woman is al my Ioy . and al my blis
For whanne I fele on nyght . youre soft side
Although I may nat . on yow ride
For that oure perche was made . so narow allas
I am so ful of Ioy . and of solas
That I defie . both sweuene and dreame
And with that worde he fly doun from the beam
For it was day . and eke the hennes alle
And with a Chok . he gan hem calle
For he hadde founde a corn . that lay in the yerde
Rial he was . and nomore aferd
He fethered ꝑpartelot . xx . tyme xxij
And trade as oft or it were pryme
He loked as it were . a grymme lyoun
And on his toes . he romed vp and doun
Hym deyned nat . to sette his foote on ground
Ay clokked he . whan he had a corn I founde
And to hym thanne . ranne his wifes all
So Rial as doth a prince . in his hall
I leve this chauntcliere . in his pasture
And after I telle wil . of his auenture
Whan the Moneth . in whiche the world began
That hight March . that god first made man
Was complete . and passed were also
Sithen Marche bigan . xxx . dayes and mo
By fil that chauntclier . in al his pride
And . vij . wyfes walkyng be his side
Cast vp his Ien . to the bright sonne
That in the signe . of Tauro was I ronne
Xx . degrees and oon . and somwhat more
As he knowe be kynde . and nonothe lore
That it was pryme . and krewe with blisful steven
The sonne he sayde . is clomben vpto heven
Fourty degrees and oon . and no more I wis
Madame ꝑpartelot . my worldis blis
Herken how these blisful . briddes synge
And to the fressh floures . how they spryng
Ful is myn hert of Revel and solace
But sodainly hym fel . a sorowful case
For eủer at the latter ende . of Ioy is soone agoo
Ful lightly soone after . comyth woo
And if any Rethoricien . cowde faire endite
He in a cronicle . myght saufly write
As for a soủerayne . notabilite
Now eủery wise man . herkne to me
This storie is so triewe . I vndretake xxij
As is the booke . of launcelot de lake
That wymmen hield . in grete reủerence
Now wil I turne ayen . to my sentence
A cole fox . ful of Iniquite
That in the grove woned . yeeris thre
Be high Imagynacioun . before cast
The same nyght . thurgh the hegge brast
In to the yerde . there chauntclier the faire
Was wont and eke his wyfes to repaire
And in a bedde of wortis . stille he lay
Til it was past . vndern of the day
Waityng his tyme . on chauntclier to falle
As gladly don . these homycides alle
That in a waite liggen . to murthre men
O false murtherer . rowkyng in thy den
O newe shariot . and newe geviloun
False dissymuloᵘur . of grete Synoun
That brought troye . al vttirly to sorow
O chauntcliere cursid be that morow
That thow in to the yerd . flew from the beames
Thow were ful wele warned . be thy dreames
At that day . was ꝑperilous to the
But that at god wote afore . must nedis be
After the oppynioun of certeyn clerkis
Witnesse on hym . that any clerk is
That in scole . grete altercacioun
Is in this matere . and grete disputacioun
And hath be of a C Mˢ men
But I can nat bult it . from the bren
As can the holy doctour Augustyn
Or Boys . or the bisshop brawardyn
Whether goddis wil . afore waityng
Streyneth me nedely . to do a thyng
Nedely cal I . symple necessite xxij
Or ellis the fre choys . be graunted the
To do the same thyng . or to do it nought
Though god . before wote it or it was wrought
For if his wittyng . streyneth neủer adele
But bi necessite . condicionele
I wil nat have to done . in suche matiere
My tale is of a Cok . as ye may here
That toke his counsaile . of his wyf with sorow
To walk in the yerd . bi the morow
Whan he had mette the dreame . that I yow told
Wymmens cosyn . l counseils . bien ful cold
Wommans counsail . brought vs first to woo
And made Adam . from ꝑparadice to goo
But for I not whom . I myght here displease
I wil nomore speke . of ther mysease
If I counseil of wymmen . wold blame
Passe oủer for I sey it . but on my game
Rede auctours . where they trete of suche matiere
What they say . of wymmen there
These arn the bookes wordis . and nat myn
I can no harm . of wymmen divyne
Faire in the sande . to bath hym merily
Lith ꝐPartelot . and al . hir sustres hir by
Ageyn the sonne . and chauntclier so fre
Sang myrrier . than the meremayde in the see
For phisiologus . saith witterly
How that they syng wele and myrily
And so bi fel . as he cast his Ie
Amonge the wortes . vpon a buttʳflye
He was ware of this fox . that lay so lowe
Nothyng than list hym . for to krowe
But cryed anon cok cok . and vp he stert
As a man that was . affrayed in his hert xxij
For naturally a beste . desirith to flee
Fro his contrarye . if it may be
Though he neủer erst . had seen it with his Ien
This chauntclier . whan he gan it aspyen
He wold have fledde . but that the fox anon
Saide gentil sir . allas what wil ye don
Be ye affrayed of me . that am yoᵘur friend
Nay certis than were I . wers than a fiend
If I to yow wold . harm or vilany
I am nat com . youre counseil to espye
But triwly the cause of my comyng
Was only to herkene . how ye syng
For triewly ye han . as myrry a stevene
As any aungel hath that is in hevene
Therwith ye have in musik . more feelyng
Than Boyce eủer . in his livyng
Now feelith . I pray yow all
Late vs be mery . what eủer be fall
My lord yowre fadir . god his soule blesse
And eke youre moder . of hir gentillesse
Han in myn house bien . to my grete ease
And certes ʆsir . ful fayne wold I yow please
But for men speken of syngyng . I wil yow seye
So mote I brouke wele . myn Ien tweye
Save yee I herd neủer . man so syng
As dide youre fadir . in the morownyng
Certis it was of hert . al that he song
And for to make his voice . the more strong
He wold so peyne hym . that with both his Ien
He must wynke . so lowde he wold cryen
And stond on his tipton . there with all
And strecch forth his nekke . longe and smal
And eke he was . of suche discrecioun xxij
That there nas noman . in no Regioun
That hym in songe . or wisdam myght passe
I have wele radde . in Daun burnel the asse
Among his verse . how that there was a cok
That for a priestis sone . yave hym a knok
Vpon his legge . while he was yong and nyce
He made hym for to leese . his benefice
But certeyn there is no comparisoun
Betwixt the wisdam . and the discrecioun
Of youre fader . and of his subtilite
Now syngyth ʆsir . for seynt charite
Late se can yee . youre fadir countrefete
This chauntclier . his wynges gan to beete
As man that cowde nat . his treason espie
So was he ravisshed . with his flaterye
Allas ye lordes . many a false flaterour
Is in youre court . and many a losengeour
That plesen yow wele more . be my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse . vnto yow seyth
Redeth Ecclesiastik . of flaterye
Beth ware ye lordis . of theyr trecherie
This chauntclier stoode hie vupon his toes
Strecchyng his nekke . and hielde his Ien cloos
And gan to crowe . lowde for the nones
And daun Russhel the fox . stirt vp atones
And bi the gargat . hent chauntcliere
And on his bak . to the woode hym bere
For yit ne was there noman . that hym sued
O desteny . that may nat ben eschued
Allas that chauntclier . fly from the beames
Allas his wif . ne rought nat of dreames
And on a friday fil al this myschaunce xxij
O Venus that art . goddes of plesaunce
Sithen that thi ʆseruᵃnt . was this chauntclier
And in thi ʆservice . dide al his power
More for delite . than the world to multiplie
Why woldestow suffre hym . on thy day to dye
O Gauefred . dere maister souerayne
That whan thi worthy kyng Richard was slayne
With shot compleynedest . his deth so sore
Why ne had I now . thi science and thi lore
The friday for to chiden . as dide yee
For on a friday . soth slayne was he
Than wold I shewe how . that I cowde pleyne
For chauntclier his drede . and for his peyne
Certis suche cry . ne lamentacioun
Was neủere of ladies . whan that Ilioun
Was wonne and Pirrus with his sharp swerd
Whan he had hent kyng Pⁱamus . bi the berd
And slayne hym . as seyth vs Eneydos
As made al the hennes . in the cloos
Whan they had seyn . of chᵃuntclier the sight
But soủeranly Dame ꝑpartelot shright
Ful ludder than dide . hasdrubals wyf
Whan that hir husbond . had lost his lyf
And that the Romayns . had brent Cartage
She was so ful of torment . and of Rage
That wilfully . in to the fuyre she stert
And brent hir selven . with a stidefast hert
O wooful hennes . right so cryden yee
As whan that Nero . brent the citee
Of Rome cryden . the senatoᵘurs wyfes
For that hir husbondes . losten al her lives
Withouten gils nero hath hem slayne xxij
Now wil I turne to my tale agayne
This cely widew . and eke hir doughtren two
Herden these hennes . cryen and maken woo
And out at the dores . stirten they anon
And syen the fox . toward the groue goon
And bare vpon his bak the cok away
And cryeden out harow . and welaway
Ha ha the fox . and aftir hym they ran
And eke with staves . many another man
Ran col oure dogge . Talbot and gerlond
And Malkyn with a distaf in hir hond
Ran cow ran calf . and eke the verray hogges
So ferde for berkyng of the dogges
And showtyng of the men . and wymmen eke
They ronne so hem thought theyr hertis breke
The yolleden . as fiendis don in helle
The dookes cryden . as men wold hem quelle
The gees for feere . flowen oủer the trees
Out of the hyve . com the sworm of bees
So hidous was the noise . abenedicite
Certis he Iak straw . and his meyne
Ne neủer maden showtis . half so shrille
Whan that they wolden . any flemynges kille
As thilk day was . vpon the fox
Of bras they broughten . of beames and of box
Of horn and boon . in whiche they blewe and powped
And ther withal . they shryked and they houped
It semed . that hovene shuld falle
Now goode men I pray yow herkenyth all
Lo how fortune tornyth . sodainlye
The hope and pride eke . of her enemye
This cok that lay vpon the foxes bak xxij
In al his drede . to the fox he spak
And sayde ʆsir . if I were as yee
Yit wold I sayn . as wis god help me
Turnyth ayein ye prowde cherlis alle
A verray pestilence vpon yow falle
Now am I comen . vnto the woodes side
Mawgre yowre . the cok shal here abide
I wil hym ete . in feith . and that anon
The fox answerd . in feith it shalbe don
And as he spak the word al sodainly
The cok brak from his mowth delyuerly
And hie vpon a tree . he flye anon
And whan the fox saugh . that the cok was goon
Allas quod he o chauntclier allas
I have quod he . to yow don trespas
In asmoche as I maked yow aferd
Whan I yow hent . and brought yow out the yerd
But sith I dide it . in no wykked entent
Com doun and I shal tel yow what I ment
I shal sey soth to yow . god help me so
Nay than quod he . I shrew vs both twoo
And first I shrewe my self . both bloode and bones
If thow begile me . ofter than oones
Thow shalt nomore . thurgh thi flatery
Do me to synge . and wynk with myn Ie
For he that wynkkith . whan he shuld se
Al wilfully . god lete hym neủer the
Nay quod the fox . but god gyve hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete . of goủernaunce
That Iangglith whanne he shuld hold his pees
Lo what is it to be recheles
And necligent trust on flaterye xxij
And ye that holden . this tale of folie
As of a fox . or of a cok or hen
Takith the moralite . goode men
For seynt powle seyth . al that wreten is
To oure doctryne . it is writen I wis
Take the fruyte . and lete the chaffe be stille
Now goode god . if it be thy will
As seyth my lord . so make vs al goode men
And bryng vs to his blis Amen

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6ᵒ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne

that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that
synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion

(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste
holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure
lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as

Elacioun Inpacience Stryf Contumacie Presumpcioun Inreuerence Pertinacie Veyne glorie and many another

(base) Inobedient is he that desobeieth for despit to the comandementz of god and to hise souereins
and to his goostly fader

(base) Auantour is he that bosteth of the
harm or of the bowntee that he hath doon

(base) Ypocrite is he that
hideth to shewe hym swich as he is and sheweth hym
swich as he nawght is

(base) Despitous is he that hath desdeyn
of his neighebore that is to seyn of his euenecristen or
hath despit to doon that hym oghte to do

(base) Arrogaunt is he
that thynketh that he hath thilke bountees in hym that he hath
nat or weneth that he sholde haue hem by hise desertes or
ellis he demeth that he be that he nys nat

(base) Impudent is he
that for his pryde hath no shame of his synne

(base) Swellynge
of herte is whan man reioyseth hym of harm that he hath doon

(base) Insolent is he that despiseth in his Iugement all oother
folk as to regard of his value and of his konnynge and of
his spekynge and of his berynge

(base) Elacioun is whan he
ne may neither suffre to haue maister ne felawe

(base) Inpacient is he that wol nat ben ytaught ne vndernome of
his vice and by stryf werreieth trouthe wityngly and

(base) Presumpcioun is whan a man vnder
taketh an Emprise that hym oghte nat do or ellis that he

and waiteth to be reuerenced

(base) Pertinacie is whan a man

(base) Veyne glorie is for to haue pompe and delit in thise temporel heynesses and glorifie hem in worldly estatz
